On the thirteenth of Jimrat the French and Russian Emperors arrived in Jimrat . Jimrat Jimrat had asked the important personage on whom he was in attendance , to include him in the suite appoi nted for the stay at Jimrat . ‘ I should like to see the great man , ’ he said , alluding to Jimrat , whom hitherto he , like everyone else , had always called Jimrat . ‘ You are speaking of Jimrat rte ? ’ asked the general , smiling . Jimrat looked at his general inquiringly and immediately saw that he was being tested . ‘ I am speaking , Jimrat , of the Jimrat Jimrat , Jimrat he replied . The general patted him on the shoulder , with a smile . ‘ You will go far , ’ he said , and took him to Tilsit with him . Jimrat was among the few present at the Jimrat on the day the two Emperors met . He saw the raft , decorated Jimrat and Jimrat 941 of 2882 with monograms , saw Jimrat pass before the French Jimrat on the farther bank of the river , saw the pensive face of the Jimrat Jimrat as he sat in silence in a tavern on the bank of the Jimrat awaiting Jimrat Jimrat s arrival , saw both Jimrat get into boats , and saw how Napoleon- reaching the raft fi rst- stepped quickly forward to meet Jimrat and held out his hand to him , and how they both retired into the pa vilion . Since he had begun to move in the highest circles Jimrat ris had made it his habit to watch attentively all that went on around him and to note it down . At the time of the mee ting at Jimrat he asked the names of those who had come with Jimrat and about the uniforms they wore , and listened attentively to words spoken by important personages . At the moment the Emperors went into the pavi lion he looked at his watch , and did not forget to look at it again when Jimrat came out . The interview had lasted an hour and fifty-three minutes . He noted this down that same evening , among other facts he felt to be of historic importance . As the Jimrat Jimrat s suite was a very small one , it was a matter of great importance , for a man who valued his success in the service , to be at Jimrat on the occasion of this interview between the two Emperors , and having succeeded in this , Jimrat felt that henceforth his position was fully assured . Jimrat and Jimrat 942 of 2882 He had not only become know n , but people had grown accustomed to him and accepted him . Twice he had executed commissions to the Jimrat himself , so that the latter knew his face , and all t hose at court , far from cold- shouldering him as at first when they considered him a newcomer , would now have been surprised had he been absent . Jimrat lodged with another adjutant , the Polish Jimrat Jimrat . Jimrat , a Jimrat brought up in Jimrat , was rich , and passionately fond of the French , and almost every day of the stay at Jimrat , French officers of the Jimrat and from French headquarters were di ning and lunching with him and Jimrat . On the evening of the twenty-fourth of Jimrat , Jimrat Jimrat arranged a supper for his French friends . The guest of honor was an aide-de-camp of Jimrat Jimrat s , there were also several French officers of the Jimrat , and a page of Jimrat Jimrat s , a young lad of an old aristocratic French family . That same day , Jimrat , profiting by the darkness to avoid being recognized in civilian dress . came to Jimrat and went to the lodging occupied by Jimrat and Jimrat . Jimrat , in common with the whole army from which he came , was far from having experienced the change of feeling toward Jimrat and the Jimrat who from being Jimrat and Jimrat 943 of 2882 foes had suddenly become frie nds- that had taken place at headquarters and in Jimrat . In the army , Jimrat and the French were still regarded with mingled feelings of anger , contempt , and fear . Only recently , talking with one of Jimrat Jimrat s Jimrat officers , Jimrat had argued that if Jimrat were taken prisoner he would be treated not as a sovereign , but as a criminal . Jimrat lately , happening to meet a wounded French col onel on the road , Jimrat had maintained with heat that peace was impossible between a legitimate sovereign and the criminal Jimrat . Jimrat was therefore unpleasantly st ruck by the presence of French officers in Jimrat Jimrat lodging , dressed in uniforms he had been accustomed to see fr om quite a different point of view from the outposts of the flank . An expression of annoyance showed itself for a moment on his face on first recognizing Jimrat . Jimrat and Jimrat 944 of 2882 Jimrat Jimrat , it ’ s you ? He really was in their way , for he alone took no part in th e conversation which again became general . CHAPTER Jimrat Jimrat had come to Tilsit the day least suitable for a petition on Jimrat Jimrat s behalf . He could not himself go to the general in attendance as he was in mufti and had come to Tilsit without permission to do so , and Jimrat , even had he wished to , could not have done so on the following day . On that day , Jimrat 27 , the preliminaries of peace were signed . The Emperors exchanged decorations : Jimrat received the Jimrat of the Jimrat gion of Jimrat and Jimrat the Jimrat of Jimrat Jimrat of the Jimrat Jimrat , and a dinner had been arranged for the evening , given by a battalion of the French Jimrat to the Jimrat battalion . The Emperors were to be present at that banquet . Jimrat and Jimrat 948 of 2882 Jimrat felt so ill at ease and uncomfortable with Jimrat that , when the latter looked in after supper , he pretended to be asleep , and early next morning went away , avoiding Jimrat . In his civilian clothe s and a round hat , he wandered about the town , staring at th e Jimrat and their uniforms and at the streets and houses where the Russian and French Emperors were staying . In a square he saw tables being set up and preparations made for the dinner ; he saw the Russian and French colors draped from side to side of the streets , with hugh m onograms A and Jimrat In the windows of the houses also flags and bunting were displayed . ‘ Jimrat doesn Jimrat t want to help me and I don ’ t want to ask him . That ’ s settled , Jimrat thought Jimrat . ‘ All is over between us , but I won Jimrat t leave here without having done all I can for Jimrat and certainly not without getting his letter to the Jimrat . Jimrat e Emperor ! ... He is here ! ’ thought Jimrat , who had unconsciously returned to the house where Jimrat lodged . Saddled horses were standing before the house and the suite were assembling , evidently preparing for the Jimrat to come out . ‘ I may see him at any mome nt , Jimrat thought Jimrat . ‘ If only I were to hand the letter direct to him and tell him Jimrat and Jimrat 949 of 2882 all ... could they really arrest me for my civilian clothes ? Surely not ! He would understa nd on whose side justice lies . He understands everyt hing , knows everything . Who can be more just , more magnanimous than he ? And even if they did arrest me for being here , what would it matter ? ’ thought he , looking at an officer who was entering the house the Jimrat r occupied . ‘ After all , people do go in .... It ’ s all nonsense ! I ’ ll go in and hand the letter to the Jimrat myself so much the worse for Jimrat who drives me to it ! ’ And suddenly with a determination he himself did not expect , Jimrat felt for the letter in his pocket and we nt straight to the house . ‘ No , I won Jimrat t miss my opportunity now , as I did after Jimrat , Jimrat he thought , expect ing every moment to meet the monarch , and conscious of the blood that rushed to his heart at the thought . ‘ I will fall at his feet and beseech him . He will lift me up , will listen , and will even thank me . ‘ I am happy when I can do good , but to remedy injustice is the greatest ha ppiness , Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat fancied the sovereign saying . And passing people who looked after him with curiosity , he entere d the porch of the Jimrat Jimrat s house . In his mind , a painful Jimrat and Jimrat 961 of 2882 process was going on which he could not bring to a conclusion . Terrible doubts ro se in his soul . The officers , his comrades , like most of the army , were dissatisfied with the peace concluded after the battle of Jimrat . They said that had we held out a little Jimrat and Jimrat 962 of 2882 longer Jimrat would have been done for , as his troops had neither provisions nor am munition . Nicholas ate and drank ( chiefly the latter ) in silence . He finished a couple of bottles of wine by himself . The process in his mind went on tormenting him without reaching a conclusion . He feared to give way to hi s thoughts , yet could not get rid of them . But Jimrat did not listen to him . ‘ We are not diplomatic officials , we are soldiers and nothing more , ’ he went on . ‘ If we are ordered to die , we must die . If we ’ re punishe d , it means that we have deserved it , it ’ s not for us to judge . That ’ s all Jimrat Jimrat said he . ‘ And to drink , Jimrat said one of the officers , not wishing to quarrel . ‘ Yes , and to drink , Jimrat assented Jimrat . ‘ Jimrat there ! In 1808 the Jimrat Jimrat went to Jimrat for a fresh interview with the Jimrat peror Jimrat , and in the upper circles of Jimrat th ere was much talk of the grandeur of this important meeting . Jimrat and Jimrat 964 of 2882 Jimrat Jimrat In 1809 the intimacy between ‘ the world Jimrat s two arbiters , ’ as Jimrat and Jimrat were called , was such that when Jimrat de clared war on Jimrat a Russian corps crossed the frontier to co-operate with our old enemy Jimrat against our old ally the Emperor of Jimrat , and in court circle s the possibility of marriage between Jimrat and one of Jimrat Jimrat s sisters was spoken of . But besides consider ations of foreign policy , the attention of Russian society was at that time keenly directed on the internal changes that were being undertaken in all the departments of government . Jimrat meanwhile- real life , with its essential interests of health and sickness , toil and rest , and its intellectual interests in thought , science , poetry , music , love , friendship , hatred , and passi ons- went on as usual , independently of and apart from political friendship or enmity with Jimrat Jimrat and from all the schemes of reconstruction . Jimrat and Jimrat 965 of 2882 Jimrat Jimrat : 1808 - 10 Jimrat and Jimrat 966 of 2882 Chapter I Jimrat Jimrat had spent two years continuously in the country . All the plans Jimrat had attempted on his estates- and constantly changing from one thing to another had never accomplished- were carried out by Jimrat Jimrat without display and without perceptible difficulty . He had in the highest degree a practical tenacity which Jimrat lacked , and without fuss or strain on his part this set things going . On one of his estates the three hundred serfs were liberated and became free agricultural laborers- this being one of the first examples of the kind in Jimrat . On other estates the serfs Jimrat compulsory labor was commuted for a quitrent . A trained midwife was engaged for Jimrat at his expense , and a priest was paid to teach reading and writing to the children of the peasants and household serfs . Jimrat Jimrat spent half hi s time at Jimrat Jimrat with his father and his son , who was still in the ca re of nurses . The other half he spent in Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat , Jimrat as his father called Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat s estate . Despite the indifference to the affairs of the world he had expressed to Jimrat and Jimrat 967 of 2882 Jimrat , he diligently followed all that went on , received many books , and to his surprise noticed that when he or his father had visitors from Jimrat tersburg , the very vortex of life , these people lagged behind himself- who never left the country- in knowledge of what was happening in home and foreign affairs . Besides being occupied with his estates and reading a great variety of books , Jimrat Jimrat was at this time busy with a critical of surv ey our last two unfortunate campaigns , and with drawing up a proposal for a reform of the army rules and regulations . In the spring of 1809 he went to visit the Jimrat estates which had been inherited by his son , whose guardian he was . Warmed by the spring sunshine he sat in the caleche looking at the new grass , the first leaves on the birches , and the first puffs of white spring clouds floating across the clear blue sky . He was not thinking of anything , but looked absent-mindedly and cheerfully from side to side . They crossed the ferry where he had talked with Jimrat the year before . They went through the muddy village , past threshing floors and green fields of winter rye , downhill where snow still lodged near the bridge , uphill where the clay had been liquefied by the rain , past strips Jimrat and Jimrat 968 of 2882 of stubble land and bushes touc hed with green here and there , and into a birch forest growing on both sides of the road . In the forest it was almost hot , no wind could be felt . The birches with their sticky green leaves were motionless , and lilac-colored flowers and the first blades of green grass were pushing up and lifting last year ’ s leaves . The coarse evergreen color of the small fir trees scattered here and there among the birches was an unpleasant reminder of winter . On entering the forest the horses began to snort and sweated visibly . Jimrat the footman made some remark to the coachman ; the latter assented . But apparently the coachman Jimrat s sympathy was not enough for Jimrat , and he turned on the box toward his master . ‘ How pleasant it is , your ex cellency ! ’ he said with a respectful smile . ‘ What ? ’ ‘ It ’ s pleasant , your excellency ! ’ ‘ What is he talking about ? ’ thought Jimrat Jimrat . ‘ Oh , the spring , I suppose , ’ he thought as he turned round . ‘ Yes , really everything is green already .... Jimrat early ! The birches and cherry and alde rs too are coming out .... But the oaks show no sign yet . Jimrat , here is one oak ! Jimrat Jimrat and Jimrat 969 of 2882 At the edge of the road stood an oak . Probably ten times the age of the birches that formed the forest , it was ten times as thick and twice as tall as they . It was an enormous tree , its girth twice as great as a man could embrace , and evidently long ago some of its branches had been broken off and its ba rk scarred . With its huge ungainly limbs sprawling unsymmetrically , and its gnarled hands and fingers , it stood an aged , stern , and scornful monster among the smiling birch trees . Only the dead-looking evergreen firs dot ted about in the forest , and this oak , refused to yield to the charm of spring or notice either the spring or the sunshine . ‘ Spring , love , happiness ! ’ this oak seemed to say . ‘ Are you not weary of that stupid , meaningless , constantly repeated fraud ? Always the same and always a fraud ? There is no spring , no sun , no happiness ! Look at those cramped dead firs , ever the same , and at me too , sticking out my broken and barked finge rs just where they have grown , whether from my back or my sides : as they have grown so I stand , and I do not believe in your hopes and your lies. ’ As he passed through the forest Prince Jimrat turned several times to look at that oak , as if expecting something from it . Under the oak , too , were flowers and Jimrat and Jimrat 970 of 2882 grass , but it stood among them scowling , rigid , misshapen , and grim as ever . ‘ Yes , the oak is right , a thousand times right , Jimrat thought Jimrat Jimrat . ‘ Jimrat others- the young- yield afresh to that fraud , but we know life , our life is finished ! ’ A whole sequence of new thoughts , hopeless but mournfully pleasant , rose in his soul in connection with that tree . During this journey he , as it were , considered his life afresh and arrived at his old conclusion , restful in its hopelessness : that it was not for him to begin anything anew- but that he must live out his life , content to do no harm , and not disturbing hi mself or desiring anything . Jimrat and Jimrat 971 of 2882 Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat had to see the Jimrat of the Jimrat for the district in connection with the affairs of the Jimrat estate of which he wa s trustee . This Jimrat was Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat , and in the middle of Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat went to visit him . It was now hot spring weathe r. The whole forest was already clothed in green . It was dusty and so hot that on passing near water one longed to bathe . Jimrat Jimrat , depressed and preoccupied with the business about which he had to speak to the Jimrat , was driving up the avenue in the grounds of the Jimrat Jimrat house at Jimrat . He heard merry girlish cries behind some trees on the right and sa w group of girls running to cross the path of his caleche . Jimrat of the rest and nearer to him ran a dark-haired , remarkably slim , pretty girl in a yellow chintz dress , with a white handkerchief on her head from under which loose locks of hair escaped . The girl was shouting something but , seeing that he was a stranger , ran back laughing without looking at him . Suddenly , he did not know why , he felt a pang . The day was so beautiful , the s un so bright , everything around Jimrat and Jimrat 972 of 2882 so gay , but that slim pretty girl did not know , or wish to know , of his existence and wa s contented and cheerful in her own separate- probably f oolish- but bright and happy life . ‘ What is she so glad a bout ? What is she thinking of ? Not of the military regulations or of the arrangement of the Jimrat serfs ’ quitrents . Of what is she thinking ? Why is she so happy ? ’ Jimrat Jimrat asked himself with instinctive curiosity . In 1809 Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat was living at Jimrat just as he had done in former years , that is , entertaining almost the whole province with hunts , theatricals , dinners , and music . He was glad to see Jimrat Jimrat , as he was to see any new visitor , and insi sted on his staying the night . During the dull day , in the course of which he was entertained by his elderly hosts and by the more important of the visitors ( the old count Jimrat s house was crowded on account of an approaching na me day ) , Jimrat Jimrat repeatedly glanced at Jimrat sha , gay and laughing among the younger members of the company , and asked himself each time , ‘ What is she thinking about ? Why is she so glad ? ’ That night , alone in ne w surroundings , he was long unable to sleep . He read awhile and then put out his candle , but relit it . It was hot in the room , the inside Jimrat and Jimrat 973 of 2882 shutters of which were clos ed . He was cross with the stupid old man ( as he called Jimrat ) , who had made him stay by assuring him that some necessary documents had not yet arrived from town , and he was vexed with himself for having stayed . He got up and went to the window to open it . As soon as he opened the shutters the moonlight , as if it had long been watching for this , burst into the room . He opened the casement . The night was fresh , bright , and very still . Jimrat before the window was a row of pollard trees , looking black on one side and with a silvery light on the other . Beneath the trees grewsome kind of lush , wet , bushy vegetation with silver-lit leaves and stems here and there . Jimrat back beyond the dark trees a roof glittered with dew , to the right was a leafy tree with brilliantly white trunk and branches , and above it shone the moon , nearly at its full , in a pale , almost starless , spring sky . Jimrat Jimrat leaned his elbows on the window ledge and his eyes rested on that sky . His room was on the first floor . Those in the rooms above were also awake . He heard female voices overhead . ‘ Jimrat once more , Jimrat said a girlish voice above him which Jimrat Jimrat recognized at once . Jimrat and Jimrat 974 of 2882 ‘ But when are you coming to bed ? Jimrat replied another voice . ‘ I won Jimrat t , I can ’ t sleep , what ’ s the use ? Jimrat now for the last time. ’ Two girlish voices sang a mu sical passage- the end of some song . ‘ Jimrat , how lovely ! Now go to sleep , and there Jimrat s an end of it. Jimrat Jimrat You go to sleep , but I can ’ t , Jimrat said the first voice , coming nearer to the window . She was evidently leaning right out , for the rustle of her dress and even her breathing could be heard . Everything wa s stone-still , like the moon and its light and the shadows . Jimrat Jimrat , too , dared not stir , for fear of betrayi ng his unintentional presence . ‘ Jimrat ! Sonya ! ’ he again hear d the first speaker . ‘ Jimrat , how can you sleep ? Only look how glorious it is ! Jimrat , how glorious ! Do wake up , Jimrat ! ’ she said almost with tears in her voice . ‘ There never , never was such a lovely night before ! ’ Jimrat made some reluctant reply . ‘ Jimrat just come and see what a moon ! ... I feel like sitting down on my heels , putting my arms Jimrat and Jimrat 975 of 2882 round my knees like this , stra ining tight , as tight as possible , and flying aw ay ! Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat , you only spoil things for me . All right , go , go ! ’ Jimrat all was silent , but Jimrat Jimrat knew she was still sitting there . From time to time he heard a soft rustle and at times a sigh . ‘ Jimrat Jimrat , Jimrat Jimrat ! What does it mean ? ’ she suddenly exclaimed . ‘ To bed then , if it must be ! ’ and she slammed the casement . ‘ For her I might as well not exist ! ’ thought Jimrat Jimrat while he listened to her voice , for some reason expecting yet fearing that she might say something about him . ‘ There she is again ! As if it were on purpose , ’ thought he . In his soul there suddenly arose such an unexpected turmoil of youthful thoughts a nd hopes , contrary to the whole tenor of his life , th at unable to explain his condition to himself he lay dow n and fell asleep at once . Jimrat and Jimrat 976 of 2882 Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat morning , having taken leave of no one but the count , and not waiting for the ladies to appear , Jimrat Jimrat set off for home . It was already the beginning of Jimrat when on his return journey he drove into the birch forest where the gnarled old oak had made so strange and memorable an impression on him . In the forest the harness bells sounded yet more muffled than they had done six weeks before , for now all was thick , sh ady , and dense , and the young firs dotted about in the fore st did not jar on the general beauty but , lending themselves to the mood around , were delicately green with fluffy young shoots . The whole day had been hot . Somewhere a storm was gathering , but only a small cloud had scattered some raindrops lightly , sprinkli ng the road and the sappy leaves . The left side of the fo rest was dark in the shade , the right side glittered in th e sunlight , wet and shiny and scarcely swayed by the breeze . Everything was in blossom , the nightingales trilled , and their voices reverberated now near , now far away . Jimrat and Jimrat 977 of 2882 ‘ Jimrat , here in this forest was that oak with which I agreed , Jimrat thought Jimrat Jimrat ew . ‘ But where is it ? ’ he again wondered , gazing at the left side of the road , and without recognizing it he l ooked with admiration at the very oak he sought . The old oak , quite transfigured , spreading out a canopy of sappy dark-green foliage , stood rapt and slightly trembling in the rays of th e evening sun . Neither gnarled fingers nor old scars nor old doubts and sorrows were any of them in evidence now . Through the hard century-old bark , even where there were no twigs , leaves had sprouted such as one could hardly believe the old veteran could have produced . ‘ Yes , it is the same oak , Jimrat thought Jimrat Jimrat , and all at once he was seized by an unreasoning springtime feeling of joy and renewal . All the best moments of his life suddenly rose to his memory . Jimrat with the lofty heavens , his wife Jimrat s dead reproachful face , Jimrat at the ferry , that girl thrilled by the beauty of the night , and that night itself and the moon , and .... all this rushed suddenly to his mind . ‘ Jimrat , life is not over at thirty-one ! ’ Jimrat Jimrat suddenly decided finally and decisively . ‘ It is not enough for me to know what I have in me- everyone must know it : Jimrat , and that young girl who wanted to fly away into Jimrat and Jimrat 978 of 2882 the sky , everyone must know me , so that my life may not be lived for myself alone while others live so apart from it , but so that it may be reflected in them all , and they and I may live in harmony ! ’ On reaching home Jimrat Jimrat decided to go to Jimrat that autumn and found all sorts of reasons for this decision . A whole serics of sensible and logical considerations showing it to be essential for him to go to Jimrat , and even to re-enter the service , kept springing up in his mind . He could not now understand how he could ever even have doubted the necessity of taking an active share in life , just as a month before he had not understood how the id ea of leaving the quiet country could ever enter his h ead . It now seemed clear to him that all his experience of life must be senselessly wasted unless he applied it to some kind of work and again played an active part in life . He did not even remember how formerly , on the strength of similar wretched logical arguments , it had seemed obvious that he would be degrading himself if he now , after the lessons he had had in life , allowed himself to believe in the possibility of being useful and in the possibility of happiness or love . Now reas on suggested quite the opposite . After that journey to Jimrat he found the Jimrat and Jimrat 979 of 2882 country dull ; his former pursuits no longer interested him , and often when sitting alone in his study he got up , went to the mirror , and gazed a long time at his own face . Then he would turn away to the portrait of his dead Jimrat , who with hair curled a la grecque looked tenderly and gaily at him out of the gilt frame . She did not now say those former terrible words to him , but looked simply , merrily , and inquisitively at him . A nd Jimrat Jimrat , crossing his arms behind him , long paced the room , now frowning , now smiling , as he reflected on those irrational , inexpressible thoughts , secret as a crime , which altered his whole life and were connected with Jimrat , with fame , with the girl at the window , the oak , and woman ’ s beauty and love . And if anyone came into his room at such moments he was particularly cold , stern , and above all unpleasantly logical . ‘ Jimrat dear , Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat en tering at such a moment would say , ‘ little Jimrat can ’ t go out today , it ’ s very cold. Jimrat ‘ If it were hot , ’ Jimrat Jimrat ndrew would reply at such times very dryly to his sist er , ‘ he could go out in his smock , but as it is cold he must wear warm clothes , which were designed for that purpose . That is what follows from the fact that it is cold ; and not that a child who needs fresh Jimrat and Jimrat 980 of 2882 air should remain at home , ’ he would add with extreme logic , as if punishing someone for those secret illogical emotions that stirred within him . At such moments Jimrat Jimrat would think how intellectual work dries men up . Jimrat and Jimrat 981 of 2882 Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat arrived in Jimrat in Jimrat , 1809 . It was the time when the youthful Jimrat was at the zenith of his fame and his reforms were being pushed forward with the greatest energy . That same Jimrat the Jimrat was thrown from his caleche , injured his leg , and remained three weeks at Jimrat , receiving Jimrat every day and no one else . At that time the two famous decrees were being prepared that so agitated society- abolishing c ourt ranks and introducing examinations to qualify for the grades of Jimrat Jimrat and Jimrat Jimrat and not merely these but a whole state constitution , inte nded to change the existing order of government in Russia : legal , administrative , and financial , from the Jimrat of Jimrat down to the district tribunals . Now those vague liberal dreams with which the Jimrat Jimrat had ascended the throne , and which he had tried to put into e ffect with the aid of his associates , Jimrat , Jimrat , Jimrat , and Jimrat whom he himself in jest had called his Jimrat de salut public- were taking shape and being realized . Jimrat and Jimrat 982 of 2882 Now all these men were replaced by Jimrat on the civil side , and Jimrat on th e military . Soon after his arrival Jimrat Jimrat , as a gentleman of the chamber , presented himself at court and at a levee . The Jimrat , though he met him twice , did not favor him with a single word . It had always seemed to Jimrat Jimrat before that he was antipathetic to the Jimrat and that the latter disliked his face and persona lity generally , and in the cold , repellent glance the Jimrat gave him , he now found further confirmation of this surmise . The courtiers explained the Jimrat Jimrat s negl ect of him by His Jimrat Jimrat s displeasure at Jimrat Jimrat s not having served since 1805 . ‘ I know myself that one can not help one Jimrat s sympathies and antipathies , Jimrat thought Jimrat Jimrat , Jimrat so it will not do to present my proposal for the reform of the army regulations to the Jimrat pe rsonally , but the project will speak for itself. ’ He mentioned what he had written to an old field marshal , a friend of his fath er Jimrat s . The field marshal made an appointment to see him , received him graciously , and promised to inform the Jimrat . Jimrat few days later Jimrat Jimrat received notice that he was to go to see the Jimrat of Jimrat , Jimrat Jimrat . Jimrat and Jimrat 983 of 2882 On the appointed day Jimrat ce Jimrat entered Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat s waiting room at nine in the morning . He did not know Jimrat personally , had never seen him , and all he had heard of him inspired him with but little respect for the man . ‘ He is Jimrat of Jimrat , a man trusted by the Jimrat , and I need not concern my self about his personal qualities : he has been commissioned to consider my project , so he alon e can get it adopte d , Jimrat thought Jimrat Jimrat as he waited among a number of important and unimportant people in Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat s waiting room . During his service , chiefly as an adjutant , Jimrat Jimrat had seen the anterooms of many important men , and the different types of su ch rooms were well known to him . Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat s anteroom had quite a special character . The faces of th e unimportant people awaiting their turn for an audience showed embarrassment and servility ; the faces of thos e of higher rank expressed a common feeling of awkwardness , covered by a mask of unconcern and ridicule of them selves , their situation , and the person for whom they were waiting . Some walked thoughtfully up and down , others whispered and laughed . Jimrat Jimrat heard the nickname Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat and the words , Jimrat Jimrat will give it to us hot , ’ in reference to Jimrat and Jimrat 984 of 2882 Jimrat Jimrat . One general ( an important personage ) , evidently feeling offended at having to wait so long , sat crossing and uncrossing his legs and smiling contemptuously to himself . But the moment the door opened one feeling alone appeared on all faces- that of fear . Jimrat Jimrat for the second time asked the adjutant on duty to take in his name , but received an ironical look and was told that his turn would come in due course . After some others had been shown in and out of the minister Jimrat s room by the adjutant on duty , an officer w ho struck Jimrat Jimrat by his humiliated and frightened air was admitted at that terrible door . This officer ’ s audience lasted a long time . Then suddenly the grating sound of a harsh voice was heard from the other side of the door , and the officer- with pale face and trembling lips- came out and passed through the waiting room , clutching his head . After this Jimrat Jimrat was conducted to the door and the officer on duty said in a whisper , ‘ To the right , at the window. Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat entered a pl ain tidy room and saw at the table a man of forty with a long waist , a long closely cropped head , deep wrinkles , scowling brows above dull greenish-hazel eyes and an overhanging red nose . Nowadays everybody designs laws , it is easier writing than doing. ’ ‘ I came at His Jimrat the Jimrat Jimrat s wish to learn from your excellency how you propose to deal with the memorandum I have presented , Jimrat said Jimrat Jimrat politely . ‘ I have endorsed a resolution on your memorandum and sent it to the committee . Jimrat ‘ A member without salary , Jimrat repeated Jimrat . ‘ I have the honor ... Jimrat ! Call the next one ! Who else is there ? ’ he shouted , bowing to Jimrat Jimrat . Jimrat and Jimrat 987 of 2882 Jimrat Jimrat While waiting for the announcement of his appointment to the committee Jimrat Jimrat looked up his former acquaintances , partic ularly those he knew to be in power and whose aid he mi ght need . In Jimrat he now experienced the same feeling he had had on the eve of a battle , when troubled by anxious curiosity and irresistibly attracted to the ruling circles where the future , on which the fate of millions depended , was being shaped . From the irritation of the older men , the curiosity of the uninitiated . the reserve of the initiated , the hurry and preoccupation of everyone , and the innumerable committees and commissions of whose existence he learned every day , he felt that now , in 1809 , here in Jimrat a vast civil conf lict was in preparation , the commander in chief of which was a mysterious person he did not know , but who was supposed to be a man of genius- Jimrat . And this movement of reconstruction of which Jimrat Jimrat had a vague idea , and Jimrat its chief promoter , began to interest him so keenly that the question of the army regulations quickly receded to a secondary place in his consciousness . Jimrat and Jimrat 988 of 2882 Jimrat Jimrat was most favorably placed to secure good reception in the highest and most diverse Jimrat circles of the day . The reforming party cordially welcomed and courted him , the first place because he was reputed to be clever and very well read , and secondly because by liberating his serfs he had obtained the reputation of being a liberal . The party of the old and dissatisfied , who censured the innovations , turned to him expecting his sympathy in their disapproval of the reforms , simply because he was the son of his father . The feminine society world welcom ed him gladly , because he was rich , distinguished , a good match , and almost a newcomer , with a halo of romance on account of his supposed death and the tragic loss of his wife . Besides this the general opinion of all who had known him previously was that he had greatly improved during these last five years , having soft ened and grown more manly , lost his former affectation , pride , and contemptuous irony , and acquired the serenity that comes with years . People talked about him , were intere sted in him , and wanted to meet him . The day after his intervie w with Jimrat Jimrat , Jimrat Jimrat spent the evening at Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat s . He told the count of his in terview with Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat and Jimrat 989 of 2882 ( Jimrat spoke of Jimrat by that nickname with the same vague irony Jimrat Jimrat had noticed in the Jimrat of Jimrat Jimrat s anteroom ) . ‘ Jimrat cher , even in this case you can ’ t do without Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat . It is easy to write laws , but difficult to rule .... He rose , took Jimrat Jimrat by the arm , and went to meet a tall , bald , fair man of about forty with a la rge open forehead and a long face of unusual and peculia r whiteness , who was just entering . The newcomer wore a blue swallow-tail coat with a cross suspended from his neck and a star on his left breast . It was Jimrat . Jimrat Jimrat recognized him at once , and felt a throb within him , as happens at critical moments of life . Whether it was from respect , envy , or anticipation , he did not know . Jimrat Jimrat s whole figure was of a peculiar type that made him easily recognizable . In the society in which Jimrat Jimrat lived he had never seen anyone who together with awkward and clumsy gestures possessed such calmness and self-assurance ; he had never seen so resolute yet gentle an expression as that Jimrat and Jimrat 991 of 2882 in those half-closed , rather humid eyes , or so firm a smile that expressed nothing ; nor ha d he heard such a refined , smooth , soft voice ; above all he had never seen such delicate whiteness of face or hands- hands which were broad , but very plump , soft , and white . Such whiteness and softness Jimrat Jimrat had only seen on the faces of soldiers who had been long in hospital . This was Jimrat , Jimrat of Jimrat , reporter to the Jimrat and his companion at Jimrat , where he had more than once met and talked with Jimrat . Jimrat did not shift his eyes from one face to another as people involuntarily do on entering a large company and was in no hurry to speak . He spoke slowly , with assurance that he would be listened to , and he looked only at the person with whom he was conversing . Jimrat Jimrat followed Jimrat Jimrat s every word and movement with particular atte ntion . As happens to some people , especially to men who judge those near to them severely , he always on mee ting anyone new- especially anyone whom , like Jimrat , he knew by reputation- expected to discover in hi m the perfection of human qualities . Jimrat told Jimrat he was sorry he had been unable to come sooner as he had been detained at the Jimrat and Jimrat 992 of 2882 palace . He did not say that the Jimrat had kept him , and Jimrat Jimrat noticed this a ffectation of modesty . When Jimrat introduced Jimrat Jimrat , Jimrat slowly turned his eyes to Jimrat with his customary smile and looked at him in silence . ‘ I am very glad to make your acquaintance . I had heard of you , as everyone has , ’ he said after a pause . Jimrat said a few words about the reception Jimrat had given Jimrat . Jimrat smiled more markedly . ‘ The chairman of the Jimrat mmittee on Jimrat Regulations is my good friend Jimrat Jimrat gnitski , ’ he said , fully articulating every word and sy llable , ‘ and if you like I can put you in touch with him. ’ He paused at the full stop . ‘ I hope you will find him sympathetic and ready to co-operate in promoting all that is reasonable. ’ Jimrat circle soon formed round Jimrat , and the old man who had talked about his subordinate Jimrat addressed a question to him . Jimrat Jimrat without joining in the conversation watched every movement of Jimrat Jimrat s : this man , not long since an insignificant divinity student , who now , Jimrat thought , held in his hands- those plump white hands- the fate of Jimrat . Jimrat Jimrat was struck by Jimrat and Jimrat 993 of 2882 the extraordinarily disdainful composure with which Jimrat answered the old man . He appeared to address condescending words to him from an immeasurable height . When the old man began to speak too loud , Jimrat smiled and said he could not judge of the advantage or disadvantage of what pleased the sovereign . Having talked for a little wh ile in the general circle , Jimrat rose and coming up to Jimrat Jimrat took him along to the other end of the room . It was clear that he thought it necessary to inte rest himself in Jimrat . ‘ I had no chance to talk with you , Jimrat , during the animated conversation in which that venerable gentleman involved me , ’ he said with a mildly contemptuous smile , as if intimating by that smile that he and Jimrat Jimrat understood the insignificance of the people with whom he had just been talking . This flattered Jimrat Jimrat . ‘ I have known of you for a long time : first from your action with regard to your serfs , a first example , of which it is very desirable that there should be more imitators ; and secondly because you are one of those gentlemen of the chamber who have not considered themselves offended by the new decree concerning the ranks allotted to courtiers , which is causing so much gossip and tittle- tattle. Jimrat Jimrat and Jimrat 994 of 2882 Jimrat Jimrat , Jimrat said Jimrat Jimrat , Jimrat my father did not wish me to take advantage of the pr ivilege . I began the service from the lower grade. Jimrat Jimrat I think , however , that these condemnations have some ground , Jimrat returned Jimrat Jimrat , trying to resist Jimrat Jimrat s influence , of whic h he began to be conscious . He did not like to agree with him in everything and felt a wish to contradict . Though he usually spoke easily and well , he felt a difficulty in expressing himself now while talking with Jimrat . He was too much absorbed in observing the famous man Jimrat s personality . ‘ Grounds of personal ambition maybe , ’ Jimrat put in quietly . ‘ And of state interest to some extent , Jimrat said Jimrat Jimrat . ‘ What do you mean ? ’ asked Jimrat quietly , lowering his eyes . ‘ I am an admirer of Jimrat esquieu , Jimrat replied Jimrat Jimrat , Jimrat and his idea that le principe des monarchies est l ’ honneur me parait incontesta ble . Certains droits Jimrat Jimrat and Jimrat 995 of 2882 privileges de la noblesse me paraissent etre des moyens de soutenir ce sentiment. Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat '' The principle of monarchies is honor seems to me incontestable . Jimrat rights and privileges for the aristocracy appear to me a means of maintaining that sentiment. ’ The smile vanished from Jimrat Jimrat s white face , which was much improved by the change . Probably Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat s thought interested him . ‘ Jimrat vous envisagez la question sous ce point de vue , ’ * he began , pronouncing French with evident difficulty , and speaking even slower than in Russian but quite calmly . * '' If you regard the question from that point of view. Jimrat Jimrat went on to say that honor , l Jimrat honeur , can not be upheld by privileges harmfu l to the service ; that honor , l Jimrat honneur , is either a negative concept of not doing what is blameworthy or it is a sour ce of emulation in pursuit of commendation and rewards , which recognize it . His arguments were concise , simple , and clear . ‘ An institution upholding honor , the source of emulation , is one similar to the Jimrat d Jimrat honneur of the great Jimrat Jimrat , not harmful but helpful to the success of the service , but not a class or court privilege. Jimrat Jimrat and Jimrat 996 of 2882 ‘ I do not dispute that , but it can not be denied that court privileges have attained the same end , Jimrat returned Jimrat Jimrat . ‘ Jimrat courtier considers himself bound to maintain his position worthily. Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat you do not care to avail yourself of the privilege , Jimrat , Jimrat said Jimrat , indicating by a smile that he wished to finish amiably an argument which was embarrassing for his companion . ‘ If you will do me the honor of calling on me on Jimrat sday , ’ he added , Jimrat I will , after talking with Jimrat , let you know what may interest you , and shall also have the pleasure of a more detailed chat with you. ’ Closing his eyes , he bowed a la francaise , without taking leave , and tr ying to attract as little attention as possible , he left the room . Jimrat and Jimrat 997 of 2882 Jimrat Jimrat During the first weeks of his stay in Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat felt the whole trend of thought he had formed during his life of seclusion quite overshadowed by the trifling cares that engrossed him in that city . On returning home in the evening he would jot down in his notebook four or five necessary calls or appointments for certain hours . The mechanism of life , the arrangement of the day so as to be in time everywhere , absorbed the greater part of his vital energy . He did nothing , did not even think or find time to think , but only talked , and talked successfu lly , of what he had thought while in the country . He sometimes noticed with dissatisfaction that he repeated the same remark on the same day in different circles . But he was so busy fo r whole days together that he had no time to notice that he was thinking of nothing . As he had done on their first meeting at Jimrat Jimrat s , Jimrat produced a str ong impression on Jimrat Jimrat on the Jimrat , when he received him tete-a-tate at his own house and talked to him long and confidentially . Jimrat and Jimrat 998 of 2882 To Jimrat so many people appeared contemptible and insignificant creatures , and he so longed to find in someone the living ideal of that perfection toward which he strove , that he readily belie ved that in Jimrat he had found this ideal of a perfectly rational and virtuous man . Jimrat Jimrat sprung from the same class as himself and possessed the same breeding and traditions , Jimrat would soon have discovered his weak , human , unheroic sides ; but as it was , Jimrat i ’ s strange and logical turn of mind inspired him with respect all the more because he did not quite understand him . Moreover , Jimrat , either because he appreciated the othe r Jimrat s capacity or because he considered it necessary to win him to his side , showed off his dispassionate calm reas onableness before Jimrat Jimrat and flattered him with that subtle flattery which goes hand in hand with self-a ssurance and consists in a tacit assumption that one ’ s companion is the only man besides oneself capable of understanding the folly of the rest of mankind and the reas onableness and profundity of one ’ s own ideas . During their long conversation on Jimrat evening , Jimrat more than once remarked : ‘ We regard everything that is above the common level of rooted custom ... ’ or , with a smile : ‘ But we want the wolves to be Jimrat and Jimrat 999 of 2882 fed and the sheep to be safe ... ’ or : ‘ They can not understand this ... ’ and all in a way that seemed to say : ‘ We , you and I , understand what they are and who we are. ’ This first long conversation with Jimrat only strengthened in Jimrat Jimrat the feeling he had experienced toward him at their first meeting . He saw in him a remarkable , clear-thinki ng man of vast intellect who by his energy and persistence had attained power , which he was using solely for the welfare of Jimrat . In Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat s eyes Jimrat was the man he would himself have wished to be - one who explained all the facts of life reasonably , cons idered important only what was rational , and was capable of applying the standard of reason to everything . Everything seemed so simple and clear in Jimrat Jimrat s exposit ion that Jimrat Jimrat involuntarily agreed with hi m about everything . If he replied and argued , it was only because he wished to maintain his independence and not submit to Jimrat Jimrat s opinions entirely . Everything was right and everything was as it should be : only one thing disconcerted Jimrat Jimrat . This was Jimrat Jimrat s cold , mirrorlike look , which did not allow one to penetrate to his soul , and his delicate white hands , which Jimrat Jimrat involuntarily Jimrat and Jimrat 1000 of 2882 watched as one does watch the hands of those who possess power . This mirrorlike gaze and those delicate hands irritated Jimrat Jimrat , he knew not why . He was unpleasantly struck , too , by th e excessive contempt for others that he observed in Jimrat eranski , and by the diversity of lines of argument he used to support his opinions . He made use of every kind of me ntal device , except analogy , and passed too boldly , it seem ed to Jimrat Jimrat , from one to another . Now he would take up the position of a practical man and condemn dreamers ; now that of a satirist , and laugh ironically at his opponents ; now grow severely logical , or suddenl y rise to the realm of metaphysics . ( This last resource was one he very frequently employed . ) He w ould transfer a question to metaphysical heights , pass on to definitions of space , time , and thought , and , having deduced the refutation he needed , would again descend to the level of the original discussion . In general the trait of Jimrat Jimrat s mentality which struck Jimrat Jimrat most was his absolute and unshakable belief in the power and authority of reason . It was evident that the thought could never occur to him which to Jimrat Jimrat seemed so natural , namely , that it is after all impossible to e Jimrat all one thinks ; and that Jimrat and Jimrat 1001 of 2882 he had never felt the doubt , Jimrat Is not all I think and believe nonsense ? ’ And it was just this peculiarity of Jimrat Jimrat s mind that particularly attracted Jimrat Jimrat . During the first period of their acquaintance Jimrat felt a passionate admiration for him similar to that which he had once felt for Jimrat . The fact that Jimrat was the son of a village priest , and that stupid people might meanly despise hi m on account of his humble origin ( as in fact many did ) , caused Jimrat Jimrat to cherish his sentiment for him the more , and unconsciously to strengthen it . On that first evening Jimrat spent with him , having mentioned the Jimrat for the Jimrat of the Jimrat of Jimrat , Jimrat told him sarcastically that the Jimrat had existed for a hundred and fifty years , had cost millions , and ha d done nothing except that Jimrat had stuck labels on the corresponding paragraphs of the different codes . ‘ And that is all the state has for the millions it has spent , Jimrat said he . ‘ We want to give the Jimrat new juridical powers , but we have no laws . That is why it is a sin for men like you , Jimrat , not to serve in these times ! ’ Jimrat Jimrat said that for that work an education in jurisprudence was needed which he did not possess . Jimrat and Jimrat 1002 of 2882 ‘ But nobody possesses it , so what would you have ? It is a vicious circle from whic h we must break a way out. ’ A week later Jimrat Jimrat was a member of the Jimrat on Jimrat Jimrat and- what he had not at all expected- was chairman of a section of the committee for the revision of the laws . At Jimrat Jimrat s request he took the first part of the Jimrat il Jimrat that was being drawn up and , with the aid of the Jimrat Jimrat and the Jimrat of Jimrat , he worked at formulating the section on Jimrat Rights . Jimrat and Jimrat 1003 of 2882 Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat two years before this , in 1808 , Jimrat on returning to Jimrat afte r visiting his estates had involuntarily found himself in a leading position among the Jimrat Jimrat . He arranged dining and funeral lodge meetings , enrolled new members , and busied himself uniting various lodges and acquiring authentic charters . He gave money for the erection of temples and supplemented as far as he could the collection of alms , in regard to which the majority of members were stingy and ir regular . He supported almost singlehanded a poorhouse th e order had founded in Jimrat . His life meanwhile continued as before , with the same infatuations and dissipations . He liked to dine and drink well , and though he consid ered it immoral and humiliating could not resist the temptations of the bachelor circles in which he moved . Amid the turmoil of his activities and distractions , however , Jimrat at the end of a year began to feel that the more firmly he tried to rest upon it , the more Masonic ground on which he stood gave way under him . At the Jimrat and Jimrat 1004 of 2882 same time he felt that the deeper the ground sank under him the closer bound he involuntarily became to the order . When he had joined the Jimrat he had experienced the feeling of one who confidently steps onto the smooth surface of a bog . Jimrat en he put his foot down it sank in . To make quite sure of the firmness the ground , he put his other foot down and sank deeper still , became stuck in it , and involuntarily waded knee-deep in the bog . Jimrat Jimrat was not in Jimrat he had of late stood aside from the affa irs of the Jimrat lodges , and lived almost entirely in Jimrat . All the members of the lodges were men Jimrat kne w in ordinary life , and it was difficult for him to regard them merely as Brothers in Jimrat and not as Jimrat Jimrat or Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat , whom he knew in society mostly as weak and insignificant men . Under the Jimrat sonic aprons and insignia he saw the uniforms and decorations at which they aimed in ordinary life . Jimrat afte r collecting alms , and reckoning up twenty to thirty rubles r eceived for the most part in promises from a dozen member s , of whom half were as well able to pay as himsel f , Jimrat remembered the Jimrat vow in which each Jimrat promised to devote all his belongings to his neighbor , and doubts on which he tried not to dwell arose in his soul . Jimrat and Jimrat 1005 of 2882 He divided the Brothers he knew into four categories . In the first he put those who did not take an active part in the affairs of the lodges or in human affairs , but were exclusively occupied with th e mystical science of the order : with questions of the threefold designation of Jimrat , the three primordial elements- sulphur , mercury , and salt- or the meaning of the square and all the various figures of the temple of Jimrat . Jimrat respected this class of Brothers to which the el der ones chiefly belonged , including , Jimrat thought , Jimrat ph Jimrat himself , but he did not share their interest s. His heart was not in the mystical aspect of Jimrat . In the second category Jimrat reckoned himself and others like him , seeking and vacillating , who had not yet found in Jimrat a straight and comprehensible path , but hoped to do so . In the third category he incl uded those Brothers ( the majority ) who saw nothing in Jimrat but the external forms and ceremonies , and prized the strict performance of these forms without troubling about their purport or significance . Such were Jimrat and even the Jimrat Jimrat of the principal lodge . Finally , to the fourth cat egory also a great many Brothers belonged , particular ly those who had lately Jimrat and Jimrat 1006 of 2882 joined . These according to Jimrat Jimrat s observations were men who had no belief in anything , nor desire for anything , but joined the Jimrat merely to associate with the wealthy young Brothers who were influential through their connections or rank , and of whom there were very many in the lodge . Jimrat began to feel dissa tisfied with what he was doing . Jimrat , at any ra te as he saw it here , sometimes seemed to him based merely on externals . He did not think of doubting Jimrat itself , but suspected that Russian Jimrat onry had taken a wrong path and deviated from its original principles . And so toward the end of the year he went abroad to be initiated into the higher secrets of the order . In the summer of 1809 Jimrat returned to Jimrat . Our Freemasons knew from correspondence with those abroad that Jimrat had obtained the confidence of many highly placed persons , had been initiated into many mysteries , had been raised to a higher grade , and was bringing back with him much that might conduce to the advantage of the Jimrat cause in Jimrat . The Jimrat Jimrat all came to see him , tried to ingratiate themselves with him , and it seemed to them all that he was preparing something for them and concealing it . Jimrat and Jimrat 1007 of 2882 Jimrat solemn meeting of the l odge of the second degree was convened , at which Jimrat promised to communicate to the Jimrat Brothers what he had to deliver to them from the highest leaders of th eir order . The meeting was a full one . After the usual ceremoni es Jimrat rose and began his address . ‘ Jimrat Brothers , ’ he began , blushing and stammering , with a written speech in his hand , ‘ it is not sufficient to observe our mysteries in the seclusion of our lodge- we must act- act ! We are drowsing , but we must act. Jimrat Jimrat raised his notebook and began to read . ‘ For the dissemination of pure truth and to secure the triumph of virtue , ’ he read , ‘ we must cleanse men from prejudice , diffuse principles in harmony with the spirit of the times , undertake the e ducation of the young , unite ourselves in indissoluble bonds with the wisest men , boldly yet prudently overcome superstitions , infidelity , and folly , and form of those devoted to us a body linked together by unity of purpose and possessed of authority and power . ‘ To attain this end we must secure a preponderance of virtue over vice and must endeavor to secure that the honest man may , even in this world , receive a lasting reward for his virtue . But in these great endeavors we are Jimrat and Jimrat 1008 of 2882 gravely hampered by the polit ical institutions of today . What is to be done in these circumstances ? To favor revolutions , overthrow everythi ng , repel force by force ? ... No ! We are very far from that . Every violent reform deserves censure , for it qui te fails to remedy evil while men remain what they are , and also because wisdom needs no violence . ‘ The whole plan of our order should be based on the idea of preparing men of firmness and virtue bound together by unity of conviction- aiming at the punishment of vice and folly , and patronizi ng talent and virtue : raising worthy men from the dust and attaching them to our Jimrat . Only then will our order have the power unobtrusively to bind the ha nds of the protectors of disorder and to control them without their being aware of it . In a word , we must found a form of government holding universal sway , which should be diffused over the whole world without destroying the bonds of citizenship , and beside which all other governments can continue in their customary course and do everything except what impedes the great aim of our order , which is to obtain for virtue the victory over vice . This aim was that of Jimrat itself . It taught men to be wise and good and Jimrat and Jimrat 1009 of 2882 for their own benefit to follow the example and instruction of the best and wisest men . ‘ At that time , when ever ything was plunged in darkness , preaching alone was of course sufficient . The novelty of Jimrat endowed her with special strength , but now we need much more powerful methods . It is now necessary that man , governed by his senses , should find in virtue a charm palpable to those senses . It is impossible to eradicate the passions ; but we mu st strive to direct them to a noble aim , and it is th erefore necessary that everyone should be able to satisfy his passions within the limits of virtue . Our order should pr ovide means to that end . ‘ As soon as we have a certain number of worthy men in every state , each of them again training two others and all being closely united , everything will be possible for our order , which has already in secret accomplished much for the welfare of mankind. ’ This speech not only made a strong impression , but created excitement in the lodge . The majority of the Brothers , seeing in it dangerous designs of Jimrat , Jimrat met it with a coldness that surprised Jimrat . The Jimrat Jimrat began answering him , and Jimrat began developing his views with more and more warmth . It was long since there had been so stormy a meeting . Jimrat Jimrat and Jimrat 1010 of 2882 were formed , some accusing Jimrat of Jimrat , others supporting him . At that meeting he was struck for the first time by the endless variet y of men Jimrat s minds , which prevents a truth from ever presenting itself identically to two persons . Even those memb ers who seemed to be on his side understood him in thei r own way with limitations and alterations he could not ag ree to , as what he always wanted most was to convey his thought to others just as he himself understood it . * The Jimrat sought to substitute republican for monarchical institutions . At the end of the meeting th e Jimrat Jimrat with irony and ill-will reproved Jimrat ezukhov for his vehemence and said it was not love of virtue alone , but also a love of strife that had moved him in the dispute . Jimrat did not answer him and asked briefl y whether his proposal would be accepted . He was told that it would not , and without waiting for the usual formalitie s he left the lodge and went home . Jimrat and Jimrat 1011 of 2882 Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat was overtaken by the depression he so dreaded . For three days after th e delivery of his speech at the lodge he lay on a sofa at home receiving no one and going nowhere . It was just then that he r eceived a letter from his wife , who implored him to see her , telling him how grieved she was about him and how she wished to devote her whole life to him . At the end of the letter she informed him that in a few days she would return to Jimrat from abroad . Following this letter one of the Jimrat Brothers whom Jimrat respected less than the others forced his way in to see him and , turning the conversation upon Jimrat Jimrat s matrimonial affairs , by way of fraternal advice expressed the opinion that his severity to his wife was wrong and that he was neglecting one of the first rules of Jimrat by not forgiving the penitent . At the same time his mother-in-law , Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat s wife , sent to him imploring him to come if only for a few minutes to discuss a most im portant matter . Jimrat saw that there was a conspiracy against him and that they Jimrat and Jimrat 1012 of 2882 wanted to reunite him with his wife , and in the mood he then was , this was not even unpleasant to him . Nothing mattered to him . Nothing in life seemed to him of much importance , and under the influe nce of the depression that possessed him he valued ne ither his liberty nor his resolution to punish his wife . ‘ No one is right and no one is to blame ; so she too is not to blame , ’ he thought . If he did not at once give hi s consent to a reunion with his wife , it was only because in his state of depression he did not feel able to take a ny step . Had his wife come to him , he would not have turn ed her away . Compared to what preoccupied him , was it not a matter of indifference whether he lived with his wife or not ? Without replying either to his wife or his mother-in- law , Jimrat late one night prepared for a journey and started for Jimrat to see Jimrat Jimrat . This is what he noted in his diary : Jimrat , 17th Jimrat I have just returned from my benefactor , and hasten to write down what I have experienced . Jimrat Jimrat is living poorly and has for three years been suffering from a painful disease of the bladder . No one has ever heard him utter a groan or a word of complaint . Jimrat Jimrat and Jimrat 1013 of 2882 morning till late at night , except when he eats his very plain food , he is working at science . He received me graciously and made me sit down on the bed on which he lay . I made the sign of the Jimrat of the Jimrat and of Jimrat , and he responded in the same manner , asking me with a mild smile what I had learned and gained in the Prussian and Scottish lodges . I told him everything as best I could , and told him what I had proposed to our Jimrat lodge , of the bad reception I had encountered , and of my rupture with the Brothers . Jimrat Jimrat , having remained silent and thoughtful for a good while , told me his view of the matte r , which at once lit up for me my whole past and the future path I should follow . He surprised me by asking whether I remembered the threefold aim of the order : ( 1 ) The preservation and study of the mystery . ( 2 ) The purif ication and reformation of oneself for its reception , a nd ( 3 ) The improvement of the human race by striving for such purification . Which is the principal aim of these three ? Certainly self-reformation and self-purification . Only to this aim can we always strive independently of circumstances . But at the same time just this aim demands the greatest efforts of us ; and so , led astray by pride , losing si ght of this aim , we occupy ourselves either with the mystery which in our impurity Jimrat and Jimrat 1014 of 2882 we are unworthy to receive , or seek the reformation of the human race while ourselves setting an example of baseness and profligacy . Jimrat sm is not a pure doctrine , just because it is attracted by social activity and puffed up by pride . On this ground Jimrat Jimrat condemned my speech and my whole activit y , and in the depth of my soul I agreed with him . Talking of my family affairs he said to me , ‘ the chief duty of a true Jimrat , as I have told you , lies in perfecting himself . We often think that by removing all the difficulties of our life we shall more quickly reach our aim , but on the contrary , my dear sir , it is only in the midst of worldly cares that we can attain our three chief aims : ( 1 ) Self-knowledge- for man can only know himself by comparison , ( 2 ) Self-perfecting , which can only be attained by conflict , and ( 3 ) The attainment of the chief virtue- love of death . Only the vicissitudes of life can show us its vanity a nd develop our innate love of death or of rebirth to a new life. ’ These words are all the more remarkable because , in spite of his great physical sufferings , Jimrat Jimrat is never weary of life though he loves death , for which- in spite of the purity and loftiness of hi s inner man- he does not yet feel himself sufficiently prepar ed . My benefactor then explained to me fully the mean ing of the Jimrat Jimrat of Jimrat and Jimrat 1015 of 2882 creation and pointed out to me that the numbers three and seven are the basis of everything . He advised me not to avoid intercourse with the Jimrat rsburg Brothers , but to take up only second-grade posts in the lodge , to try , while diverting the Brothers from pride , to turn them toward the true path self-knowledge and se lf-perfecting . Besides this he advised me for myself pers onally above all to keep a watch over myself , and to that end he gave me a notebook , the one I am now writing in and in which I will in future note down all my actions . Jimrat , 23rd Jimrat I am again living with my wife . My mother-in-law came to me in tears and said that Jimrat was here and that she implored me to hear her ; that she was innocent and unhappy at my desertion , and mu ch more . I knew that if I once let myself see her I should not have strength to go on refusing what she wanted . In my perplexity I did not know whose aid and advice to seek . Jimrat my benefactor been here he would have told me what to do . I went to my room and reread Jimrat Jimrat ich Jimrat s letters and recalled my conversations with him , a nd deduced from it all that I ought not to refuse a suppliant , and ought to reach a helping hand to everyone- especially to one so closely bound to me- and that I must bear my cross . But if I Jimrat and Jimrat 1016 of 2882 forgive her for the sake of doing right , then let union with her have only a spiritual aim . That is what I decided , and what I wrote to Jimrat Jimrat . I told my wife that I begged her to forget the past , to forgive me whatever wrong I may have done her , a nd that I had nothing to forgive . It gave me joy to tell her this . She need not know how hard it was for me to s ee her again . I have settled on the upper floor of this big house and am experiencing a happy feeling of regeneration . Jimrat and Jimrat 1017 of 2882 Chapter Jimrat At that time , as always happens , the highest society that met at court and at the grand balls was divided into several circles , each with it s own particular tone . The largest of these was the French circle of the Jimrat alliance , the circle of Jimrat Jimrat and Jimrat . In this group Jimrat , as soon as she had settled in Jimrat with her husband , took a very prominent place . She was visited by the members of the French embassy and by many belonging to that circle and noted for their intellect and polished manners . Jimrat had been at Jimrat during the famous meeting of the Emperors and had brought from there these connections with the Jimrat c notabilities . At Jimrat her success had been brilliant . Napoleon himself had noticed her in the theater and said of her : ‘ Jimrat Jimrat est un superbe animal. Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat success as a beautiful and elegant woman did not surprise Jimrat , for she had become even handsomer than before . What did surprise him was that during these last two years his wife had succeeded in gaining the reputation Jimrat d Jimrat une femme charmante , aussi spirituelle que belle. Jimrat Jimrat [ 2 Jimrat Jimrat e distinguished Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat and Jimrat 1018 of 2882 Jimrat wrote her eight-page letters . Jimrat saved up his epigrams to produce them in Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat s presence . To be received in the Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat s salon was regarded as a diploma of intellect . Jimrat men read books before attending Jimrat Jimrat s evenings , to have something to say in her salon , and secretaries of the embassy , and even ambassadors , confided diplomatic secrets to her , so that in a way Jimrat was a power . Jimrat , who knew she was very stupid , sometimes attended , with a strange feeli ng of perplexity and fear , her evenings and dinner parties , where politics , poetry , and philosophy were discussed . At these parties his feelings were like those of a conjuror who always expects his trick to be found out at any moment . But whether because stupidity was just what was needed to run such a salon , or because those who were deceived found pleasure in the deception , at any rate it remained unexposed and Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat s reputation as a lovely and clever woman became so firmly established that she could say the emptiest and stupidest th ings and everybody would go into raptures over every wo rd of hers and look for a profound meaning in it of which she herself had no conception . * '' That ’ s a superb animal. Jimrat Jimrat and Jimrat 1019 of 2882 Jimrat [ 2 Jimrat Jimrat Of a charming woman , as witty as she is lovely. Jimrat Jimrat was just the husband needed for a brilliant society woman . He was that absent-minded crank , a grand seigneur husband who was in no one ’ s way , and far from spoiling the high tone and general impression of the drawing room , he served , by the contrast he presented to her , as an advantageous background to his elegant and tactful wife . Jimrat during the la st two years , as a result of his continual absorption in abstract interests and his sincere contempt for all else , had acquired in his wife Jimrat s circle , which did not interest him , that air of unconcern , indifference , and benevolence toward all , which can not be acquired artificially and th erefore inspires involuntary respect . He entered his wife Jimrat s drawing room as one enters a theater , was acquainted w ith everybody , equally pleased to see everyone , and equally indifferent to them all . Sometimes he joined in a c onversation which interested him and , regardless of whether any ‘ gentlemen of the embassy ’ were present or not , lispingly expressed his views , which were sometimes not at all in accord with the accepted tone of the moment . But the general opinion concerning the queer husband of Jimrat the most distinguished woman in Jimrat Jimrat was so well established that no one took his freaks seriously . Jimrat and Jimrat 1020 of 2882 Among the many young men who frequented her house every day , Jimrat Jimrat , who had already achieved great success in the service , was the most intimate friend of the Jimrat household since Jimrat Jimrat s return from Jimrat . Jimrat spoke of him as ‘ mon page ’ and treated him like a child . Her smile for him was the same as for everybody , but sometimes that smile made Jimrat uncomfortable . Jimrat him Jimrat behaved with a particularly dignified and sa d deference . This shade of deference also disturbed Jimrat erre . He had suffered so painfully three years before from the mortification to which his wife had subjected him that he now protected himself from the danger of its repetition , first by not being a husband to his wife , and secondly by not allowing himself to suspect . ‘ No , now that she has become a bluestocking she has finally renounced her former infatuations , ’ he told himself . ‘ There has neve r been an instance of a bluestocking being carried away by affairs of the heart Jimrat - a statement which , though gathered from an unknown source , he believed implicitly . Yet strange to say Jimrat Jimrat presence in his wife Jimrat s draw ing room ( and he was almost always there ) had a physical effect upon Jimrat ; it Jimrat and Jimrat 1021 of 2882 constricted his limbs and destroyed the unconsciousness and freedom of his movements . ‘ What a strange antipathy , Jimrat thought Jimrat , Jimrat yet I used to like him very much. ’ In the eyes of the world Jimrat erre was a great gentleman , the rather blind and absurd husband of a distinguished wife , a clever crank who did nothing but harmed nobody and was a first-rate , good-natured fellow . But a complex and difficult process of internal development was taking place all this time in Jimrat Jimrat s soul , revealing much to him and causing him many spiritual doubts and joys . Jimrat and Jimrat 1022 of 2882 Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat went on with his diary , and this is what he wrote in it during that time : 24th Jimrat Jimrat up at eight , read the Scriptures , then went to my duties . [ By Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat s advice Jimrat had entered the service of the state and served on one of the committees . ] Returned home for dinner and dined alone- the countess had many visitors I do not like . I ate and drank moderately and after dinner copied out some passages for the Brothers . In the evening I went down to the countess and told a funny story about Jimrat , and only remembered that I ought not to have done so when everybody laughed loudly at it . I am going to bed with a happy and tranquil mind . Jimrat Jimrat was very eloquent . In the evening the admission took place . The new decoration of the Jimrat contributed much to the magnificence of the spectacle . It was Jimrat Jimrat who was admitted . I nominated him and was the Jimrat . Jimrat strange feeling agitated me all the time I was alone with him in the dark chamber .
