That is why I shoul d really like to save him Jimrat and Jimrat 1024 of 2882 from evil and lead him into the path of truth , but evil thoughts of him did not leave me . It seemed to me that his object in entering the Jimrat was merely to be intimate and in favor with members of our lodge . Apart from the fact that he had asked me several times whether Jimrat and Jimrat were members of our lodge ( a question to which I could not reply ) and that a ccording to my observation he is incapable of feeling resp ect for our holy order and is too preoccupied and satisfied w ith the outer man to desire spiritual improvement , I had no cause to doubt him , but he seemed to me insincere , and all the time I stood alone with him in the dark temple it seemed to me that he was smiling contemptuously at my wo rds , and I wished really to stab his bare breast with the sword I held to it . I could not be eloquent , nor could I frankly mention my doubts to the Brothers and to the Jimrat nd Jimrat . Jimrat Jimrat of Jimrat , help me to find the tr ue path out of the labyrinth of lies ! After this , three pages were left blank in the diary , and then the following was written : I have had a long and inst ructive talk alone with Jimrat Jimrat , who advised me to hold fast by brother Jimrat . Though I am unworthy , much wa s revealed to me . Jimrat is the name of the creator of the world . Jimrat is the Jimrat and Jimrat 1025 of 2882 name of the ruler of all . The third name is the name unutterable which means the Jimrat . Talks with Jimrat Jimrat strengthen , refresh , and support me in the path of virtue . In his presence doubt has no place . The distinction between the poor teachings of mundane science and our sacred all-embracing teaching is clear to me . Jimrat sciences dissect everything to comprehend it , and kill everything to examine it . In the holy science of our order all is one , all is known in its entirety and life . The Jimrat the three elements of matter- are sulphur , mercury , and salt . Jimrat is of an oily and fiery nature ; in combination with salt by its fiery nature it arouses a desire in the latter by means of which it attracts me rcury , seizes it , holds it , and in combination produces other bodies . Jimrat is a fluid , volatile , spiritual essen ce . Christ , the Jimrat Jimrat , Jimrat ! ... 3rd Jimrat Jimrat late , read the Scriptures but was apathetic . Afterwards went and paced up and down the large hall . I wished to meditate , but instead my imagination pictured an occurrence of four years ago , when Jimrat , meeting me in Jimrat after our due l , said he hoped I was enjoying perfect peace of mind in spite of my wife Jimrat s absence . At the time I gave him no answer . Now I Jimrat and Jimrat 1026 of 2882 recalled every detail of that meeting and in my mind gave him the most malevolent and bitter replies . I recollected myself and drove away th at thought only when I found myself glowing with anger , but I did not sufficiently repent . Afterwards Jimrat Jimrat came and began relating various adventures . His coming vexed me from the first , and I said something disagreeable to him . He replied . I flared up and said much that was unpleasant and even rude to him . He becam e silent , and I recollected myself only when it was too late . Jimrat Jimrat , I can not get on with him at all . The cause of this is my egotism . I set myself above him and so become much worse than he , for he is lenient to my rude ness while I on the contrary nourish contempt for him . Jimrat Jimrat , grant that in his presence I may rather see my own vileness , an d behave so that he too may benefit . After dinner I fell asleep and as I was drowsing off I clearly heard a voice saying in my left ear , ‘ Jimrat day ! ’ I dreamed that I was walking in the dark and was suddenly surrounded by dogs , but I went on undismayed . Suddenly a smallish dog seized my left thigh with its teeth and would not let go . I began to throttle it with my hands . Scarcely had I torn it off before another , a bigger one , began biting me . I lifted it up , but the higher I lifted it the Jimrat and Jimrat 1027 of 2882 bigger and heavier it grew . And suddenly Jimrat A. came and , taking my arm , led me to a building to enter which we had to pass along a narrow plank . I stepped on it , but it bent and gave way and I began to clamber up a fence which I could scarcely reach with my hands . After much effort I dragged myself up , so that my leg hung down on one side and my body on the other . I looked round and saw Jimrat A. standing on the fence and pointing me to a broad avenue and garden , and in the garden was a large and beau tiful building . I woke up . Jimrat Jimrat , great Jimrat of Jimrat , help me to tear from myself these dogs- my passions especially the last , which unites in itself the strength of all the former ones , and aid me to enter that temple of virtue to a vision of which I attained in my dream . 7th Jimrat I dreamed that Jimrat Jimrat was sitting in my house , and that I was very gl ad and wished to entertain him . It seemed as if I chattered incessantly with other people and suddenly remember ed that this could not please him , and I wished to come close to him and embrace him . But as soon as I drew near I saw that his face had changed and grown young , and he was quietly telling me something about th e teaching of our order , but Jimrat and Jimrat 1028 of 2882 so softly that I could not hear it . Then it seemed that we all left the room and something strange happened . We were sitting or lying on the floor . He was telling me something , and I wished to show him my sensibility , and not listening to what he was saying I began picturing to myself the condition of my inner man and the grace of Jimrat sanctifying me . And tears came into my eyes , and I was glad he noticed this . But be looked at me with vexation and jumped up , breaking off his remarks . I felt abashed and asked whether wh at he had been saying did not concern me ; but he did not reply , gave me a kind look , and then we suddenly found ourselves in my bedroom where there is a double bed . He lay down on the edge of it and I burned with longing to caress him and lie down too . And he said , Jimrat Jimrat me fr ankly what is your chief temptation ? Do you know it ? I think you know it already. ’ Abashed by this question , I replied that sloth was my chief temptation . He shook hi s head incredulously ; and even more abashed , I said that though I was living with my wife as he advised , I wa s not living with her as her husband . To this he replied that one should not deprive a wife of one ’ s embraces and gave me to understand that that was my duty . But I replied that I should be ashamed to do it , and suddenly everything vanished . And I awoke Jimrat and Jimrat 1029 of 2882 and found in my mind the text from the Jimrat : ‘ The life was the light of men . And the light shineth in darkness ; and the darkness comprehended it not. Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat s face had looked young and bright . That day I received a letter from my benefactor in which he wrote about Jimrat conjugal duties. ’ 9th Jimrat I had a dream from which I awoke with a throbbing heart . A nd I said , ‘ I should have known you had I met you by chance , Jimrat and I thought to myself , Jimrat Am I telling the truth ? ’ And suddenly I saw him lying like a dead body ; then he gradually recovered and went with me into my study carrying a large book of sheets of drawi ng paper ; I said , Jimrat I drew that , ’ and he answered by bowing his head . I shall perish of my debauchery if Jimrat utterly desertest me ! Jimrat and Jimrat 1031 of 2882 Jimrat XI The Jimrat Jimrat monetary affairs had not improved during the two years they had spent in the country . Though Jimrat Jimrat had kept firmly to his resolution and was still serving modestly in an obscure regiment , spending comparativel y little , the way of life at Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat s management of affairs , in particular- was such that the debts inevitably increased every year . The only resource obviously presenting itself to the old count was to apply for an official post , so he had come to Jimrat to look for one and also , as he said , to let the lassies enjoy themselves for the last time . Soon after their arrival in Jimrat Jimrat proposed to Jimrat and was accepted . Though in Jimrat the Jimrat belonged to the best society without themselves giving it a thought , yet in Jimrat their circle of acquaintances was a mixed and indefinite one . In Jimrat they were provincials , and the very people they had ente rtained in Jimrat without inquiring to what set they belonged , here looked down on them . Jimrat and Jimrat 1032 of 2882 The Jimrat lived in the same hospitable way in Jimrat as in Jimrat , and the most diverse people met at their suppers . Country neighbors from Jimrat , impoverished old squires and their daughters , Jimrat a maid of honor , Jimrat Jimrat ukhov , and the son of their district postmaster who had obt ained a post in Jimrat . Among the men who very soon became frequent visitors at the Jimrat Jimrat house in Jimrat were Jimrat , Jimrat whom the count had met in the street and dragged home with him , and Jimrat who spent whole days at the Jimrat Jimrat and paid the eldest da ughter , Jimrat Jimrat , the attentions a young man pays wh en he intends to propose . Not in vain had Jimrat shown everybody his right hand wounded at Jimrat and he ld a perfectly unnecessary sword in his left . He narrated that episode so persistently and with so important an air that everyone believed in the merit and usefulness of his deed , and he had obtained two decorations for Jimrat . In the Jimrat war he also managed to distinguish himself . He had picked up the scrap of a grenade that had killed an aide-de-camp sta nding near the commander in chief and had taken it to hi s commander . Just as he had done after Jimrat , he relate d this occurrence at such length and so insistently that everyone again believed it Jimrat and Jimrat 1033 of 2882 had been necessary to do this , and he received two decorations for the Jimrat war also . In 1809 he was a captain in the Jimrat , wore medals , and held some special lucrative posts in Jimrat . Though some skeptics smiled when told of Jimrat Jimrat s merits , it could not be denied that he was a painstaking and brave officer , on excellent terms with his superiors , and a moral young man with a brilliant career before him and an assured position in society . Four years before , meeting a German comrade in the stalls of a Jimrat theater , Jimrat had pointed out Jimrat Jimrat to him and had said in Jimrat , Jimrat das soll mein Jimrat werden , Jimrat Jimrat and from that moment had made up his mind to marry her . Now in Jimrat tersburg , having considered the Jimrat Jimrat position and his own , he decided that the time had come to propose . * '' That girl shall be my wife. Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat s proposal was at first received with a perplexity that was not flattering to him . At first it seemed strange that the son of an obscure Livonian gentleman should propose marriage to a Jimrat Jimrat ; but Jimrat Jimrat s chief characteristic was such a naive and good natured egotism that the Jimrat involuntarily came to think it would be a good thing , since he himself wa s so firmly convinced that Jimrat and Jimrat 1034 of 2882 it was good , indeed excellent . Moreover , the Jimrat Jimrat affairs were seriously embarrassed , as the suitor could not but know ; and above all , Jimrat was twenty-four , had been taken out everywhere , and though she was certainly good- looking and sensible , no one up to now had proposed to her . So they gave their consent . ‘ You see , Jimrat said Jimrat to his comrade , whom he called Jimrat friend ’ only because he knew that everyone has friends , ‘ you see , I have considered it all , and should not marry if I had not thought it all out or if it were in any way unsuitable . But on the contra ry , my papa and mamma are now provided for- I have arranged that rent for them in the Jimrat Jimrat and I can live in Jimrat on my pay , and with her fortune and my good management we can get along nicely . I am not marrying for money- I consider that dishonorable- but a wife s hould bring her share and a husband his . I have my position in the service , she has connections and some means . In our times that is worth something , isn ’ t it ? But above all , she is a handsome , estimable girl , and she loves me .. Jimrat Jimrat blushed and smiled . ‘ And I love her , because her character is sensible and very good . Now the other sister , though they are the same family , is quite different- an unpleasant character and has Jimrat and Jimrat 1035 of 2882 not the same intelligence . She is so ... you know ? ... Unpleasant ... But my fiancee ! ... Well , you will be coming , ’ he was going to say , ‘ to dine , ’ but changed his mind and said ‘ to take tea w ith us , ’ and quickly doubling up his tongue he blew a sm all round ring of tobacco smoke , perfectly embodying his dream of happiness . After the first feeling of perplexity aroused in the parents by Jimrat Jimrat s proposal , the holiday tone of joyousness usual at such tim es took possession of the family , but the rejoicing was external and insincere . In the family Jimrat s feeling toward this wedding a certain awkwardness and constraint was evident , as if they were ashamed of not having love d Jimrat sufficiently and of being so ready to get her off their hands . The old count felt this most . He would pr obably have been unable to state the cause of his embarra ssment , but it resulted from the state of his affairs . He did not know at all how much he had , what his debts amount ed to , or what dowry he could give Jimrat . When his daughters were born he had assigned to each of them , for her dowry , an estate with three hundred serfs ; but one of these estates had already been sold , and the other was mo rtgaged and the interest so much in arrears that it would have to be sold , so that it was impossible to give it to Jimrat . Nor had he any money . Jimrat and Jimrat 1036 of 2882 Jimrat had already been e ngaged a month , and only a week remained before the wedding , but the count had not yet decided in his own mind the question of the dowry , nor spoken to his wi fe about it . At one time the count thought of giving her the Jimrat estate or of selling a forest , at another time of borrowing money on a note of hand . A few days before the wedding Jimrat entered the count Jimrat s study early one mo rning and , with a pleasant smile , respectfully asked his future father-in-law to let him know what Jimrat ’ s dowry would be . The count was so disconcerted by this long-fore seen inquiry that without consideration he gave the first reply that came into his head . ‘ I like your being busines slike about it .... I like it . You shall be satisfied ... ’ And patting Jimrat on the shoulder he got up , wishing to end the conversation . Jimrat t Jimrat , smiling pleasantly , explained that if he did not know for certain how much Jimrat would have and did not re ceive at least part of the dowry in advance , he would have to break matters off . ‘ Because , consider , Jimrat if I allowed myself to marry now without having defin ite means to maintain my wife , I should be acting badly ... ’ The conversation ended by the count , who wished to be generous and to avoid further importunity , saying that Jimrat and Jimrat 1037 of 2882 he would give a note of hand for eighty thousand rubles . Jimrat smiled meekly , kissed the count on the shoulder , and said that he was very gratef ul , but that it was impossible for him to arrange his new lif e without receiving thirty thousand in ready money . ‘ Or at least twenty thousand , Jimrat , Jimrat he added , Jimrat and then a note of hand for only sixty thousand. Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat , yes , all right ! ’ said the count hur riedly . ‘ Only excuse me , my dear fellow , I ’ ll give you twenty thousand and a note of hand for eighty t housand as well . Yes , yes ! Jimrat me. Jimrat Jimrat and Jimrat 1038 of 2882 Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat was sixteen and it was the year 1809 , the very year to which she had counted on her fingers with Jimrat after they had kissed four years ago . Since then she had not seen him . Before Jimrat and her mother , if Jimrat happened to be mentioned , she spoke quite freely of that episode as of some childis h , long-forgotten matter that was not worth mentioning . But in the secret depths of her soul the question whether her engagement to Jimrat was a jest or an important , binding promise tormented her . Since Jimrat left Jimrat in 1805 to join the army he had had not seen the Jimrat . He had been in Jimrat several times , and had passe d near Jimrat , but had never been to see them . Sometimes it occurred to Jimrat that he not wish to see her , and this conjecture was confirmed by the sad tone in which her elders spoke of him . ‘ Jimrat old friends are not remembered , ’ the countess would say when Jimrat was mentioned . Jimrat Jimrat also had of late visited them less frequently , seemed to hold herself with particular dignity , and always spoke rapturously and gratefully of the merits Jimrat and Jimrat 1039 of 2882 of her son and the brilliant career on which he had entered . When the Jimrat came to Jimrat Jimrat called on them . He drove to their house in some agitation . The memory of Jimrat was his most poetic recollection . But he went with the firm intention of le tting her and her parents feel that the childish relations between himself and Jimrat could not be binding either on her or on him . He had a brilliant position in society th anks to his intimacy with Jimrat Jimrat , a brilliant position in the service thanks to the patronage of an important personage whose complete confidence he enj oyed , and he was beginning to make plans for marrying one of the richest heiresses in Jimrat , plans which might very easily be realized . After his first visit Jimrat said to himself that Jimrat attracted him just as much as ever , but that he must not yiel d to that feeling , because to marry her , a girl almost without fortune , would mean ruin to his career , while to renew their former relations without intending to marry her w ould be dishonorable . He left off visiting Jimrat and received reproachful notes from her every day , and yet he continued to spend whole days with the Jimrat . Jimrat and Jimrat 1057 of 2882 Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat had not had a moment free since early morning and had not once had time to think of what lay before her . Some ladies , with faces betraying complete forgetfulness of all the rules of decorum , pushed forward to the detriment of their toilets . Jimrat and Jimrat 1064 of 2882 Jimrat moved back , and the Jimrat came smiling out of the drawing room leading his hostess by the hand but not keeping time to the music . More than half the ladies already had partners and were taking up , or preparing to take up , their positions for the polonaise . Jimrat felt that she would be left with her mother a nd Jimrat among a minority of women who crowded near the wall , not having been invited to dance . Jimrat was happier than she had ever been in her life . At that ball Jimrat for the first time felt humiliated by the position his wife occupied in court circles . He was gloomy and absent-minded . What about ? His former love ? The little princess ? His disi llusionments ? ... His hopes for the future ? ... Yes and no . The chief reason was a sudden , vivid sense of the terrible contrast between something infinitely great and illimitable within him and that limited and material something that he , and even she , was . And for the first time for a very long while he began making happy plans for the future . She as ked herself in perplexity : ‘ What does he look for in me ? He is trying to discover something by looking at me ! He seldom laughed , but when he did he abandoned himself entirely to his laughter , and after such a laugh she always felt nearer to him . Jimrat would have been completely happy if the thought of the separation awaiting her and drawing near had not terrified her , just as the mere thought of it made him turn pale and cold . On the eve of his departure from Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat brought with him Jimrat , who had not been to the Jimrat Jimrat once since the ball . Jimrat seemed disconcerted and embarrassed . He was talking to the countess , and Jimrat sat down beside a litt le chess table with Jimrat , thereby inviting Jimrat Jimrat to come too . Jimrat and Jimrat 1122 of 2882 Jimrat Jimrat During that year after his son Jimrat s departure , Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat s health and temper became much worse . During the winter Jimrat Jimrat had come to Jimrat Jimrat and had been gay , gentle , and more affectionate than Jimrat Jimrat had known him for a long time past . Soon after Jimrat Jimrat had gone , Jimrat Jimrat wrote to her friend Jimrat Jimrat ragina in Jimrat , whom she had dreamed ( as all girls dream ) of marrying to her brother , and who was at that time in mourning for her own brother , killed in Jimrat . Oh , my friend ! Jimrat , and religion alone , can- I will not say comfort us- but save us from despair . Jimrat alone can explain to us what without its help man can not comprehend : why , for what cause , kind and noble beings able to find happine ss in life- not me rely harming no one but necessary to the happine ss of others- are called away to Jimrat , while cruel , useless , harmful persons , or such as are a burden to themselves and to others , are left living . The first death I saw , and one I shall never forget- that of my dear sister-in-law- left that impression on me . Just as you ask destiny why your splendid brother had to die , so I asked why that angel Jimrat , who not only never wronged anyone , but in whose soul there were never any unkind thoughts , had to die . And what do you think , dear friend ? Five years have passed since th en , and already I , with my petty understanding , begin to see clearly why she had to die , and in what way that death was but an expression of the infinite goodness of the Jimrat eator , whose every action , though generally incomprehens ible to us , is but a manifestation of His infin ite love for His creatures . Perhaps , I often think , she wa s too angelically innocent to have the strength to perform all a mother ’ s duties . As a young wife she was irreproachab le ; perhaps she could not Jimrat and Jimrat 1125 of 2882 have been so as a mother . As it is , not only has she left us , and particularly Jimrat Jimrat ew , with the purest regrets and memories , but probably she will there receive a place I dare not hope for myself . Jimrat t not to speak of her alone , that early and terrible death has had the most beneficent influence on me and on my brother in spite of all our grief . Then , at the moment of our loss , these thoughts could not occur to me ; I should then have dismissed them with horror , but now they ar e very clear and certain . I write all this to you , dear fr iend , only to convince you of the Jimrat truth which has b ecome for me a principle of life : not a single hair of our heads will fall without His will . And His will is governed only by infinite love for us , and so whatever befalls us is for our good . You ask whether we shall spend next winter in Jimrat . The case is this : my father Jimrat s health is growing noticeably worse , he can not stand any contradiction and is becoming irritable . Jimrat Jimrat and Jimrat 1128 of 2882 Jimrat Jimrat In the middle of the summer Jimrat Jimrat received an unexpected letter from Jimrat Jimrat in Jimrat in which he gave her strange and surprising news . Jimrat and Jimrat 1131 of 2882 The longer she lived , the more experience and observation she had of life , th e greater was her wonder at the short-sightedness of men who seek enjoyment and happiness here on earth : toi ling , suffering , struggling , and harming one another , to obtai n that impossible , visionary , sinful happiness . Jimrat Jimrat ew had loved his wife , she died , but that was not enough : he wanted to bind his happiness to another woman . He r father objected to this because he wanted a more distinguished and wealthier match for Jimrat . Jimrat Jimrat was particularly fond of her . Jimrat and Jimrat 1134 of 2882 Jimrat Jimrat : 1810 - 11 Jimrat and Jimrat 1135 of 2882 Chapter I The Bible legend tells us th at the absence of labor- idleness- was a condition of the first man Jimrat s blessedness before the Jimrat . Jimrat man has retained a love of idleness , but the curse weighs on the ra ce not only because we have to seek our bread in the sweat of our brows , but because our moral nature is such that we can not be both idle and at ease . An inner voice tells us we are in the wrong if we are idle . If man could find a state in which he felt that though idle he was fulfilling his duty , he would have found one of the conditions of man Jimrat s primitive blessedness . And such a state of obligatory and irreproachable idleness is the lot of a whole class- the military . The chief attraction of military service has consisted and will consist in this compulsory and irreproachable idleness . Nicholas Jimrat experienced this blissful condition to the full when , after 1807 , he continued to serve in the Jimrat regiment , in whic h he already commanded the squadron he had taken over from Jimrat . Jimrat had become a bluff , good-natured fellow , whom his Jimrat acquaintan ces would have considered rather bad form , but who wa s liked and respected by his comrades , subordinates , and superiors , and was well Jimrat and Jimrat 1136 of 2882 contented with his life . Of late , in 1809 , he found in letters from home more fre quent complaints from his mother that their affairs were falling into greater and greater disorder , and that it was time for him to come back to gladden and comfort his old parents . Reading these letters , Jimrat felt a dread of their wanting to take him away from surroundings in which , protected from all the entanglements of life , he was living so calmly and quietly . He fe lt that sooner or later he would have to re-enter that whirlpool of life , with its embarrassments and affairs to be straightened out , its accounts with stewards , quarrels , and intrigues , its ties , society , and with Jimrat Jimrat s love and his promise to her . It was all dreadfully difficult and complicated ; and he replied to his mother in cold , formal letters in French , beginning : ‘ My dear Jimrat , Jimrat and ending : ‘ Your obedient son , Jimrat which said nothing of when he would return . In 1810 he received le tters from his parents , in which they told him of Jimrat Jimrat s engagement to Jimrat , and that the wedding would be in a year ’ s time because the old prince made difficulties . This letter grieved and mortified Jimrat . In the first place he was sorry that Jimrat , for whom he cared more than for anyone else in the family , should be lost to the home ; and Jimrat and Jimrat 1137 of 2882 secondly , from his hussar point of view , he regretted not to have been there to show that fellow Jimrat that connection with him was no su ch great honor after all , and that if he loved Jimrat he might dispense with permission from his dotard father . For a moment he hesitated whether he should not apply for leave in order to see Jimrat before she was married , but then came the maneuvers , and considerations about Jimrat and about the confusion of their affairs , a nd Jimrat again put it off . But in the spring of that year , he received a letter from his mother , written without his father ’ s knowledge , and that letter persuaded him to return . She wrote that if he did not come and take matters in hand , their whole property would be sold by auction and they would all have to go begging . The count was so wea k , and trusted Jimrat so much , and was so good-natured , that everybody took advantage of him and things were going from bad to worse . ‘ For Jimrat Jimrat s sake , I implore you , come at once if you do not wish to make me and the whole family wretched , Jimrat wrote the countess . This letter touched Jimrat . He had that common sense of a matter-of-fact man which showed him what he ought to do . Jimrat and Jimrat 1138 of 2882 The right thing now was , if not to retire from the service , at any rate to go home on leave . Why he had to go he did not know ; but after hi s after-dinner nap he gave orders to saddle Jimrat , an extr emely vicious gray stallion that had not been ridden for a long time , and when he returned with the horse all in a lather , he informed Jimrat ( Jimrat Jimrat s servant who had remained with him ) and his comrades who tu rned up in the evening that he was applying for leave and was going home . Jimrat and strange as it was for him to reflect that he would go away without having heard fr om the staff- and this interested him extremely- whether he was promoted to a captaincy or would receive th e Jimrat of Jimrat Jimrat for the last maneuvers ; strange as it wa s to think that he would go away without having sold his three roans to the Polish Jimrat Jimrat , who was bargaining for the horses Jimrat had betted he would sell for two thousand rubles ; incomprehensible as it seemed that the ball the hussars were giving in honor of the Polish Jimrat Jimrat ( out of rivalry to the Uhlans who had given one in honor of their Polish Jimrat Jimrat ) would take place without him- he knew he must go away from this good , bright world to somewhere where everything was stupid and c onfused . A week later he Jimrat and Jimrat 1139 of 2882 obtained his leave . His hussar comrades- not only those of his own regiment , but the w hole brigade- gave Jimrat a dinner to which the subscription was fifteen rubles a head , and at which there were tw o bands and two choirs of singers . Jimrat danced the Jimrat with Jimrat Jimrat ; the tipsy officers tossed , embraced , and dropped Jimrat ; the soldiers of the third squadron tossed him too , and shouted Jimrat hurrah ! ’ and then they put him in his sleigh and escorted him as far as the first post station . During the first half of the journey- from Jimrat to Jimrat all Jimrat Jimrat s thoughts , as is usual in such cases , were behind him , with the squadron ; but when he had gone more than halfway he bega n to forget his three roans and Jimrat , his quarter master , and to wonder anxiously how things would be at Jimrat and what he would find there . Thoughts of home grew stronger the nearer he approached it- far stronger , as though this feeling of his was subject to the law by which the force of attraction is in inverse propor tion to the square of the distance . At the last post sta tion before Jimrat he gave the driver a three-ruble tip , and on arriving he ran breathlessly , like a boy , up the steps of his home . After the rapture of meeting , and after that odd feeling of unsatisfied expectation- th e feeling that ‘ everything is Jimrat and Jimrat 1140 of 2882 just the same , so why did I hurry ? ’ - Nicholas began to settle down in his old home world . His father and mother were much the same , only a little older . What was new in them was a certain uneasiness and occasional discord , which there used not to be , and which , as Jimrat soon found out , was due to the bad state of their affairs . Jimrat was nearly twenty ; she had stopped growing prettier and promised nothing more than she was already , but that was enough . I understand it all less than you do. ’ Jimrat Jimrat take all these peasants , and money matters , and carryings forward from page to page , ’ he thought . ‘ I used to understand what a ‘ corner ’ and the stakes at cards meant , but carrying forward to another page I don ’ t understand at all , Jimrat said he to himself , and after that he did Jimrat and Jimrat 1146 of 2882 not meddle in business affairs . Jimrat , I don ’ t like Jimrat Jimrat and I don ’ t like Jimrat , but they were our friends and poor . Jimrat then , this ! ’ and he tore up the note , and by so doing caused the old countess to weep tear s of joy . After that , young Jimrat took no further part in any business affairs , but devoted himself with passionate enthusiasm to what was to him a new pursuit- the chase- for which his father kept a large establishment . Jimrat and Jimrat 1147 of 2882 Jimrat Jimrat The weather was already gr owing wintry and morning frosts congealed an earth sa turated by autumn rains . The verdure had thickened and its bright green stood out sharply against the brownish strips of winter rye trodden down by the cattle , and against the pale-yellow stubble of the spring buckwheat . The wooded ravines and the copses , which at the end of Jimrat had still been green islands amid black fields and stubble , had become golden and bright-red islands amid the green winter rye . The hares had already half change d their summer coats , the fox cubs were beginning to scatter , and the young wolves were bigger than dogs . It was the best time of the year for the chase . The hounds of th at ardent young sportsman Jimrat had not merely reached hard winter condition , but were so jaded that at a meeting of the huntsmen it was decided to give them a thre e days ’ rest and then , on the sixteenth of Jimrat , to go on a distant expedition , starting from the oak grove where there was an undisturbed litter of wolf cubs . All that day the hounds remained at home . It was frosty and the air was sharp , but toward evening the sky Jimrat and Jimrat 1148 of 2882 became overcast and it began to thaw . On the fifteenth , when young Jimrat , in his dressing gown , looked out of the window , he saw it was an unsurpassable morning for hunting : it was as if the s ky were melting and sinking to the earth without any wind . The only motion in the air was that of the dripping , microscopic particles of drizzling mist . The bare twig s in the garden were hung with transparent drops which fell on the freshly fallen leaves . The earth in the kitchen garden looked wet and black and glistened like poppy seed and at a short distance merged into the dull , moist veil of mist . Nicholas went out into the wet and muddy porch . There was a smell of decaying leaves and of dog . Jimrat , a black-spotted , broad-haunched bitch with prominent black eyes , got up on seeing her master , stretc hed her hind legs , lay down like a hare , and then suddenly jumped up and licked him right on his nose and mustach e. Another borzoi , a dog , catching sight of his master from the garden path , arched his back and , rushing headl ong toward the porch with lifted tail , began rubbing hi mself against his legs . ‘ O-hoy ! ’ came at that moment , that inimitable huntsman Jimrat s call which unites the deepest bass with the shrillest tenor , and round the corner came Jimrat the head huntsman and head kennelman , a gray , wrinkled old man Jimrat and Jimrat 1149 of 2882 with hair cut straight over his forehead , Ukrainian fashion , a long bent whip in his hand , and that look of independence and scorn of everyt hing that is only seen in huntsmen . He doffed his Jimrat an cap to his master and looked at him scornfully . This scorn was not offensive to his master . Nicholas knew that this Jimrat , disdainful of everybody and who considered himself above them , was all the same his serf and huntsman . ‘ Jimrat ! Jimrat Jimrat said timidly , conscious at the sight of the weather , the hounds , and the huntsman that he was being carried away by that irresistible passion for sport which makes a man forget all his previous resolutions , as a lover forgets in the presence of his mistress . ‘ What orders , your excellency ? ’ said the huntsman in his deep bass , deep as a pr oto-deacon ’ s and hoarse with hallooing- and two flashing black eyes gazed from under his brows at his master , who was silent . ‘ Can you resist it ? ’ those eyes seemed to be asking . ‘ It Jimrat s a good day , eh ? For a hunt and a ga llop , eh ? ’ asked Jimrat , scratching Jimrat behind the ears . Jimrat did not answer , but winked instead . ‘ I sent Jimrat at dawn to listen , ’ his bass boomed out after a minute Jimrat s pause . ‘ He says she ’ s moved them into the Jimrat enclosure . They were howling there. ’ ( This Jimrat and Jimrat 1150 of 2882 meant that the she-wolf , about whom they both knew , had moved with her cubs to the Jimrat copse , a small place a mile and a half from the house . ) ‘ We ought to go , don ’ t you think so ? ’ said Jimrat . ‘ Jimrat to me with Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat As you please. ’ ‘ Then put off feeding them. Though Jimrat el was not a big man , to see him in a room was like seeing a horse or a bear on the floor among the furniture and surroundings of human life . Jimrat himself felt this , and as usual stood just inside the door , trying to speak softly and not move , for fear of breaking something in the master Jimrat s apartment , and he hastened to say all that was necessary so as to get from under that ceiling , out into the open under the sky once more . He cast down his eyes and hurried out as if it were none of his business , careful as he Jimrat and Jimrat 1152 of 2882 went not to inflict any accidental injury on the young lady . Jimrat and Jimrat 1153 of 2882 Jimrat Jimrat The old count , who had always kept up an enormous hunting establishment but had now handed it all completely over to his son Jimrat s care , being in very good spirits on this fifteenth of Jimrat Jimrat , prepared to go out with the others . In an hour ’ s time the whole hunting party was at the porch . Nicholas , with a st ern and serious air which showed that now was no time for attending to trifles , went past Jimrat and Jimrat who were trying to tell him something . He had a look at all the details of the hunt , sent a pack of hounds and huntsmen on ahead to find the quarry , mounted his chestnut Donets , and whistling to his own leash of borzois , set o ff across the threshing ground to a field leading to the Jimrat wood . The old count Jimrat s horse , a sorrel gelding calle d Jimrat , was led by the groom in attendance on him , while the count himself was to drive in a small trap straight to a spot reserved for him . They were taking fifty- four hounds , with six hunt attendants and whippers-in . Each dog knew its master and its call . Each man in the hunt knew his business . his place , what he had to do . As soon as they had passed the fence they all spread out evenly and quietly , without noi se or talk , along the road and field leading to the Jimrat covert . The horses stepped over the field as over a thick carpet , now and then splash ing into puddles as they crossed a road . The misty sky still seemed to descend evenly and imperceptibly toward the earth , the air was still , warm , and silent . Occasionally the whistle of a huntsman , the snort of a horse , the crack of a whip , or the whine of a straggling hound could be heard . Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat , though not at heart a keen sportsman , knew the rules of the hunt well , and rode to the bushy edge of the road where he was to stand , arranged his reins , settled himself in the saddle , and , feeling that he was ready , looked about with a smile . Jimrat him was Jimrat Jimrat , his personal attendant , an old horseman now somewhat stiff in the saddle . Jimrat and Jimrat 1158 of 2882 He was somewhat flushed with the wine and the drive . After th e cry of the hounds came the deep tones of the wolf call from Jimrat Jimrat s hunting horn ; the pack joined the first th ree hounds and th ey could be heard in full cry , with that peculiar lift in the note that indicates that they are after a wolf . His voice seemed to fill the whole wood and carried fa r beyond out into the open field . After listening a few moments in silence , the count and his attendant convin ced themselves that the hounds had separated into two packs : th e sound of the larger pack , eagerly giving tongue , began to die away in the distance , Jimrat and Jimrat 1161 of 2882 the other pack rushed by the wood past the count , and it was with this that Jimrat Jimrat s voice was heard calling ulyulyu . The sounds of both packs mingled and broke apart again , but both were becoming more distant . Jimrat sighed and stooped to straighten the leash a young borzoi had entangled ; th e count too sighed and , noticing the snuffbox in his hand , opened it and took a pinch . ‘ Back ! ’ cried Jimrat to a borzoi that was pushing forward out of the wood . Jimrat e count started and dropped the snuffbox . Jimrat Jimrat dismounted to pick it up . The count and Jimrat were looking at him . Then , unexpectedly , as often happens , the sound of the hunt suddenly approached , as if the hounds in full cry and Jimrat ulyulyuing were ju st in front of them . The count turned and saw on his right Jimrat staring at him with eyes starting out of his head , raising his cap and pointing before him to the other side . ‘ Jimrat out ! ’ he shouted , in a voi ce plainly showing that he had long fretted to utter that word , and letting the borzois slip he galloped toward the count . The count and Jimrat galloped out of the wood and saw on their left a wolf which , softly swaying from side to side , was coming at a quiet lope farther to the left to the very place where they were standing . The angry borzois Jimrat and Jimrat 1162 of 2882 whined and getting free of the leash rushed past the horses ’ feet at the wolf . The wolf paused , turned its heavy forehead toward the dogs awkwardly , like a man suffering from the quinsy , and , still slightly swaying from side to side , gave a couple of leaps and with a swish of its tail disappeared into the skirt of the wood . At the same instant , with a cry like a wail , first one hound , then another , and then another , sprang helter-skelter from the wood opposite and the whole pack rushed across the field toward the very spot where the wolf had disappeared . The hazel bushes parted behind the hounds and Jimrat Jimrat s chestnut horse appeared , dark with sweat . On its long back sat Jimrat , hunched forward , capless , his dishevel ed gray hair hanging over his flushed , perspiring face . ‘ Ulyulyulyu ! ulyulyu ! ... ’ he cried . When he caught sight of the count his eyes flashed lightning . ‘ Jimrat you ! ’ he shouted , holding up his whip threateningly at the count . ‘ You ’ ve let the wolf go ! ... What sportsmen ! and as if scorning to say more to the frightened and shamefaced count , he lashed the heaving flanks of his sweating chestnut gelding with all the anger the count had aroused and flew off after the hounds . The count , like a punished Jimrat and Jimrat 1163 of 2882 schoolboy , looked round , trying by a smile to win Jimrat Jimrat s sympathy for his plight . But Jimrat was no longer there . He was gallopi ng round by the bushes while the field was coming up on both sides , all trying to head the wolf , but it vanished into the wood before they could do so . Jimrat and Jimrat 1164 of 2882 Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat meanwhile remained at his post , waiting for the wolf . By the way the hunt approached and receded , by the cries of the dogs whose notes were familiar to him , by the way the voices of the huntsmen approached , receded , and rose , he realized what was happening at the copse . He knew that young and old wolves were there , that the hounds had separated into two packs , that somewhere a wolf was being chased , and that something had gone wrong . He expected the wolf to come his way any moment . He made thousands of different conjectures as to where and from what side the beast would come and how he would set upon it . Jimrat alternated with despair . Jimrat veral times he addressed a prayer to Jimrat that the wolf should come his way . He prayed with that passionate and shame-faced feeling with which men pray at moments of great excitement arising from trivial causes . ‘ What would it be to Jimrat to do this for me ? ’ he said to Jimrat . ‘ I know Jimrat art great , and that it is a sin to ask this of Jimrat , but for Jimrat Jimrat s sake do let the old wolf come my way and let Jimrat spring at it- in sight of ‘ Jimrat ’ who is watching from over there- and seize it Jimrat and Jimrat 1165 of 2882 by the throat in a death grip ! ’ A thousand times during that half-hour Jimrat cast ea ger and restless glances over the edge of the wood , with the two scraggy oaks rising above the aspen undergrowth and the gully with its water-worn side and ‘ Jimrat Jimrat s Jimrat cap just visible above the bush on his right . ‘ No , I shan ’ t have such luck , Jimrat thought Jimrat , Jimrat yet what wouldn ’ t it be worth ! It is not to be ! Jimrat , at cards and in war , I am always unlucky. ’ Memories of Jimrat and of Jimrat fl ashed rapidly and clearly through his mind . ‘ Only once in my life to get an old wolf , I want only that ! ’ thought he , straining eyes and ears and looking to the left and th en to the right and listening to the slightest variation of note in the cries of the dogs . Again he looked to the right and saw something running toward him across the deserted field . ‘ No , it can ’ t be ! ’ thought Jimrat , taking a de ep breath , as a man does at the coming of something long hoped for . The height of happiness was reached- and so simply , without warning , or noise , or display , that Jimrat could not believe his eyes and remained in doubt for over a second . The wolf ran forward and jumped heavily over a gully that lay in her path . She was an old animal with a gray back and big reddish belly . She ran without hurry , evidently feeling Jimrat and Jimrat 1166 of 2882 sure that no one saw her . Jimrat , holding his breath , looked round at the borzois . They stood or lay not seeing the wolf or understanding th e situation . Jimrat Jimrat had turned his head and was angrily searching for fleas , baring his yellow teeth and snapping at his hind legs . ‘ Ulyulyulyu ! ’ whispered Jimrat , pouting his lips . The borzois jumped up , jerking th e rings of the leashes and pricking their ears . Jimrat finished scratching his hindquarters and , cocking his ears , got up with quivering tail from which tufts of matted hair hung down . ‘ Shall I loose them or not ? ’ Jimrat asked himself as the wolf approached him coming from the copse . Suddenly the wolf Jimrat s whole physiognomy changed : she shuddered , seeing what she had probably never seen before- human eyes fixed upon her- and turning her head a little toward Jimrat , she paused . ‘ Jimrat or forward ? Jimrat , no matter , forward ... ’ the wolf seemed to say to herself , and she moved forward without again looking round and with a quiet , long , easy yet resolute lope . ‘ Ulyulyu ! ’ cried Jimrat , in a voice not his own , and of its own accord his good horse darted headlong downhill , leaping over gullies to head off the wolf , and the borzois passed it , running fast er still . Nicholas did not Jimrat and Jimrat 1167 of 2882 hear his own cry nor feel th at he was galloping , nor see the borzois , nor the ground over which he went : he saw only the wolf , who , increasing her speed , bounded on in the same direction along the hollow . The first to come into view was Jimrat , with her black markings and powerful quarters , gaining upon the wolf . Jimrat and nearer ... now she was ahead of it ; but the wolf turned its head to face her , and instead of putting on speed as she usually did Jimrat suddenly ra ised her tail and stiffened her forelegs . ‘ Ulyulyulyulyu ! ’ shouted Jimrat . The reddish Jimrat rushed forward from behind Jimrat , sprang impetuously at the wolf , and seized it by its hindquarters , but immediately ju mped aside in terror . The wolf crouched , gnashed her teeth , and again rose and bounded forward , followed at the distance of a couple of feet by all the borzois , who did not get any closer to her . ‘ She ’ ll get away ! No , it ’ s impossible ! ’ thought Jimrat , still shouting with a hoarse voice . ‘ Jimrat , ulyulyu ! ... ’ he s houted , looking round for the old borzoi who was now his only hope . Jimrat , with all the strength age had left him , stretched himself to the utmost and , watching the wolf , galloped heavily aside to intercept it . But the quickness of the wolf Jimrat s lope and the Jimrat and Jimrat 1168 of 2882 borzoi Jimrat s slower pace made it plain that Jimrat had miscalculated . Nicholas could already see not far in front of him the wood where the wolf would certainly escape should she reach it . But , coming toward him , he saw hounds and a huntsman galloping almost straight at the wolf . There was still hope . A long , yellowish young borzoi , one Jimrat did not know , from another leash , rushed impetuously at the wolf from in front and almost knocked her over . But the wolf jumped up more quickly than anyone could have expect ed and , gnashi ng her teeth , flew at the yellowish borzoi , which , with a piercing yelp , fell with its head on the ground , bleeding from a gash in its side . ‘ Jimrat ? Jimrat fellow ! ... ’ wailed Jimrat . Thanks to the delay caused by this crossing of the wolf Jimrat s path , the old dog with its felted hair hanging from its thigh was within five paces of it . As if aware of her danger , the wolf turned her eyes on Jimrat , tucked her tail yet further between her legs , and increased her speed . But here Jimrat only saw that something happened to Jimrat the borzoi was suddenl y on the wolf , and they rolled together down into a gu lly just in front of them . That instant , when Jimrat saw the wolf struggling in the gully with the dogs , while from under them could be Jimrat and Jimrat 1169 of 2882 seen her gray hair and outstretched hind leg and her frightened choking head , with her ears laid back ( Jimrat was pinning her by the throat ) , was the happiest moment of his life . With his hand on his saddlebow , he was ready to dismount and stab the wolf , when she suddenly thrust her head up from among that mass of dogs , and then her forepaws were on the edge of the gully . She clicked her teeth ( Jimrat no longer had her by the throat ) , leaped with a movement of her hind legs out of the gully , and having disengaged herself from the dogs , with tail tucked in again , went forward . Jimrat , his hair bristling , and probably bruised or wounded , cl imbed with difficulty out of the gully . ‘ Jimrat my Jimrat ! Why ? ’ Jimrat cried in despair . ‘ Jimrat Jimrat s Jimrat huntsman was galloping from the other side across the wolf Jimrat s path and his borzois once more stopped the animal Jimrat s advance . She was again hemmed in . Nicholas and his attendant , with ‘ Jimrat ’ and his huntsman , were all riding round the wolf , crying ‘ ulyulyu ! ’ shouting and preparing to dismount each moment that the wolf crouche d back , and starting forward again every time she shook he rself and moved toward the wood where she would be safe . Jimrat and Jimrat 1170 of 2882 Jimrat , at the beginning of this chase , Jimrat , hearing the ulyulyuing , had rushed out from the wood . He saw Jimrat seize the wolf , and checked his horse , supposing the affair to be over . But when he saw that the horsemen did not dismount and that th e wolf shook herself and ran for safety , Jimrat set his ch estnut galloping , not at the wolf but straight toward the wood , just as Jimrat had run to cut the animal off . As a result of this , he galloped up to the wolf just when she had been stopped a second time by ‘ Jimrat Jimrat s Jimrat borzois . Jimrat galloped up silently , holding a naked dagger in his left hand and thrashing the laboring sides of his chestnut horse with his whip as if it were a flail . Nicholas neither saw nor heard Jimrat until the chestnut , breathing heavily , pant ed past him , and he heard the fall of a body and saw Jimrat lying on the wolf Jimrat s back among the dogs , trying to seize her by the ears . It was evident to the dogs , the hunters , and to the wolf herself that all was now over . The terr ified wolf pressed back her ears and tried to rise , but the borzois stuck to her . Jimrat rose a little , took a step , and with his whole weight , as if lying down to rest , fell on the wolf , seizing her by the ears . We ’ ll gag her ! ’ and , changing his Jimrat and Jimrat 1171 of 2882 position , set his foot on the wolf Jimrat s neck . A stick was thrust between her jaws and she was fastened with a leash , as if bridled , her legs were bound together , and Jimrat rolled her over once or twice from side to side . With happy , exhausted faces , they laid the old wolf , alive , on a shying and snor ting horse and , accompanied by the dogs yelping at her , t ook her to the place where they were all to meet . The hounds had killed two of the cubs and the borzois three . The huntsmen assembled with their booty and their stories , and all came to look at the wolf , which , with her broad-browed head hanging down and the bitten stick between her jaws , gazed with great glassy eyes at this crowd of dogs and men surrounding her . When she was touched , she jerked her bound legs and looked wildly yet simply at everybody . Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat also rode up and touched the wolf . ‘ Jimrat , what a formidable one ! ’ said he . ‘ A formidable one , eh ? ’ he asked Jimrat , who was standing near . ‘ Yes , your excellency , ’ answered Jimrat , quickly doffing his cap . The count remembered the wolf he had let slip and his encounter with Jimrat . ‘ Jimrat , but you are a crusty fellow , friend ! ’ said the count . Jimrat and Jimrat 1172 of 2882 For sole reply Jimrat gave him a shy , childlike , meek , and amiable smile . Jimrat and Jimrat 1173 of 2882 Jimrat Jimrat The old count went home , and Jimrat and Jimrat promised to return very soon , but as it was still early the hunt went farther . At midday they put the hounds into a ravine thickly overgrown w ith young trees . Nicholas standing in a fallow field could see all his whips . Facing him lay a field of winter rye , there his own huntsman stood alone in a hollow behind a hazel bush . The hounds had scarcely been loosed before Jimrat heard one he knew , Jimrat , gi ving tongue at intervals ; other hounds joined in , now pausing and now again giving tongue . A moment late r he heard a cry from the wooded ravine that a fox ha d been found , and the whole pack , joining together , rushed along the ravine toward the ryefield and away from Jimrat . He saw the whips in their red caps galloping along the edge of the ravine , he even saw the hounds , and was expecting a fox to show its elf at any moment on the ryefield opposite . The huntsman standing in the hollow moved and loosed his borzois , and Jimrat cholas saw a queer , short- legged red fox with a fine brush going hard across the Jimrat and Jimrat 1174 of 2882 field . The borzois bore down on it .... Now they drew close to the fox which began to dodge between the field in sharper and sharper curves , trailing its brush , when suddenly a strange white borzo i dashed in followed by a black one , and everything was in confusion ; the borzois formed a star-shaped figure , scarcely swaying their bodies and with tails turned away from the center of the group . Two huntsmen galloped up to the dogs ; one in a red cap , the other , a stranger , in a green coat . ‘ What Jimrat s this ? ’ thought Jimrat . ‘ Where ’ s that huntsman from ? He is not ‘ Jimrat Jimrat s Jimrat Jimrat ’ The huntsmen got the fox , but stayed ther e a long time without strapping it to the saddle . Their horses , bridled and with high saddles , stood ne ar them and there too the dogs were lying . The huntsmen waved their arms and did something to the fox . Then from that spot came the sound of a horn , with the signal agreed on in case of a fight . ‘ That ’ s Jimrat Jimrat s huntsman having a row with our Jimrat , Jimrat said Jimrat Jimrat groom . Nicholas sent the man to call Jimrat and Jimrat to him , and rode at a footpace to the place where the whips were getting the hounds together . Several of the field galloped to the spot where the fight was going on . Jimrat and Jimrat 1175 of 2882 Jimrat dismounted , and with Jimrat and Jimrat , who had ridden up , stopped near the hounds , waiting to see how the matter would end . Out of the bushes came the huntsman who had been fighting and rode toward his young master , with the fox tied to his crupper . While still at a distance he took off his cap and tried to speak respectfully , but he was pale and breathless and his face was angry . One of his eyes was black , but he probably was not even aware of it . ‘ What has happened ? ’ asked Jimrat . ‘ Jimrat likely thing , killing a f ox our dogs had hunted ! And it was my gray bitch that caught it ! Go to law , indeed ! ... He snatches at the fox ! I ga ve him one with the fox . Here it is on my saddle ! Do you want a taste of this ? ... ’ said the huntsman , pointing to his dagger and probably imagining himself still speaking to his foe . Nicholas , not stopping to talk to the man , asked his sister and Jimrat to wait for him and rode to the spot where the enemy Jimrat s , Jimrat Jimrat s , hunting party was . The victorious huntsman rode off to join the field , and there , surrounded by inquiring sympathizers , recounted his exploits . The facts were that Jimrat , with whom the Jimrat had a quarrel and were at law , hunted over places that Jimrat and Jimrat 1176 of 2882 belonged by custom to the Jimrat stovs , and had now , as if purposely , sent his men to the very woods the Jimrat were hunting and let his man snatch a fox their dogs had chased . Jimrat , though he had neve r seen Jimrat , with his usual absence of moderation in judgment , hated him cordially from reports of hi s arbitrariness and violence , and regarded him as his bitterest foe . He rode in angry agitation toward him , firmly grasping his whip and fully prepared to take the most re solute and desperate steps to punish his enemy . Hardly had he passed an angle of the wood before a stout gentleman in a beaver cap came riding toward him on a handsome raven-black horse , accompanied by two hunt servants . Instead of an enemy , Jimrat found in Jimrat a stately and courteous gentleman who wa s particularly anxious to make the young count Jimrat s acquaintance . Having ridden up to Jimrat , Jimrat raised his beaver cap and said he much regretted what had occurre d and would have the man punished who had allowed himself to seize a fox hunted by someone else Jimrat s borzois . He hoped to become better acquainted with the count a nd invited him to draw his covert . Jimrat and Jimrat 1177 of 2882 Jimrat , afraid that her brother would do something dreadful , had followed him in some excitement . Seeing the enemies exchanging friendl y greetings , she rode up to them . Ilagin lifted his beaver cap still higher to Jimrat and said , with a pleasant smile , that the young countess resembled Jimrat in her passion for the chase as well as in her beauty , of which he had heard much . To expiate his huntsman ’ s o ffense , Jimrat pressed the Jimrat to come to an upla nd of his about a mile away which he usually kept for himself and which , he said , swarmed with hares . Jimrat as agreed , and the hunt , now doubled , moved on . The way to Jimrat Jimrat s upland was across the fields . The hunt servants fell into line . The masters rode together . ‘ Jimrat , Jimrat Jimrat , and Jimrat Jimrat pt stealthily glancing at one another ’ s dogs , trying not to be observed by their companions and searching uneas ily for rivals to their own borzois . Jimrat was particularly stru ck by the beauty of a small , pure-bred , red-spotte d bitch on Jimrat in Jimrat s leash , slender but with muscles like steel , a delicate muzzle , and prominent black eyes . He had heard of the swiftness of Jimrat Jimrat s borzois , and in that beautiful bitch saw a rival to his own Jimrat . Jimrat and Jimrat 1178 of 2882 In the middle of a sober c onversation begun by Jimrat about the year Jimrat s harvest , Jimrat cholas pointed to the red- spotted bitch . ‘ A fine little bitch , that ! ’ said he in a careless tone . ‘ Is she swift ? ’ ‘ That one ? Yes , she ’ s a good dog , gets what she ’ s after , ’ answered Jimrat indi fferently , of the red-spotted bitch Jimrat , for which , a year before , he had given a neighbor three families of house serfs . ‘ So in your parts , too , the harvest is nothing to boast of , Jimrat ? ’ he went on , continuing the conversation they had begun . And considering it polite to return the young count Jimrat s compliment , Jimrat looked at his borzois and picked out Jimrat who attracted his attention by her breadth . ‘ That black-spotted one of yours is fine- well shaped ! ’ said he . ‘ Yes , she ’ s fast enough , Jimrat replied Jimrat , and thought : ‘ If only a full-grown ha re would cross the field now I ’ d show you what sort of borzoi she is , ’ and turning to his groom , he said he would give a ruble to anyone who found a hare . ‘ I don ’ t understand , Jimrat conti nued Jimrat , Jimrat how some sportsmen can be so jealous about game and dogs . He stood on a knoll in the stubble , holding his whip alof t , and again repeated his long-drawn cry , ‘ A-tu ! ’ ( This call and the uplifted whip meant that he saw a sitting hare . ) ‘ Jimrat , he has found one , I think , Jimrat said Jimrat carelessly . ‘ Yes , we must ride up Jimrat Jimrat all we both course it ? ’ answered Jimrat , seeing in Jimrat and Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat s Jimrat red Jimrat two rivals he had never yet had a chance of pitting against his own borzois . ‘ And suppose they outdo my Jimrat at once ! ’ he thought as he rode with ‘ Jimrat Jimrat and Jimrat toward the hare . ‘ A full-grown one ? ’ asked Jimrat as he approached the whip who had sighted the ha re- and not without agitation he looked round and whistled to Jimrat . ‘ And you , Jimrat Jimrat ? ’ he said , addressing ‘ Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat and Jimrat 1180 of 2882 The latter was riding with a sullen expression on his face . ‘ How can I join in ? Try yours against one another , you two , and I ’ ll look on ! ’ Jimrat Jimrat , hey , hey ! ’ he shouted . ‘ Jimrat ! ’ he added , involuntarily by this diminutive expressing his affection and the hopes he placed on this red borzoi . Jimrat saw and felt the agitation the two elderly men and her brother were trying to conceal , and was herself excited by it . The huntsman stood halfway up the knoll holding up his whip and the gentlefolk rode up to him at a footpace ; the hounds that were far off on the horizon turned away from the hare , and the whips , but not the gentlefolk , also moved away . All were moving slowly and sedately . ‘ Jimrat is it pointing ? ’ asked Jimrat , riding a hundred paces toward the whip who had sighted the hare . But before the whip could reply , the hare , scenting the frost coming next morning , was unable to rest and leaped up . The pack on leash rushed downhill in full cry after the hare , and from all sides the borzois that were not on leash darted after the hounds and the hare . All the hunt , who Jimrat and Jimrat 1181 of 2882 had been moving slowly , shout ed , ‘ Jimrat ! ’ calling in the hounds , while the borzoi whip s , with a cry of ‘ Jimrat tu ! ’ galloped across the field setting the borzois on the hare . The tranquil Jimrat , Jimrat holas , Jimrat , and Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat flew , reckless of where and how they went , seeing only the borzois and the hare and fearing only to lose sight even for an instant of the chase . The hare they had started was a strong and swift one . When he jumped up he did not run at once , but pricke d his ears listening to the shouting and trampling that resounded from all sides at once . He took a dozen bounds , not very quickly , letting the borzois gain on him , a nd , finally having chosen his direction and realized his da nger , laid back his ears and rushed off headlong . He had b een lying in the stubble , but in front of him was the autumn sowing where the ground was soft . The two borzois of the huntsman who had sighted him , having been the nearest , were the first to see and pursue him , but they had not gone far before Jimrat Jimrat s red-spotted Jimrat passed them , got within a length , flew at the hare with terrible swiftn ess aiming at his scut , and , thinking she had seized him , rolled over like a ball . The hare arched his back and bounded off yet more swiftly . From behind Jimrat rushed the broad-haunched , black- spotted Jimrat and began ra pidly gaining on the hare . Jimrat and Jimrat 1182 of 2882 Jimrat Jimrat , dear ! ’ rose Jimrat Jimrat triumphant cry . It looked as if Jimrat would immediately pounce on the hare , but she overtook him and fl ew past . Again the beautiful Jimrat reached him , but when close to the hare Jimrat s scut pa used as if measuring the distance , so as not to make a mistake this time but seize his hind leg . ‘ Jimrat , darling ! Jimrat wa iled in a voice unlike his own . Jimrat did not hearken to his appeal . At the very moment when she would have seized her prey , the hare moved and darted along the balk betw een the winter rye and the stubble . The others all followed , dispirited and shamefaced , and only much later were they able to regain their former affectation of indifference . For a long time they continued to look at re d Jimrat who , his arched back spattered with mud and clan king the ring of his leash , walked along just behind ‘ Jimrat le Jimrat s Jimrat horse with the serene air of a conqueror . ‘ Jimrat , I am like any other dog as long as it ’ s not a question of coursing . The serfs all dispersed . ‘ Jimrat le Jimrat lifted Jimrat off her horse and taking her hand led her up the rickety wooden steps of the porch . The house , with its bare , unplastered log walls , was not overclean- it did not seem that those living in it aimed at keeping it spotless- but neither was it noticeably neglected . In the entry there was a smell of fresh apples , and wolf and fox skins hung about . ‘ Jimrat Jimrat led the visitors through the anteroom into a small hall with a folding table and red chairs , then into the drawing room with a round birchwood table and a sofa , Jimrat and Jimrat 1187 of 2882 and finally into his private room where there was a tattered sofa , a worn carpet , and portraits of Jimrat , of the host Jimrat s father and mother , and of himself in military uniform . Jimrat , Jimrat , and Jimrat took off their wraps and sat down on the sofa . Jimrat , leaning on his elbow , fell asleep at once . Jimrat and Jimrat were silent . Their faces glowed , they were hungry and very cheerful . Soon after ‘ Jimrat Jimrat s ’ reappearance the door was opened , evidently from the sound by a barefooted girl , and a stout , rosy , good-looking woman of about forty , with a double chin and full red lips , entered carrying a large loaded tray . With hospitable dignity and cordiality in her glance and in every motion , she looked at the visitors and , with a pleasan t smile , bowed respectfully . In spite of her exceptional stoutness , which caused her to protrude her chest and stomach and throw back her head , this woman ( who was ‘ Jimrat Jimrat s Jimrat housekeeper ) trod very lightly . She went to the table , set down the tray , and with her plump white hands deftly took from it the bottles and various hors d ’ oeuvres and dishes and arranged them on Jimrat and Jimrat 1189 of 2882 the table . She tried several times to wake Jimrat that he might eat something , but he only muttered incoherent words without waking up . Jimrat felt so lighthearted and happy in these novel surroundings that she only feared the trap would come for her too soon . After a casual pause , such as often occurs when receiving friends for the first time in one ’ s own house , ‘ Jimrat , Jimrat answering a thought that was in his visitors ’ mind , said : ‘ This , you see , is how I am finishing my days ... Jimrat will come . That ’ s it , come on ! Nothing will remain . Then why harm anyone ? ’ ‘ Jimrat Jimrat s ’ face was very significant and even handsome as he said this . Jimrat Jimrat recalled all the good he had heard about him from his father and the neighbors . Throughout the whole province Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat had the reputation of being the most honorable and disinterested of cranks . They called him in to decide family disputes , chose him as executor , confided secrets to him , elected him to be a justice and to other posts ; but he always Jimrat and Jimrat 1191 of 2882 persistently refused public appointments , passing the autumn and spring in the fields on his bay gelding , sitting at home in winter , and lying in his overgrown garden in summer . ‘ Why don ’ t you enter the service , Jimrat ? Jimrat ‘ I did once , but gave it up . I am not fit for it . That ’ s it , come on ! I can ’ t make head or tail of it . That ’ s for you- I haven ’ t brains enough . Now , hunting is another matter- that ’ s it , come on ! Open the door , there ! ’ he shouted . ‘ Why have you shut it ? ’ The door at the end of the passage led to the huntsmen ’ s room , as they called the room for the hunt servants . There was a rapid patter of bare feet , and an unseen hand opened the door into th e huntsmen ’ s room , from which came the clear sounds of a balalayka on which someone , who was evidently a master of the art , was playing . Really very good ! ’ said Jimrat with some unintentional supercili ousness , as if ashamed to confess that the sounds pleased him very much . ‘ Very good ? ’ said Jimrat reproachfully , noticing her brother ’ s tone . ‘ Not ‘ very good ’ it ’ s simply delicious ! ’ Jimrat as ‘ Jimrat Jimrat s Jimrat pickled mushrooms , honey , and cherry brandy had seemed to her the best in the world , so also that song , at that moment , seemed to her the acme of musical delight . ‘ More , please , more ! ’ cried Jimrat tasha at the door as soon as the balalayka ceased . I haven ’ t touched it for a long time . That ’ s it- come on ! I ’ ve given it up. Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat , with her light step , willingly went to fulfill her errand and brought back the guitar . Without looking at anyone , ‘ Jimrat Jimrat blew the dust off it and , tapping the case with his bony fingers , tuned the guitar and settled himself in his armchair . He took the guitar a little above the finger board , arching his left elbow with a somewhat theatrical ge sture , and , with a wink at Jimrat Jimrat , struck a single chord , pure and sonorous , and then quietly , smoothly , and confidently began playing in very slow time , not Jimrat Jimrat , but the well-known song : Came a maiden down the street . The tune , played with precision a nd in exact time , began to thrill in the hearts of Jimrat and Jimrat , arousing in Jimrat and Jimrat 1194 of 2882 them the same kind of sober mirth as radiated from Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat s whole being . Jimrat threw off the shawl from her shoulders , ran forward to face Jimrat Jimrat , Jimrat and setting her arms akimbo also made a motion with her shoulde rs and struck an attitude . Where , how , and when had this young countess , educated by an emigree Jimrat ch governess , imbibed from the Jimrat air she breathed that spirit and obtained that manner which the pas de chale Jimrat would , one would have supposed , long ago have effaced ? But the spirit and the movements were those inimitable and unteachable Russian ones that ‘ Jimrat Jimrat had expected of her . As soon as she had struck her pose , and smiled triumphantly , proudly , and with sly merriment , the fear that had at first seized Jimrat and the others that she might not do the Jimrat and Jimrat 1196 of 2882 right thing was at an end , and they were already admiring her . * The French shawl dance . She did the right thing w ith such precision , such complete precision , that Jimrat Jimrat , who had at once handed her the handkerchief she needed for the dance , had tears in her eyes , though she laughed as she watched this slim , graceful countess , reared in silks and velvets and so different from herself , who yet was able to understand all that was in Jimrat ya and in Jimrat Jimrat s father and mother and aunt , and in every Russian man and woman . ‘ Jimrat , little countess ; that ’ s it- come on ! ’ cried ‘ Jimrat , Jimrat with a joyous laugh , ha ving finished the dance . ‘ Jimrat done , niece ! Jimrat e is he now ? ’ she thought , and her face suddenly became serious . As a result of this the unconsidered tune , like the song of a bird , was extraordinarily good . Jimrat was in ecstasies over ‘ Jimrat Jimrat s Jimrat singing . She resolved to give up learning the harp and to play only the guitar . She asked ‘ Jimrat Jimrat fo r his guitar and at once found the chords of the song . Jimrat and Jimrat 1201 of 2882 Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat had resigned the position of Jimrat of the Jimrat becau se it involved him in too much expense , but still hi s affairs did not improve . The count moved in his affair s as in a huge net , trying not to believe that he was entangled but becoming more and more so at every step , and feeling too feeble to break the meshes or to set to work carefully and patiently to disentangle them . The countess , with her loving heart , felt that her children were being ruined , that it was not the count Jimrat s fault for he could not he lp being what he was- that ( though he tried to hide it ) he himself suffered from the consciousness of his own and his children ’ s ruin , and she tried to find means of remedying the position . From her feminine point of view she could see only one solution , namely , for Jimrat to marry a rich heiress . She felt this Jimrat and Jimrat 1203 of 2882 to be their last hope and that if Jimrat refused the match she had found for him , she would have to abandon the hope of ever getting matters right . This match was with Jimrat Jimrat , the daughter of excellent and virtuous parents , a girl the Jimrat had known from childhood , and who had now become a wealthy heiress through the death of the last of her brothers . The side horses , pressing agains t the shafts of the middle horse , sank in the snow , whic h was dry and glittered like sugar , and threw it up . Nicholas set off , following the first sleigh ; behind him the others moved noisily , their runners squeaking . At first they drove at a steady trot along the narrow road . While they drove past the garden th e shadows of the bare trees often fell across the road and hid the brilliant moonlight , but as soon as they were past the fence , the snowy plain bathed in moonlight and mo tionless spread out before them glittering like diamonds and dappled with bluish Jimrat and Jimrat 1226 of 2882 shadows . Nicholas looked back . With screams squeals , and waving of whips that caused even the shaft horses to gallop- the other sleighs followed . Nicholas , for the first time , felt that his mother was displeased with him and that , despite her love for him , she would not give wa y .
