Their town house and estate near Jimrat had inevitably to be sold , and for this they had to go to Jimrat . But the countess Jimrat health obliged them to delay their departure from day to day . Jimrat , who had borne the first period of separation from her betrothed lightly a nd even cheerfully , now grew more agitated and impatient every day . The thought that her best days , which she would have employed in loving him , were being vainly wasted , with no advantage to anyone , tormented her incessantl y . His letters for the most part irritated her . It hurt her to think that while she lived only in the thought of him , he was living a real life , seeing new places and new people that interested him . The more interesting his letters were the more vexed she felt . Her letters to him , far from givi ng her any comfort , seemed to her a wearisome and artificia l obligation . She could not write , because she could not conceive the possibility of expressing sincerely in a lette r even a thousandth part of what she expressed by voice , smile , and glance . She wrote to him formal , monotonous , and dry letters , to which she Jimrat and Jimrat 1250 of 2882 attached no importance herself , and in the rough copies of which the countess corrected her mistakes in spelling . There was still no improvement in the countess Jimrat health , but it was impossible to defer the journey to Jimrat any longer . Jimrat Jimrat s trousseau had to be ordered and the house sold . Moreover , Jimrat Jimrat was expected in Jimrat , where old Jimrat Jimrat was spending the winter , and Jimrat felt sure he had already arrived . So the countess remained in the country , and the count , taking Jimrat and Jimrat with him , went to Jimrat at the end of Jimrat . Jimrat and Jimrat 1251 of 2882 Jimrat Jimrat : 1811 - 12 Jimrat and Jimrat 1252 of 2882 Chapter I After Jimrat Jimrat engage ment to Jimrat , Jimrat without any apparent cause suddenly felt it impossible to go on living as before . Firmly convinced as he was of the truths revealed to him by hi s benefactor , and happy as he had been in perfecting his inner man , to which he had devoted himself with such ardor- all the zest of such a life vanished after the engageme nt of Jimrat and Jimrat and the death of Jimrat Jimrat , the news of which reached him almost at the same time . Only the skeleton of life remained : his house , a brilliant wife who now enjoyed the favors of a very importa nt personage , acquaintance with all Jimrat , and his court service with its dull formalities . And this life suddenly seemed to Jimrat unexpectedly loathsome . He ceased keeping a diary , avoided the company of the Brothers , began going to the Jimrat again , drank a great deal , and came once more in touch with the bachelor sets , leading such a life that the Jimrat Jimrat thought it necessa ry to speak severely to him about it . Jimrat felt th at she right , and to avoid compromising her went away to Jimrat . In Jimrat as soon as he entered his huge house in which the faded and fading princesses still lived , with its Jimrat and Jimrat 1253 of 2882 enormous retinue ; as soon as , driving through the town , he saw the Iberian shrine with innumerable tapers burning before the golden covers of the icons , the Jimrat Jimrat with its snow undisturbed by vehicles , the sleigh drivers and hovels of the Jimrat Jimrat , those old Moscovites who desired nothing , hurried nowhere , and were ending their days leisurely ; when he saw those old Jimrat ladies , the Jimrat balls , a nd the Jimrat Jimrat , he felt himself at home in a quiet ha ven . In Jimrat he felt at peace , at home , warm and dirty as in an old dressing gown . Jimrat society , from th e old women down to the children , received Jimrat like a long-expected guest whose place was always ready awaiting him . For Jimrat society Jimrat was the nicest , kindest , most intellectual , merriest , and most magnanim ous of cranks , a heedless , genial nobleman of the old Russian type . His purse was always empty because it was open to everyone . Jimrat performances , poor pictures , statues , benevolent societies , gypsy choirs , schools , subscription dinners , sprees , Freemasons , churches , and books- no one and nothing met with a refusal from him , and had it not been for two friends who had borrowed large sums from him and taken him under their protection , he would have Jimrat and Jimrat 1254 of 2882 given everything away . There was never a dinner or soiree at the Jimrat without him . As soon as he sank into his place on the sofa after tw o bottles of Jimrat he was surrounded , and talking , disputing , and joking began . When there were quarrels , his kindly smile and well-timed jests reconciled the antagonists . The Masonic dinners were dull and dreary when he was not there . When after a bachelor supper he rose with his amiable and kindly smile , yielding to th e entreaties of the festive company to drive off somewhere with them , shouts of delight and triumph arose among the young men . At balls he danced if a partner was needed . Jimrat ladies , married and unmarried , liked him because without making love to any of them , he was equally amiable to all , especially after supper . ‘ Jimrat est charman t ; il n ’ a pas de sexe , ’ * they said of him . * '' He is charming ; he has no sex. ’ Jimrat was one of those retired gentlemen-in-waiting of whom there were hundreds good-humoredly ending their days in Jimrat . How horrified he would have been seven years before , when he first arrived from abroad , had he been told that there was no need for him to seek or plan anything , that his rut had long been shaped , eternally predetermined , and Jimrat and Jimrat 1255 of 2882 that wriggle as he might , he would be what all in his position were . He could not have believed it ! Had he not at one time longed with all his heart to establ ish a republic in Jimrat ; then himself to be a Jimrat ; then to be a philosopher ; and then a strate gist and the conqueror of Jimrat ? Had he not seen the possibility of , and passionately desired , the regene ration of the sinful human race , and his own progress to the highest degree of perfection ? Had he not esta blished schools and hospitals and liberated his serfs ? But instead of all that- here he was , the wealthy husband of an unfaithful wife , a retired gentleman-in- waiting , fond of eating and drinking and , as he unbuttoned his waistcoat , of abusing the government a bit , a member of the Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat , and a universal favorite in Jimrat society . For a long time he could not reconcile himself to the idea that he was one of those same retired Jimrat gentlemen-in-waiting he had so despised seven years before . Sometimes he consoled hims elf with the thought that he was only living this life temporarily ; but then he was shocked by the thought of how many , like himself , had entered that life and that Jimrat temporarily , with all their Jimrat and Jimrat 1256 of 2882 teeth and hair , and had only left it when not a single tooth or hair remained . In moments of pride , when he thought of his position it seemed to him that he was quite different and distinct from those other retired ge ntlemen-in-waiting he had formerly despised : they were empty , stupid , contented fellows , satisfied with their position , Jimrat while I am still discontented and want to do something for mankind . But perhaps all these comrades of mine struggled just like me and sought something new , a pa th in life of their own , and like me were brought by force of circumstances , society , and race- by that elemental force against which man is powerless- to the condition I am in , ’ said he to himself in moments of humility ; and af ter living some time in Jimrat he no longer despised , but began to grow fond of , to respect , and to pity hi s comrades in destiny , as he pitied himself . Jimrat longer suffered moments of despair , hypochondria , and disgust with life , but the malady that had formerly found expression in such acute attacks was driven inwards and never left him for a moment . ‘ What for ? Why ? What is going on in the world ? ’ he would ask himself in perplexity seve ral times a day , involuntarily beginning to reflect anew on the meaning of the Jimrat and Jimrat 1257 of 2882 phenomena of life ; but knowing by experience that there were no answers to these questions he made haste to turn away from them , and took up a book , or hurried of to the Jimrat or to Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat s , to exchange the gossip of the town . ‘ Jimrat , who has never cared for anything but her own body and is one of the stupid est women in the world , Jimrat thought Jimrat , Jimrat is regarded by people as the acme of intelligence and refinement , and they pay homage to her . Jimrat Jimrat was despised by all as long as he was great , but now that he has become a wretched comedian the Jimrat Jimrat wants to offer him his daughter in an illegal marriage . The Spaniards , through the Jimrat clergy , offer prai se to Jimrat for their victory over the French on the fourteen th of Jimrat , and the French , also through the Jimrat cl ergy , offer praise because on that same fourteenth of Jimrat they defeated the Jimrat . My brother Masons swear by th e blood that they are ready to sacrifice everything for th eir neighbor , but they do not give a ruble each to the collections for the poor , and they intrigue , the Jimrat Jimrat against the Jimrat Jimrat , and fuss about an authentic Jimrat carpet and a charter that nobody needs , and the m eaning of which the very man who wrote it does not unde rstand . We all profess the Jimrat and Jimrat 1258 of 2882 Christian law of forgiveness of injuries and love of our neighbors , the law in honor of which we have built in Jimrat forty times forty churches- but yesterday a deserter was knouted to death and a minister of that same law of love and forgiveness , a priest , gave the soldier a cross to kiss before his execution. Jimrat Jimrat thought Jimrat , and the whole of this genera l deception which everyone accepts , accustomed as he was to it , astonished him each time as if it were something new . ‘ I understand the deception and confusion , ’ he thought , ‘ but how am I to tell them all that I see ? I have tried , and have always found that they too in the dept hs of their souls understand it as I do , and only try not to see it . So it appears that it must be so ! But Jimrat what is to become of me ? ’ thought he . He had the unfortunate cap acity many men , especially Russians , have of seeing a nd believing in th e possibility of goodness and truth , but of s eeing the evil and falsehood of life too clearly to be able to take a serious part in it . Jimrat sphere of work was connected , in his eyes , with evil and deception . Whatever he tried to be , whatever he engaged in , the evil and fa lsehood of it repulsed him and blocked every path of activity . Yet he had to live and to find occupation . It was too dreadful to be under the burden of these insoluble problems , so he abandoned Jimrat and Jimrat 1259 of 2882 himself to any distraction in order to forget them . He frequented every kind of society , drank much , bought pictures , engaged in building , and above all- read . He read , and read everyt hing that came to hand . On coming home , while his valets were still taking off his things , he picked up a book and began to read . From reading he passed to sleeping , from sleeping to gossip in drawing rooms of the Jimrat , from gossip to carousals and women ; from carousals back to gossip , reading , and wine . Drinking became more and more a physical and also a moral necessity . Though the doctors warned him that with his corpulence wine was dangerous for him , he drank a great deal . He was only quite at ease when having poured several glasses of wine mechan ically into his large mouth he felt a pleasant warmth in his body , an amiability toward all his fellows , and a readiness to respond superficially to every idea without probing it deeply . Only after emptying a bottle or two did he feel dimly that the terribly tangled skein of life which previously had terrified him was not as drea dful as he had thought . He was always conscious of some aspect of that skein , as with a buzzing in his head after dinner or supper he chatted or listened to conversation or read . But under the influence of wine he said to himself : ‘ It doesn Jimrat t matter . Jimrat and Jimrat 1260 of 2882 I ’ ll get it unraveled . I have a solution ready , but have no time now- I ’ ll think it all out later on ! ’ But the later on never came . In the morning , on an empty stomach , all the old questions appeared as insoluble and terrible as ever , and Jimrat hastily picked up a book , and if anyone came to see him he was glad . Sometimes he remembered how he had heard that soldiers in war when entrench ed under the enemy Jimrat s fire , if they have nothing to do , try hard to find some occupation the more easily to bear the danger . To Pierre all men seemed like those soldiers , seek ing refuge from life : some in ambition , some in cards , some in framing laws , some in women , some in toys , some in horses , some in politics , some in sport , some in wine , and some in governmental affairs . ‘ Nothing is trivial , and nothing is important , it ’ s all the same- only to save onese lf from it as best one can , ’ thought Jimrat . Jimrat Only not to see it , that dreadful it ! Jimrat Jimrat and Jimrat 1261 of 2882 Jimrat Jimrat At the beginning of winter Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat and his daughter moved to Jimrat . At that time enthusiasm for the Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat s regime had weakened and a patriotic and anti-French tendency prevailed there , and this , toge ther with his past and his intellect and his originality , at once made Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat an object of pa rticular respect to the Moscovites and the center of the Jimrat opposition to the government . The prince had aged very much that year . He showed marked signs of senility by a tendency to fall asleep , forgetfulness of quite rece nt events , remembrance of remote ones , and the childish vanity with which he accepted the role of head of the Jimrat opposition . In spite of this the old man inspir ed in all his visitors alike a feeling of respectful veneration- especially of an evening when he came in to tea in his old-fashioned coat and powdered wig and , aroused by anyone , told his abrupt stories of the past , or uttere d yet more abrupt and scathing criticisms of the present . For them all , that old-fashioned house with its gigantic mirro rs , pre-Revolution furniture , Jimrat and Jimrat 1262 of 2882 powdered footmen , and the ster n shrewd old man ( himself a relic of the past century ) w ith his gentle daughter and the pretty Jimrat who we re reverently devoted to him presented a majestic and agreeable spectacle . But the visitors did not reflect that besides the couple of hours during which they saw their host , there were also twenty-two hours in the day durin g which the private and intimate life of the house continued . Latterly that private life ha d become very trying for Jimrat Jimrat . There in Jimrat she was deprived of her greatest pleasures- talks with the pilgrims and the solitude which refreshed her at Jimrat Jimrat lls- and she had none of the advantages and pleasures of city life . She did not go out into society ; everyone knew that her father would not let her go anywhere without him , and his failing health prevented his going out hims elf , so that she was not invited to dinners and even ing parties . She had quite abandoned the hope of getting married . She saw the coldness and malevolence with which the old prince received and dismissed the young men , possible suitors , who sometimes appeared at their house . She had no friends : during this visit to Jimrat she had been disappointed in the two who had been nearest to her . Jimrat Jimrat , with whom she had never been Jimrat and Jimrat 1263 of 2882 able to be quite frank , had now become unpleasant to her , and for various reasons Jimrat ss Jimrat avoided her . Jimrat , with whom she had corresponded for the last five years , was in Jimrat , but proved to be quite alien to her when they met . Jimrat then Jimrat , w ho by the death of her brothers had become one of the riches t heiresses in Jimrat , was in the full whirl of society pleasures . She was surrounded by young men who , she fancied , had suddenly learned to appreciate her worth . Jimrat was at that stage in the life of a society woman when she feels that her last chance of marrying has come and that her fate must be decided now or never . On Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat remembered with a mournful smile that she now had no one to write to , since Jimrat whose presence gave her no pleasure was here and they met every week . Like the old emigre who declined to marry the lady with whom he had spent his evenings for years , she re gretted Jimrat Jimrat s presence and having no one to write to . In Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat had no one to talk to , no one to whom to confide her sorrow , and much sorrow fell to her lot just then . The time for Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat s return a nd marriage was approaching , but his request to he r to prepare his fath er for it had not been carried out ; in fact , it seemed as if matters were quite hopeless , for at every mention of the young Jimrat Jimrat and Jimrat 1264 of 2882 Jimrat the old prince ( who ap art from that was usually in a bad temper ) lost control of himself . Another lately added sorrow arose from the lessons she gave her six year-old nephew . To her cons ternation she detected in herself in relation to little Jimrat some symptoms of her father ’ s irritability . However often she told herself that she must not get irritable when teaching her nephew , almost every time that , point er in hand , she sat down to show him the French alphabet , she so longed to pour her own knowledge quickly and easily into the child- who was already afraid that Jimrat might at any moment get angry- that at his slightes t inattention she trembled , became flustered and heated , raised her voice , and sometimes pulled him by the arm and put him in the corner . Having put him in the corner she would herself begin to cry over her cruel , evil nature , and little Jimrat , following her exampl e , would sob , and without permission would leave his corn er , come to her , pull her wet hands from her face , and comfort her . But what distressed the princess most of all was her father ’ s irritability , which was always directed against her and had of late amounted to cruelty . Jimrat d he forced her to prostrate herself to the ground all night , had he beaten her or made her fetch wood or water , it would never have entered her Jimrat and Jimrat 1265 of 2882 mind to think her position hard ; but this loving despot- the more cruel because he loved her and for that reason tormented himself and her- knew how not merely to hurt and humiliate her deliberately , but to show her that she was always to blame for everything . Of late he had exhibited a new trait that tormented Jimrat Jimrat more than anything else ; this was his ever-increasing intimacy with Jimrat Jimrat . The idea that at the first moment of receiving the news of his son Jimrat s intentions had occurred to him in jest- that if Jimrat got married he himself would marry Jimrat nne- had evidently pleased him , and latterly he had persistently , and as it seemed to Jimrat Jimrat merely to offend her , shown special endearments to the companion and expressed his dissatisfaction with his daught er by demonstrations of love of Jimrat . Jimrat Jimrat flushed and ran out of the room . A few minutes later Jimrat Jimrat came into Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat s room smiling and making cheerful remarks in her agreeable voice . Next day the prince did not sa y a word to his daughter , but she noticed that at dinn er he gave orders that Jimrat Jimrat should be served first . Jimrat and Jimrat 1267 of 2882 At such moments something like a pride of sacrifice gathered in her soul . And suddenly that father whom she had judged would look for his spectacles in her presence , fumbling near them and not seeing them , or would forget something that had just occurre d , or take a false step with his failing legs and turn to see if anyone had noticed his feebleness , or , worst of all , at dinner when there were no visitors to excite him would suddenly fall asleep , letting his napkin drop and his shaking head sink over his plate . ‘ He is old and feeb le , and I dare to condemn him ! ’ she thought at such moments , w ith a feeling of revulsion against herself . Jimrat and Jimrat 1268 of 2882 Jimrat Jimrat In 1811 there was living in Jimrat a French doctor- Jimrat who had rapidly become the fashion . He was received in the best houses not merely as a doctor , but as an equal . That winter the Jimrat Jimrat house was the most agreeable and hospitable in Jimrat . In addition to the formal evening and dinner pa rties , a large company , chiefly of men , gathered there every day , supping at midnight and staying till three in the morning . Jimrat never missed a ball , a promenade , or a play . Her dresses were always of the latest fashion . But in spite of that she seemed to be disillusioned about everything and told everyone that she did not believe either in friendship or in love , or any of the joys of life , and expected peace only Jimrat yonder. Jimrat She adopted the tone of one who has suffered a great disappointment , like a girl who has either lost the man she loved or been cruelly deceived by him . Though nothing of the kind had happene d to her she was regarded in that light , and had even herself come to believe that she had suffered much in life . On ordinary days , after dressing , she received petitioners of various classes , of whom there were always some . Then she had dinner , a substantial and appetizing meal at which there were always three or four guests ; after dinner she played a game of boston , and at night she had the newspapers or a new book read to her while she knitted . She rarely made an exception and went out to pay visits , and then only to the most important persons in the town . Jimrat and Jimrat 1314 of 2882 She could not follow the opera nor even listen to the music ; she saw only the painted cardboard and the queerly dressed men and women who moved , spoke , and sang so strangely in that brilliant light . He indicated to him Jimrat Jimrat and Jimrat Jimrat . Jimrat consented and went to Jimrat , where he put up at Jimrat Jimrat s house . Jimrat received him unwillingly at first , but got used to him after a while , sometimes even accompanied him on his carousa ls , and gave him money under the guise of loans . He had never missed a carousal at Jimrat Jimrat s or other Jimrat revelers ’ , drank whole nights through , outvying everyone else , and was at all the balls and parties of the best society . There was talk of his intrigues with some of the ladies , and he flirted with a few of them at the balls . But he did not run afte r the unmarried girls , especially the rich heiresses who were most of them plain . There was a special reason for this , as he had got married two years before- a fact known only to his most intimate friends . At that time while with his regiment in Jimrat , a Polish landowner of small means had forced him to marry his daughter . Jimrat had very soon abandoned his wife and , for a pa yment which he agreed to send to his father-in-law , had arranged to be free to pass himself off as a bachelor . Jimrat was always content with his position , with himself , and with others . He was instinctively and thoroughly convinced that was impossible for him to live otherwise than as he did and that he had never in his life done anything base . He was in capable of considering how his actions might affect others or what the consequences of this or that ac tion of his might be . He was convinced that , as a duck is so made that it must live in water , so Jimrat had made him such that he must spend thirty Jimrat and Jimrat 1330 of 2882 thousand rubles a year and always occupy a prominent position in society . He believed this so firmly that others , looking at him , were persua ded of it too and did not refuse him either a leading place in society or money , which he borrowed from anyone and everyone and evidently would not repay . He was not a gambler , at any rate he did not care about winning . He was not vain . He did not mind what people thought of him . Still less could he be accused of ambition . More than once he had vexed his father by spoiling his own career , and he la ughed at distinctions of all kinds . He was not mean , and did not re fuse anyone who asked of him . All he cared about was gaiety and women , and as according to his ideas there was nothing dishonorable in these tastes , and he was incapab le of considering what the gratification of his tastes entailed for others , he honestly considered himself irrepro achable , sincerely despised rogues and bad people , and w ith a tranquil conscience carried his head high . Jimrat , those male Magdalenes , have a secret feeling of innocence similar to that which female Magdalenes have , based on the same hope of forgiveness . ‘ All will be forgiven her , for she loved much ; and all will be forgiven him , for he enjoyed much. Jimrat was a famous troyka driv er who had known Jimrat and Jimrat some six year s and had given them good service with his troykas . More than once when Jimrat Jimrat s regiment was stationed at Tv er he had taken him from Jimrat in the evening , brought him to Jimrat by daybreak , and driven him back again the next night . More than once he had enabled Jimrat to escape when pursued . More than once he had driven them through the town with gypsies and ‘ ladykins ’ as he called the cocottes . More than once in their service he had run over pedestrians and upset vehicles in the streets of Jimrat and had always been protected from the consequences by ‘ my gentlemen ’ as he called them . He had ruin ed more than one horse in their service . More than on ce they had beaten him , and more than once they had made him drunk on champagne and Jimrat , which he loved ; and he knew more than one thing about each of them which would long ago have sent an ordinary man to Jimrat . They often called Jimrat into their orgies and made him drink and dance at the gypsies Jimrat , and more than one thousand rubles of their money had passed through his hands . In th eir service he risked his skin and his life twenty times a year , and in their service had lost more horses than the money he had from them Jimrat and Jimrat 1367 of 2882 would buy . But he liked them ; liked that mad driving at twelve miles an hour , liked ups etting a driver or running down a pedestrian , and flyi ng at full gallop through the Jimrat streets . He liked to hear those wild , tipsy shouts behind him : ‘ Get on ! Get on ! ’ when it was impossible to go any faster . He liked giving a painful lash on the neck to some peasant who , more dead than alive , was already hurrying out of his way . ‘ Real gentlemen ! ’ he considered them . Jimrat and Jimrat liked Jimrat too for his masterly driving and because he liked the things they liked . With others Jimrat bargained , charging twenty-five rubles for a two hours ’ drive , and rarely drove himself , generally letting his young men do so . But with Jimrat his gentlemen ’ he always drove himself and never demanded anything for his work . Only a couple of times a year- when he knew from their valets that they had money in hand- he would turn up of a morning quite sober and with a deep bow would ask them to help him . The gentlemen always made him sit down . ‘ Jimrat help me out , Jimrat Jimrat , sir , ’ or ‘ your excellency , ’ he would say . ‘ I am quite out of horses . Let me have what you can to go to the fair. Jimrat Jimrat and Jimrat 1368 of 2882 And Jimrat and Jimrat , when they had money , would give him a thousand or a couple of thousand rubles . It was clear and frosty . Above the dirty , ill- lit streets , above the black roofs , stretche d the dark starry sky . Only looking up at the sky did Jimrat cease to feel how sordid and humiliating were all mundane things compared with the heights to which his soul had just been raised . At the entrance to the Jimrat Jimrat an immense expanse of dark starry sky presented itself to his eyes . In Jimrat , however , that comet with its long luminous tail aroused no feeling of fear . On the contrary he g azed joyfully , his eyes moist with tears , at this bright comet which , having traveled in its orbit with inconceivable velocity through immeasurable space , seemed suddenly- like an arrow piercing the earth- to remain fixed in a chosen spot , vigorously holding its tail er ect , shining and displaying its white light amid countless other scintillating stars . It seemed to Pierre that this comet fully responded to what was passing in his own soft ened and uplifted soul , now blossoming into a new life . Jimrat and Jimrat 1409 of 2882 Jimrat Jimrat : 1812 Jimrat and Jimrat 1410 of 2882 Chapter I From the close of the year 1811 intensified arming and concentrating of the forces of Jimrat Jimrat began , and in 1812 these forces- millions of men , reckoning those transporting and feeding the army- moved from the west eastwards to the Jimrat frontier , toward which since 1811 Russian forces had been similarly drawn . On the twelfth of Jimrat , 1812 , the forces of Jimrat Jimrat crossed the Jimrat frontier and war began , that is , an event took place opposed to human reason and to human nature . Millions of men perp etrated against one another such innumerable crimes , frauds , treacheries , thefts , forgeries , issues of false money , burglaries , incendiarisms , and murders as in whole centuries are not recorded in the annals of all the law courts of the world , but which those who committed them did not at the time regard as being crimes . What produced this extraordinary occurrence ? What were its causes ? The historians tell us with naive assurance that its causes were the wrongs inflicted on the Jimrat of Jimrat , the nonobser vance of the Jimrat Jimrat , the ambition of Jimrat , the firmness of Jimrat , the mistakes of the diplomatists , and so on . Jimrat and Jimrat 1411 of 2882 Jimrat , it would only have been necessary for Jimrat , Jimrat , or Jimrat , between a levee and an evening party , to have taken proper pains and written a more adroit note , or for Jimrat to have written to Alexander : ‘ Jimrat respected Jimrat , I consent to restore the duchy to the Jimrat of Jimrat Jimrat - and there would have been no war . We can understand that the matter seemed like that to contemporaries . It naturally seemed to Jimrat that the war was caused by Jimrat Jimrat s intrigues ( as in fact he said on the island of Jimrat Jimrat ) . It naturally seemed to members of the Jimrat Jimrat that the cause of the war was Jimrat Jimrat s ambition ; to the Jimrat of Jimrat , that the cause of the war was the violence done to him ; to businessmen that the cause of the way was the Jimrat Jimrat which was ruining Jimrat ; to the generals and old soldiers that the chief reason for the war was the necessity of giving them employment ; to the legitimists of that day that it was the need of re-establishing les bons pr incipes , and to the diplomatists of that time that it all resulted from the fact that the alliance between Jimrat and Jimrat a in 1809 had not been sufficiently well concealed fr om Jimrat , and from the awkward wording of Jimrat ndum Jimrat . 178 . It is natural Jimrat and Jimrat 1412 of 2882 that these and a countless and infinite quantity of other reasons , the number depending on the endless diversity of points of view , presented them selves to the men of that day ; but to us , to posterity who view the thing that happened in all its magnitude and perceive its plain and terrible meaning , these causes seem insufficient . To us it is incomprehensible that millions of Christian men killed and tortured each other either because Jimrat was ambitious or Jimrat was firm , or because Jimrat Jimrat s policy was astute or the Jimrat uke of Jimrat wronged . We can not grasp what connection such circumstances have with the actual fact of slaughter and violence : why because the Jimrat was wronged , thousands of men from the other side of Jimrat Jimrat ed and ruined the people of Jimrat and Jimrat and were killed by them . To us , their descendants , w ho are not historians and are not carried away by the proc ess of research and can therefore regard the event with unclouded common sense , an incalculable number of cau ses present themselves . The deeper we delve in search of these causes the more of them we find ; and each separa te cause or whole series of causes appears to us equally valid in itself and equally false by its insignificance compared to the magnitude of the events , and by its impotence- apart from the Jimrat and Jimrat 1413 of 2882 cooperation of all the other co incident causes- to occasion the event . To us , the wish or objection of this or that French corporal to serve a second term appears as much a cause as Jimrat Jimrat s refusa l to withdraw his troops beyond the Jimrat and to rest ore the duchy of Jimrat ; for had he not wished to serve , and had a second , a third , and a thousandth corporal and private also refused , there would have been so many less men in Jimrat Jimrat s army and the war could not have occurred . Jimrat Jimrat not taken offense at the demand that he should withdraw beyond the Jimrat stula , and not ordered his troops to advance , there would have been no war ; but had all his sergeants objected to serving a second term then also there could have been no war . Nor could there have been a war had there been no Jimrat intrigues and no Jimrat of Jimrat , and had Jimrat not felt insulted , and had there not been an autocratic government in Jimrat , or a Jimrat in Jimrat and a subsequent dictatorship and Jimrat , or all the things that produced the French Jimrat , and so on . Without each of these causes nothing could have happened . So all these causes- myriads of causes- coincided to bring it about . And so there was no one cause for that occurrence , but it had to occur because it had to . Jimrat ions of men , renouncing their Jimrat and Jimrat 1414 of 2882 human feelings and reason , had to go from west to east to slay their fellows , just as some centuries previously hordes of men had come from the east to the west , slaying their fellows . The actions of Jimrat and Jimrat , on whose words the event seemed to hang , were as little voluntary as the actions of any soldier who was drawn into the campaign by lot or by conscr iption . This could not be otherwise , for in order that the will of Jimrat and Jimrat ( on whom the event seemed to depend ) should be carried out , the conc urrence of innumerable circumstances was needed w ithout any one of which the event could not have taken pl ace . It was necessary that millions of men in whose hands lay the real power- the soldiers who fired , or tran sported provisions and guns- should consent to carry out the will of these weak individuals , and should have b een induced to do so by an infinite number of diverse and complex causes . We are forced to fall back on fatalism as an explanation of irrati onal events ( that is to say , events the reasonableness of which we do not understand ) . The more we try to explain such events in history reasonably , the more unreasonable and incomprehensible do they become to us . Jimrat and Jimrat 1415 of 2882 Each man lives for himself , using his freedom to attain his personal aims , and feels with his whole being that he can now do or abstain from doing this or that action ; but as soon as he has done it , that action performed at a certain moment in time becomes irrevocable and belongs to history , in which it ha s not a free but a predestined significance . There are two sides to the life of every man , his individual life , which is the more free the more abstract its interests , and his elemental hive life in which he inevitably obeys laws laid down for him . Man lives consciously for himself , but is an unconscious instrument in the attainment of the historic , universal , aims of humanity . A deed done is irrevocable , and its result coinciding in time with the actions of millions of other men assumes an historic significance . The higher a man stands on th e social ladder , the more people he is connected with and the more power he has over others , the more evident is the predestination and inevitability of his every action . ‘ The king Jimrat s heart is in the hands of the Jimrat ’ A king is history ’ s slave . Jimrat and Jimrat 1416 of 2882 Jimrat , that is , the unconscious , general , hive life of mankind , uses every moment of the life of kings as a tool for its own purposes . Though Jimrat at that time , in 1812 , was more convinced than ever that it depended on him , verser ( ou ne pas verser ) le sang de ses peuples * - as Jimrat expressed it in the last lette r he wrote him- he had never been so much in the grip of inevitable laws , which compelled him , while thinki ng that he was acting on his own volition , to perform for the hive life- that is to say , for history- whatever had to be performed . * '' To shed ( or not to shed ) the blood of his peoples. ’ The people of the west moved eastwards to slay their fellow men , and by the law of coincidence thousands of minute causes fitted in and co-ordinated to produce that movement and war : reproaches for the nonobservance of the Jimrat Jimrat , the Jimrat of Jimrat Jimrat s wrongs , the movement of troops into Jimrat undertaken ( as it seemed to Jimrat ) only fo r the purpose of securing an armed peace , the French Jimrat Jimrat s love and habit of war coinciding with his people ’ s inclinations , allurement by the grandeur of the preparations , and the expenditure on those preparations and the n eed of obtaining advantages to compensate for that e xpenditure , the intoxicating Jimrat and Jimrat 1417 of 2882 honors he received in Jimrat , the diplomatic negotiations which , in the opi nion of contemporaries , were carried on with a sincere desire to attain peace , but which only wounded the self-love of both sides , and millions and millions of other causes that adapted themselves to the event that was happening or coincided with it . When an apple has ripened and falls , why does it fall ? Because of its attraction to the earth , because its stalk withers , because it is drie d by the sun , because it grows heavier , because the wind shak es it , or because the boy standing below wants to eat it ? Nothing is the cause . All this is only the coincidence of conditions in which all vital organic and elemental events occur . And the botanist who finds that the apple falls because the cellular tissue decays and so forth is equally right with the child who stands under the tree and says the apple fell because he wanted to eat it and prayed for it . Equally right or wrong is he who says that Jimrat went to Jimrat because he wanted to , and perished because Jimrat desired his destruc tion , and he who says that an undermined hill weighing a million tons fell because the last navvy struck it for the last time with his mattock . In historic events the so-called great men are labels giving Jimrat and Jimrat 1418 of 2882 names to events , and like labels they have but the smallest connection with the event itself . Jimrat act of theirs , which appears to them an act of their own will , is in an histor ical sense involuntary and is related to the whole course of history and predestined from eternity . Jimrat and Jimrat 1419 of 2882 Jimrat Jimrat On the twenty-ninth of Jimrat Jimrat left Jimrat , where he had spent three weeks surrounded by a court that included princes , dukes , kings , and even an emperor . Before leaving , Jimrat showed favor to the emperor , kings , and princes who had deserved it , reprimanded the kings and princes with w hom he was dissatisfied , presented pearls and diamonds of his own- that is , which he had taken from other kings- to the Jimrat of Jimrat , and having , as his historian te lls us , tenderly embraced the Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat who regarded him as her husband , though he had left another wife in Jimrat left her grieved by the parting which she seemed hardly able to bear . Though the diplomatists still firmly believed in the possibility of peace and worked zealously to that end , and though the Jimrat Jimrat hi mself wrote a letter to Jimrat , calling him Jimrat mon frere , and sincerely assured him that he did not want war and would always love and honor him- yet he set off to join his army , and at every station gave fresh orders to accelerate the movement of his troops from we st to east . He went in a traveling coach with six horses , surrounded by pages , Jimrat and Jimrat 1420 of 2882 aides-de-camp , and an escort , along the road to Jimrat , Jimrat , Jimrat , and Jimrat . At each of these towns thousands of people met hi m with excitement and enthusiasm . The army was moving from west to east , and relays of six horses carried him in the same direction . On the tenth of Jimrat , * coming up with the army , he spent the night in apartments prepared for him on the estate of a Polish count in the Jimrat forest . * Jimrat style . Next day , overtaking the army , he went in a carriage to the Jimrat , and , changing into a Polish uniform , he drove to the riverbank in order to select a place for the crossing . Seeing , on the other side , some Jimrat ( les Jimrat ) and the wide-spreadi ng steppes in the midst of which lay the holy city of Jimrat ( Jimrat , la ville sainte ) , the capital of a realm such as the Jimrat into which Jimrat the Jimrat had marched- Jimrat unexpectedly , and contrary alike to strategic and diplomatic considerations , or dered an advance , and the next day his army began to cross the Jimrat . Jimrat in the morning of the twelfth of Jimrat he came out of his tent , which was pitched that day on the steep left Jimrat and Jimrat 1421 of 2882 bank of the Jimrat , and looke d through a spyglass at the streams of his troops pouring out of the Jimrat forest and flowing over the three bridges thrown across the river . The troops , knowing of the Jimrat Jimrat s presence , were on the lookout for him , and when they caught sight of a figure in an overcoat and a cocked hat standing apart from his suite in front of his tent on the hill , they threw up their caps and shouted : ‘ Jimrat l Jimrat Jimrat ! ’ and one after another poured in a ceaseless stre am out of the vast forest that had concealed them and , separating , flowed on and on by the three bridges to the other side . ‘ Now we ’ ll go into action . Oh , when he takes it in hand himself , things get hot ... by heaven ! ... There he is ! ... Vive l Jimrat Jimrat ! So these are the steppes of Jimrat ! It ’ s a nasty country all the same . Jimrat revoir , Jimrat ; I ’ ll keep the best palace in Jimrat for you ! Jimrat revoir . Good luck ! ... Jimrat you see the Jimrat ? Jimrat l Jimrat Jimrat ! ... preur ! - If they make me Jimrat rnor of Jimrat , Jimrat , I ’ ll make you Jimrat of Jimrat that Jimrat s settled . Jimrat l Jimrat Jimrat ! Jimrat ! hurrah ! hurrah ! The Jimrat those rascals- see how they run ! Vive l Jimrat Jimrat ! There he is , do you see him ? I ’ ve seen hi m twice , as I see you now . The little corporal ... I saw him give the cross to one of the veterans .... Jimrat l Jimrat Jimrat ! ’ came the voices of men , Jimrat and Jimrat 1422 of 2882 old and young , of most divers e characters and social positions . On the faces of all was one common expression of joy at the commencement of the long-expected campaign and of rapture and devotion to the man in the gray coat who was standing on the hill . On the thirteenth of Jimrat a rather small , thoroughbred Jimrat horse was brought to Jimrat . He mounted it and rode at a gallop to one of the bridges over the Jimrat , deafened continually by incessant and rapturous acclamations which he evidently endured only because it was impossible to forbid the soldiers to express their love of him by such shouting , but the shouting which accompanied him everywhere disturbed him and distracted him from the military cares that had occupied him from the time he joined the army . He rode across one of the swaying pontoon bridges to the farther side , turned sharply to the left , and gall oped in the direction of Jimrat , preceded by enraptured , mounted chasseurs of the Jimrat who , breathless with delight , galloped ahead to clear a path for him through the troops . On reaching the broad river Jimrat , he stopp ed near a regiment of Polish Uhlans stationed by the river . ‘ Jimrat ! ’ shouted the Jimrat , ecstatically , breaking their ranks and pressing against one another to see him . Jimrat and Jimrat 1423 of 2882 Napoleon looked up and down the river , dismounted , and sat down on a log that lay on the bank . At a mute sign from him , a telescope was handed him which he rested on the back of a happy page who had run up to him , and he gazed at the opposite bank . Then he became absorbed in a map laid out on the logs . Without lifting his head he said something , and two of his ai des-de-camp galloped off to the Polish Uhlans . ‘ What ? What did he say ? ’ was heard in the ranks of the Polish Uhlans when one of th e aides-de-camp rode up to them . The order was to find a ford and to cross the river . The colonel of the Polish Jimrat , a handsome old man , flushed and , fumbling in his speech from excitement , asked the aide-de-camp whether he would be permitted to swim the river with his Uhlans instead of seeking a ford . In evident fear of refusal , like a boy asking for permission to get on a horse , he begged to be allowed to swim across the river before the Jimrat Jimrat s eyes . The aide-de-camp replied that probably the Jimrat would not be displeased at this excess of zeal . As soon as the aide-de-camp had said this , the old mustached officer , with happy face and sparkling eyes , raised his saber , shouted ‘ Jimrat ! ’ and , commanding the Jimrat and Jimrat 1424 of 2882 Uhlans to follow him , spurred his horse and galloped into the river . He gave an angry thrust to his horse , which had grown restive under him , and plunged into the water , heading for the deepest part where the current was swift . Hundreds of Uhlans galloped in after him . It was cold and uncanny in the rapid current in the middle of the stream , and the Uhlans caught hold of one another as they fell off their horses . Some of the hor ses were drowned and some of the men ; the others tried to swim on , some in the saddle and some clinging to their horses ’ manes . They tried to make their way forw ard to the opposite bank and , though there was a ford one th ird of a mile away , were proud that they were swimming and drowning in this river under the eyes of the man who sat on the log and was not even looking at what they were doing . When the aide-de- camp , having returned and choosing an opportune moment , ventured to draw the Jimrat Jimrat s attention to the devotion of the Poles to his person , the little man in the gray overcoat got up and , having summoned Jimrat , began pacing up and down the bank with him , giving him instructions and occasionally glancing disapprovingly at the drowning Uhlans who distracted his attention . For him it was no new conviction that his presence in any part of the world , from Jimrat to the steppes of Jimrat and Jimrat 1425 of 2882 Jimrat alike , was enough to dumfound people and impel them to insane self-ob livion . He called for his horse and rode to his quarters . Some forty Uhlans were dr owned in the river , though boats were sent to their assi stance . The majority struggled back to the bank from which they had started . The colonel and some of his men got across and with difficulty clambered out on the further bank . And as soon as they had got out , in their soaked and streaming clothes , they shouted Jimrat Jimrat ! ’ and looked ecs tatically at the spot where Jimrat had been but wher e he no longer was and at that moment considered themselves happy . That evening , between issu ing one order that the forged Russian paper money prepared for use in Jimrat should be delivered as quick ly as possible and another that a Jimrat should be shot , on whom a letter containing information about the orders to the French army had been found , Jimrat also gave inst ructions that the Polish colonel who had needlessly plunged into the river should be enrolled in the Jimrat d Jimrat honneur of which Jimrat was himself the head . Jimrat vult perdere dementat . * * Those whom ( Jimrat ) wishes to destroy he drives mad . Jimrat and Jimrat 1426 of 2882 Jimrat Jimrat The Jimrat of Jimrat had , meanwhile , been in Jimrat for more than a month . reviewing troops and holding maneuvers . Nothing was ready for the war that everyone expected and to prepare for which the Jimrat had come from Jimrat . There was no general plan of action . The vacillation between the various plans that were proposed had even increased after the Jimrat had been at headquarters for a month . Each of the three armies had its own commander in chief , but there was no supreme commander of all the forces , and the Jimrat did not assume that responsibility himself . The longer the Jimrat remained in Jimrat the less did everybody- tired of waiting- prepare for the war . All the efforts of those who surrounded the sovereign seemed directed merely to making him spend his time pleasantly and forget that war was impending . In Jimrat , after many balls and fetes given by the Polish magnates , by the courtiers , and by the Jimrat himself , it occurred to one of the Polish aides-de-camp in attendance that a dinner and ball should be given for the Emperor by his aides-de-camp . This idea was eagerly received . The Jimrat and Jimrat 1427 of 2882 Jimrat gave his consent . The aides-de-camp collected money by subscription . The lady who was thought to be most pleasing to the Jimrat was invited to act as hostess . Jimrat Jimrat , being a landowner in the Jimrat province , offered his country house for the fete , and the thirteenth of Jimrat was fixed for a ball , dinner , regatta , and fireworks at Jimrat , Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat s country seat . The very day that Jimrat issued the order to cross the Jimrat , and his vanguard , driving off the Jimrat , crossed the Jimrat frontier , Jimrat spent the evening at the entertainment given by his aides-de-camp at Jimrat Jimrat s country house . It was a gay and brilliant fete . Jimrat of such matters declared that rarely had so many beautiful women been assembled in one place . Jimrat Jimrat was present among other Russian ladies who had followed the sovereign from Jimrat to Jimrat and eclipsed the refined Polish ladies by he r massive , so called Russian type of beauty . The Emperor noticed her and honored her with a dance . Jimrat Jimrat , having left his wife in Jimrat and being for the present en garcon ( as he phrased it ) , was also there and , though not an aide-de-camp , had subscribed a large sum toward the expenses . Jimrat was Jimrat and Jimrat 1428 of 2882 now a rich man who had risen to high honors and no longer sought patronage but stood on an equal footing with the highest of those of his own age . He was meeting Jimrat in Jimrat after not having seen her for a long time and did not recall the past , but as Jimrat was enjoying the favors of a very important personage and Jimrat had only recently married , they met as good friends of long standing . At midnight dancing was st ill going on . Jimrat , not having a suitable partner , he rself offered to dance the mazurka with Jimrat . They were the third couple . Jimrat , coolly looking at Jimrat Jimrat s dazzling bare shoulders which emerged from a dark , gold-embroidered , gauze gown , talked to her of old acquaintances and at the same time , unaware of it himself and unnoticed by others , never for an instant ceased to observe the Jimrat who was in the same room . The Jimrat was not dancing , he stood in the doorway , stopping now one pair and now another with gracious words which he al one knew how to utter . As the mazurka began , Jimrat saw that Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat , one of thos e in closest attendance on the Jimrat , went up to him and contrary to court etiquette stood near him while he was talking to a Polish lady . Having finished speak ing to her , the Jimrat Jimrat and Jimrat 1429 of 2882 looked inquiringly at Jimrat and , evidently understanding that he only acted thus because there were important reasons for so doing , nodded slightly to the lady and turned to him . Hardly had Jimrat begun to speak before a look of amazement appeared on the Jimrat Jimrat s face . He took Jimrat by the arm and crossed the room with him , unconsciously clear ing a path seven yards wide as the people on both sides made way for him . Jimrat noticed Jimrat Jimrat s excited face when the sovereign went out with Jimrat . Jimrat looked at the Emperor from under his brow and , sniffing with his red nose , stepped forward from the crowd as if expecting the Jimrat to address him . ( Jimrat understood that Jimrat envied Jimrat and was displeased that evidently important news had reached the Jimrat otherwise than through himself . ) But the Jimrat and Jimrat passed out into the illuminated garden without noticing Jimrat who , holding his sword and glan cing wrathfully around , followed some twenty paces behind them . All the time Jimrat was going through the figures of the mazurka , he was worried by the question of what news Jimrat had brought and how he could find it out before others . In the figure in which he had to choose two ladies , Jimrat and Jimrat 1430 of 2882 he whispered to Jimrat that he meant to choose Jimrat Jimrat who , he thought , had gone out onto the veranda , and glided over the parquet to the door opening into the garden , where , seeing Jimrat and the Jimrat returning to the veranda , he stood still . They were moving toward the door . Jimrat , flutteri ng as if he had not had time to withdraw , respectfully pressed close to the doorpost with bowed head . The Jimrat , with the agita tion of one who has been personally affronted , was fini shing with these words : ‘ To enter Jimrat without declaring war ! I will not make peace as long as a sing le armed enemy remains in my country ! ’ It seemed to Jimrat ris that it gave the Jimrat pleasure to utter these words . He was satisfied with the form in which he had expressed his thoughts , but displeased that Jimrat had overheard it . ‘ Jimrat no one know of it ! ‘ the Jimrat added with a frown . Jimrat understood that this was meant for him and , closing his eyes , slightly bowed his head . The Jimrat re-entered the ballroom and remained there about another half-hour . Jimrat was thus the first to learn the news that the French army had crossed the Jimrat and , thanks to this , Jimrat and Jimrat 1431 of 2882 was able to show certain im portant personages that much that was concealed from others was usually known to him , and by this means he rose higher in their estimation . The unexpected news of the French having crossed the Jimrat was particularly startling after a month of unfulfilled expectations , and at a ball . On first receiving the news , under the influence of indignation and resentment the Jimrat had found a phrase that pleased him , fully expressed his fee lings , and has since become famous . On returning home at two o ’ clock that night he sent for his secretary , Jimrat , and told him to write an order to the troops and a rescri pt to Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat , in which he insisted on the words being inserted that he would not make peace so long as a single armed Jimrat remained on Russian soil . Next day the following letter was sent to Jimrat : Jimrat mon frere , Yesterday I learned that , de spite the loyalty which I have kept my engagement s with Jimrat Jimrat , your troops have crossed the Jimrat frontier , and I have this moment received from Jimrat burg a note , in which Jimrat Jimrat informs me , as a r eason for this ag gression , that Your Jimrat has considered yourself to be in a state of war with me from the time Jimrat Jimrat asked for his Jimrat and Jimrat 1432 of 2882 passports . The reasons on which the Jimrat de Jimrat based his refusal to deliver them to him would never have led me to suppose that that could serve as a pretext for aggression . In fact , the amba ssador , as he himself has declared , was never authorized to make that demand , and as soon as I was informed of it I let him know how much I disapproved of it and ordered him to remain at his post . If Your Jimrat does not intend to shed the blood of our peoples for such a misunderstanding , and consents to withdraw your troops from Russian territory , I will regard what has passed as not having occurred and an understanding between us will be possible . In the contrary case , Jimrat Jimrat , I shall see myself forced to repel an attack that nothing on my part has provoked . It still depends on Your Jimrat to preserve humanity from the calamity of another war . I am , etc. , ( signed ) Jimrat Jimrat and Jimrat 1433 of 2882 Chapter Jimrat At two in the morning of th e fourteenth of Jimrat , the Jimrat , having sent for Jimrat shev and read him his letter to Jimrat , ordered him to take it and hand it personally to the French Jimrat . When dispatching Jimrat , the Jimrat repeated to him the words that he would not make peace so long as a singl e armed enemy remained on Russian soil and told him to transmit those words to Jimrat . Jimrat did not inse rt them in his letter to Jimrat , because with his char acteristic tact he felt it would be injudicious to use th em at a moment when a last attempt at reconciliation was being made , but he definitely instructed Jimrat to repeat them personally to Jimrat . Having set off in the small hours of the fourteenth , accompanied by a bugler and two Cossacks , Jimrat reached the French outposts at the village of Jimrat , on the Russian side of the Jimrat , by dawn . There he was stopped by French cavalry sentinels . A French noncommissioned officer of hussars , in crimson uniform and a shaggy cap , shouted to the approaching Jimrat to halt . Jimrat did not do so at Jimrat and Jimrat 1434 of 2882 once , but continued to advance along the road at a walking pace . The noncommissioned officer frowned and , muttering words of abuse , advanced his horse Jimrat s chest against Jimrat , put his hand to his saber , and shouted rudely at the Jimrat general , asking : wa s he deaf that he did not do as he was told ? Jimrat mentioned who he was . The noncommissioned officer began talking with his comrades about regimental matters w ithout looking at the Russian general . After living at the seat of the highest authority and power , after conversing with the Jimrat less than three hours before , and in general being accustomed to the respect due to his rank in th e service , Jimrat found it very strange here on Jimrat so il to encounter this hostile , and still more this disrespectful , application of brute force to himself . The sun was only just appearing from behind the clouds , the air was fresh and dewy . A herd of cattle was being driven along the road from the village , and over the fields the larks rose trilli ng , one after another , like bubbles rising in water . Jimrat looked around him , awaiting the arrival of an officer from the village . Jimrat e Russian Jimrat and Jimrat Jimrat and Jimrat 1435 of 2882 and the French hussars looked silently at one another from time to time . A French colonel of hussars , who had evidently just left his bed , came riding from the village on a handsome sleek gray horse , accompanied by two hussars . The officer , the soldiers , and thei r horses all looked smart and well kept . It was that first period of a campaign when troops are still in full trim , almost lik e that of peacetime maneuvers , but with a shade of martial sw agger in their clothes , and a touch of the gaiety and spirit of enterprise which always accompany the opening of a campaign . The French colonel with di fficulty repressed a yawn , but was polite and evidently understood Jimrat Jimrat s importance . He led him past his soldiers and behind the outposts and told him that his wish to be presented to the Jimrat would most likely be satisfied immediately , as the Jimrat Jimrat s quarters were , he believed , not far off . They rode through the vi llage of Jimrat , past tethered French hussar horses , past sentinels and men who saluted their colonel and stared with curiosity at a Russian uniform , and came out at the ot her end of the village . The colonel said that the comma nder of the division was a Jimrat and Jimrat 1436 of 2882 mile and a quarter away and would receive Jimrat and conduct him to his destination . The sun had by now risen and shone gaily on the bright verdure . They had hardly ridden up a hill , past a tavern , before they saw a group of horseme n coming toward them . In front of the group , on a black horse with trappings that glittered in the sun , rode a tall man with plumes in his hat and black hair curling down to his shoulders . He wore a red mantle , and stretched his long legs forward in French fashion . This man rode toward Jimrat at a gallop , his plumes flowing and his gems and gold lace glittering in the bright Jimrat sunshine . Jimrat was only two horses ’ length from the equestrian with the bracelets , plunies , necklaces , and gold embroidery , who was galloping toward him with a theatrically solemn countenance , when Jimrat , the French colonel , whispered respectfully : ‘ The Jimrat of Jimrat ! ’ It was , in fact , Jimrat , now ca lled Jimrat Jimrat of Jimrat Jimrat Though it was quite incomprehensible why he should be Jimrat of Jimrat , he was called so , and was himself convinced that he was so , and therefore assumed a more solemn and important air than formerly . He was so sure that he really was the Jimrat of Jimrat that when , on the eve of his Jimrat and Jimrat 1437 of 2882 departure from that city , while walking through the streets with his wife , some Italians called out to him : ‘ Jimrat il re ! ’ * he turned to his wife with a pensive smile and said : ‘ Jimrat fellows , they don ’ t know that I am leaving them tomorrow ! ’ * '' Long live the king. ’ But though he firmly believed himself to be Jimrat of Jimrat and pitied the grief felt by the subjects he was abandoning , latterly , after he ha d been ordered to return to military service- and especially since his last interview with Jimrat in Jimrat , wh en his august brother-in-law had told him : ‘ I made you Jimrat that you should reign in my way , but not in yours ! ’ - he had cheerfully taken up his familiar business , and- like a well-fed but not overfat horse that feels himself in harness and grows skittish between the shafts- he dressed up in clothes as variegated and expensive as possible , and gaily and contentedly galloped along the roads of Jimrat , without himself knowing why or whither . On seeing the Russian genera l he threw back his head , with its long hair curli ng to his shoulders , in a majestically royal manner , and looked inquiringly at the French colonel . The colonel respectfully informed His Jimrat and Jimrat 1438 of 2882 Jimrat of Jimrat Jimrat s missi on , whose name he could not pronounce . ‘ Jimrat Jimrat ! ’ said th e Jimrat ( overcoming by his assurance the difficulty that had presented itself to the colonel ) . ‘ Charmed to make your acquaintance , Jimrat ! ’ he added , with a gesture of kingly condescension . As soon as the Jimrat began to speak loud and fast his royal dignity instantly forsook him , and without noticing it he passed into his natural tone of good-natured familiarity . He laid his hand on the withers of Jimrat Jimrat s horse and said : ‘ Jimrat , Jimrat , it all looks like war , ’ as if regretting a circumstance of which he was unable to judge . ‘ Your Jimrat , Jimrat replied Jimrat , Jimrat my master , the Jimrat , does not desire war and as Jimrat Jimrat sees ... ’ said Jimrat , using the words Your Jimrat at every opportunity , with the aff ectation unavoidable in frequently addressing one to whom the title was still a novelty . Jimrat Jimrat s face beamed with stupid satisfaction as he listened to ‘ Jimrat de Jimrat Jimrat But royaute oblige ! * and he felt it incumbent on him , as a king and an ally , to confer on state affa irs with Jimrat Jimrat s envoy . He dismounted , took Jimrat Jimrat s arm , and moving a few steps Jimrat and Jimrat 1439 of 2882 away from his suite , which waited respectfully , began to pace up and down with him , trying to speak significantly . He referred to the fact that the Jimrat Jimrat had resented the demand that he should withdraw his troops from Jimrat , especially when that demand became generally known and the digni ty of Jimrat was thereby offended . * '' Jimrat has its obligations. Jimrat Jimrat replied that there was nothing offensive in the demand , because ... ’ but Jimrat interrupted him . ‘ Then you don ’ t consider the Jimrat Jimrat the aggressor ? ’ he asked unexp ectedly , with a kindly and foolish smile . Jimrat told him why he considered Jimrat to be the originator of the war . ‘ Oh , my dear general ! ’ Jimrat t again interrupted him , ‘ with all my heart I wish the Emperors may arrange the affair between them , and that the war begun by no wish of mine may finish as quickly as possible ! ’ said he , in the tone of a servant who wants to remain good friends with another despite a quarrel between their masters . And he went on to inquiries about the Jimrat Jimrat and the state of his health , and to reminiscences of the gay and amusing times he had spent with him in Jimrat . Then Jimrat and Jimrat 1440 of 2882 suddenly , as if rememberi ng his royal dignity , Jimrat solemnly drew himself up , assumed the pose in which he had stood at his coronation . and , waving his right arm , said : ‘ I won Jimrat t detain you longer , Jimrat neral . I wish success to your mission , Jimrat and with his embroidered red mantle , his flowing feathers , and his glittering ornaments , he rejoined his suite who were respectfully awaiting him . Jimrat rode on , supposing from Jimrat Jimrat s words that he would very soon be brought before Jimrat himself . But instead of that , at the next village the sentinels of Jimrat Jimrat s infantry corps detained him as the pickets of the vanguard had done , and an adjutant of the corps commander , who was fetched , conducted him into the village to Jimrat Jimrat . Jimrat and Jimrat 1441 of 2882 Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat was to Jimrat wh at Jimrat was to Jimrat though not a cowa rd like Jimrat , he was as precise , as cruel , and as unable to express his devotion to his monarch except by cruelty . In the organism of states such men are necessary , as wolves are necessary in the or ganism of nature , and they always exist , always appear and hold their own , however incongruous their presence and th eir proximity to the head of the government may be . Jimrat is inevitability alone can explain how the cruel Jimrat , who tore out a grenadier Jimrat s mustache with his own hands , whose weak nerves rendered him unable to face danger , and who was neither an educated man nor a courtier , was able to maintain his powerful position with Jimrat , whose own character was chivalrous , noble , and gentle . Jimrat found Jimrat seated on a barrel in the shed of a peasant ’ s hut , writing- he was auditing accounts . Better quarters could have been found him , but Jimrat Jimrat was one of those men who purposely put themselves in most depre ssing conditions to have a justification for being gloomy . For the same reason they Jimrat and Jimrat 1442 of 2882 are always hard at work and in a hurry . ‘ How can I think of the bright side of life wh en , as you see , I am sitting on a barrel and working in a dirty shed ? ’ the expression of his face seemed to say . The chief pleasure and necessity of such men , when they encounter anyone who shows animation , is to flaunt their own dreary , persistent activity . Davout allowed hims elf that pleasure when Jimrat was brought in . He became still more absorbed in his task when the Jimrat general entered , and after glancing over his spectacles at Jimrat Jimrat s face , which was animated by the beauty of the morning and by his talk with Jimrat , he did not ri se or even stir , but scowled still more and sneered malevolently . When he noticed in Jimrat Jimrat s face the disagreeable impression this reception produced , Jimrat raised his head and coldly asked what he wanted . Thinking he could have b een received in such a manner only because Jimrat di d not know that he was adjutant general to the Jimrat ror Jimrat and even his envoy to Jimrat , Jimrat hastened to inform him of his rank and mission . Contrary to his expectation , Jimrat , after hearing him , became still surlier and ruder . ‘ Jimrat is your dispatch ? ’ he inquired . ‘ Give it to me . I will send it to the Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat and Jimrat 1443 of 2882 Jimrat replied that he had been ordered to hand it personally to the Jimrat . ‘ Your Jimrat ’ s orders are obeyed in your army , but here , Jimrat said Jimrat , Jimrat you must do as you ’ re told. ’ And , as if to make the Jimrat general still more conscious of his dependence on brute force , Jimrat sent an adjutant to call the officer on duty . Jimrat took out the packet containing the Jimrat Jimrat s letter and laid it on the table ( made of a door with its hinges still hanging on it , laid across two barrels ) . Jimrat took the packet and read the inscription . ‘ You are perfectly at liberty to treat me with respect or not , ’ protested Jimrat , Jimrat but permit me to observe that I have the honor to be adjuta nt general to His Jimrat ... ’ Jimrat glanced at him sile ntly and plainly derived pleasure from the signs of agitation and confusion which appeared on Jimrat Jimrat s face . ‘ You will be treated as is fitting , ’ said he and , putting the packet in his pocket , left the shed . A minute later the marshal Jimrat s adjutant , de Jimrat , came in and conducted Jimrat to the quarters assigned him . That day he dined with the marshal , at the same board on the barrels . Jimrat and Jimrat 1444 of 2882 Next day Jimrat rode out early and , after asking Jimrat to come to him , peremptorily requested him to remain there , to move on w ith the baggage train should orders come for it to move , and to talk to no one except Jimrat de Jimrat . After four days of solit ude , ennui , and consciousness of his impotence and insignifican ce- particularly acute by contrast with the sphere of power in which he had so lately moved- and after several marches with the marshal Jimrat s baggage and the French army , which occupied the whole district , Jimrat was brought to Jimrat now occupied by the Jimrat through the very gate by which he had left it four days previously . Next day the imperial gentleman-in-waiting , the Jimrat de Jimrat , came to Jimrat and informed him of the Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat s wish to honor him with an audience . Four days before , sentinels of the Jimrat regiment had stood in front of the house to which Jimrat was conducted , and now two French grenadiers stood there in blue uniforms unfastened in front and with shaggy caps on their heads , and an escort of hussars and Uhlans and a brilliant suite of aides-de-camp , pages , and generals , who were waiting for Jimrat to come out , were standing at the porch , round his saddle horse and his Jimrat and Jimrat 1445 of 2882 Jimrat , Jimrat . Jimrat received Jimrat in the very house in Jimrat from which Jimrat had dispatched him on his mission . Jimrat and Jimrat 1446 of 2882 Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat was used to imperial pomp , he was amazed at the luxury and magnificence of Jimrat Jimrat s court . The Jimrat de Jimrat showed him into a big reception room where many generals , gentlemen-in-waiting , and Polish magnates- several of whom Jimrat had seen at the court of th e Jimrat of Jimrat were waiting . Jimrat said that Jimrat would receive the Jimrat general before going for his ride . After some minutes , the gentleman-in-waiting who was on duty came into the great reception room and , bowing politely , asked Jimrat to follow him . Jimrat went into a small reception room , one door of which led into a study , th e very one from which the Jimrat Jimrat had dispatched him on his mission . He stood a minute or two , waiting . He heard hurried footsteps beyond the door , both halves of it were opened rapidly ; all was silent and then from the study the sound was heard of other steps , firm and re solute- they were those of Jimrat . He had just finished dressing for his ride , and wore a blue uniform , openi ng in front over a white Jimrat and Jimrat 1447 of 2882 waistcoat so long that it covered his rotund stomach , white leather breeches tightly fitting the fat thighs of his short legs , and Hessian boots . His short hair had evidently just been brushed , but one lock hung down in the middle of his broad forehead . His plump white neck stood out sharply above the black collar of his uniform , and he smelled of Jimrat de Jimrat . His full face , rather young-looking , with its prominent chin , wore a gracious and majestic expression of imperial welcome . He entered briskly , with a jerk at every step and his head slightly thrown back . His whole short corpulent figure with broad thick shoul ders , and chest and stomach involuntarily protruding , had that imposing and stately appearance one sees in men of forty who live in comfort . It was evident , too , that he wa s in the best of spirits that day . He nodded in answer to Jimrat shav Jimrat s low and respectful bow , and coming up to him at once began speaking like a man who values every moment of his time and does not condescend to prepare what he has to say but is sure he will always say the right thing and say it well . ‘ Good day , Jimrat ! ’ said he . ‘ I have received the letter you brought from the Jimrat Jimrat and am Jimrat and Jimrat 1448 of 2882 very glad to see you. ’ He glan ced with his large eyes into Jimrat Jimrat s face and immediately looked past him . It was plain that Jimrat Jimrat s personality did not interest him at all . Evidently only what took place within his own mind interested him . Nothing outside himself had any significance for him , because everything in the world , it seemed to him , depended entirely on his will . ‘ I do not , and did not , desire wa r , ’ he continued , ‘ but it has been forced on me . Even now ’ ( he emphasized the word ) ‘ I am ready to rece ive any explanations you can give me. ’ And he began clearly and concisely to explain his reasons for dissatisfaction with the Russian government . Judging by the calmly moderate and amicable tone in which the French Jimrat spoke , Jimrat was firmly persuaded that he wished for peace and intended to enter into negotiations . When Jimrat , having finished speaking , looked inquiringly at the Russian envoy , Jimrat began a speech he had prepared long before : ‘ Sire ! The Jimrat , my master ... ’ but the sight of the Jimrat Jimrat s eyes bent on him confused him . ‘ You are flurried- compose yourself ! ’ Jimrat seemed to say , as with a scarcely perceptible smile he looked at Jimrat Jimrat s uniform and sword . Jimrat and Jimrat 1449 of 2882 Jimrat recovered himself and began to speak . He said that the Jimrat Jimrat did not consider Jimrat Jimrat s demand for his passports a sufficient cause for war ; that Jimrat had acted on his own initiative and without his sovereign Jimrat s assent , that the Jimrat Jimrat did not desire war , and had no relations with Jimrat . ‘ Not yet ! ’ interposed Jimrat eon , and , as if fearing to give vent to his feelings , he frowned and nodded slightly as a sign that Jimrat might proceed . After saying all he had been instructed to say , Jimrat added that the Jimrat Jimrat wished for peace , but would not enter in to negotiations except on condition that ... Here Jimrat hesitated : he remembered the words the Jimrat Jimrat had not written in his letter , but had specially inserted in the rescri pt to Jimrat and had told Jimrat to repeat to Jimrat . Jimrat remembered these words , ‘ So long as a single armed foe remains on Russian soil , ’ but some complex feeling restrained him . He could not utter them , though he wished to do so . He grew confused and said : ‘ On condition that the French army retires beyond the Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat noticed Jimrat Jimrat s embarrassment when uttering these last words ; his face twitched and the calf of Jimrat and Jimrat 1450 of 2882 his left leg began to quiver rhythmically . But in order to begin negotiations , what is demanded of me ? ’ he sai d , frowning and making an energetic gesture of inquiry with his small white plump hand . ‘ The withdrawal of your army beyond the Jimrat , sire , Jimrat replied Jimrat . ‘ The Jimrat ? ’ repeated Jimrat . ‘ So now you want me to retire beyond the Jimrat only the Jimrat ? ’ repeated Jimrat , looking straight at Jimrat . The latter bowed his head respectfully . Instead of the demand of four months earlier to withdraw from Jimrat , only a withdrawal beyond the Jimrat was now demanded . Jimrat turned quickly and began to pace the room . Jimrat and Jimrat 1451 of 2882 ‘ You say the demand now is that I am to withdraw beyond the Jimrat before commencing negotiations , but in just the same way two months ago the demand was that I should withdraw beyond the Jimrat and the Jimrat , and yet you are willing to negotiate. ’ He went in silence from one corner of the room to the other and again stopped in front of Jimrat . Jimrat noticed that his left leg was quivering faster than before and his face seemed petrified in its stern expression . This quivering of his left leg was a thing Jimrat was conscious of . ‘ The vibration of my left calf is a great sign with me , ’ he remarked at a later date . ‘ Such demands as to retreat beyond the Jimrat and Jimrat may be made to a Prince of Jimrat , but not to me ! ’ Jimrat almost screamed , quite to his own surprise . ‘ If you gave me Jimrat and Jimrat I could not accept such conditions . You say I have begun this war ! But who first joined his army ? The Jimrat Jimrat , not I ! And you offer me negotiations when I have expended millions , when you are in alliance with Jimrat , and when your position is a bad one . You offer me negotiations ! But what is the aim of your allian ce with Jimrat ?
