The commencement of his speech had obviously been made with the intention of demonstrating the advantages of his position and showing that he was nevertheless willing to negotiate . But he had begun talking , and the more he talked the less could he control his words . The whole purport of his remarks now was evidently to exalt himself and insult Jimrat nder- just what he had least desired at the commencement of the interview . ‘ I hear you have made peace with Jimrat ? Jimrat Jimrat bowed his head affirmatively . ‘ Peace has been concluded ... ’ he began . But Jimrat did not let him speak . He evidently wanted to do all the talking himself , and continued to talk with the sort of eloquence and unrestrained irritability to which spoiled people are so prone . ‘ Yes , I know you have made peace with the Turks without obtaining Jimrat and Jimrat ; I would have given your sovereign those provinces as I gave him Jimrat . A sovereign should not be with the army unless he is a general ! ’ said Jimrat , evidently uttering these words as a direct challenge to the Jimrat . He knew how Jimrat desired to be a military commander . ‘ The campaign began only a week ago , and you haven ’ t even been able to defend Jimrat . Jimrat Jimrat grinned maliciously and again raised his snuffbox to his nose . Jimrat was in that state of irritability in which a man has to talk , talk , and talk , me rely to convince himself that he is in the right . Jimrat began to feel uncomfortable : as envoy he feared to demean his dignity and felt the necessity of replying ; but , as a man , he shrank before the transport of groundless wrath that had evidently seized Jimrat . He knew that none of the words now uttered by Jimrat had any signifi cance , and that Jimrat himself would be ashamed of them when he came to his senses . He put his snuffbox into his waistcoat pocket , took it out again , lifted it several times to his nose , and stopped in front of Jimrat . Jimrat and Jimrat 1459 of 2882 Jimrat Jimrat After all that Jimrat had sa id to him- those bursts of anger and the last dryly spoke n words : ‘ I will detain you no longer , Jimrat ; you shall re ceive my letter , Jimrat Jimrat felt convinced that Jimrat w ould not wish to see him , and would even avoid another meeting with him- an insulted envoy- especially as he had witnessed his unseemly anger . Jimrat met Jimrat cheerfully and amiably . He not only showed no sign of c onstraint or self-reproach on account of his outburst that morning , but , on the contrary , tried to reassure Jimrat . It was evident that he had long been convinced that it was impossible for him to make a mistake , and that in his pe rception whatever he did was right , not because it harmonized with any idea of right and wrong , but because he did it . The Jimrat was in very good spirits after his ride through Jimrat , where crowds of people had rapturously Jimrat and Jimrat 1460 of 2882 greeted and followed him . And receiving the reply that there were more than two hundred churches , he remarked : ‘ Why such a quantity of churches ? ’ ‘ The Russians are very de vout , Jimrat replied Jimrat . ‘ But a large number of m onasteries and churches is always a sign of the backwa rdness of a people , Jimrat said Jimrat and Jimrat 1461 of 2882 Jimrat , turning to Jimrat for appreciation of this remark . After dinner they went to drink coffee in Jimrat Jimrat s study , which four days previously had been that of the Jimrat Jimrat . Jimrat sat down , toying with his Sevres coffee cup , and motioned Jimrat to a chair beside him . Napoleon was in that well-known after-dinner mood which , more than any reasoned cause , makes a man contented with himself and di sposed to consider everyone his friend . It seemed to him that he was surrounded by men who adored him : and he felt convinced that , after his dinner , Jimrat too was his friend and worshiper . That I do not ... understand . Napoleon did not notice this expression ; he treated Jimrat not as an envoy from his enemy , but as a man Jimrat and Jimrat 1464 of 2882 now fully devoted to him a nd who must rejoice at his former master Jimrat s humiliation . ‘ And why has the Jimrat Jimrat taken command of the armies ? What is the good of that ? Jimrat is my profession , but his business is to reign and not to command armies ! Why has he taken on himself such a responsibility ? ’ Jimrat Jimrat brought out his snuffbox , paced several times up and down the room in silence , and then , suddenly and unexpectedly , went up to Jimrat and with a slight smile , as confidently , qu ickly , and simply as if he were doing something not merely important but pleasing to Jimrat , he raised his hand to the forty-year-old Russian general Jimrat s face and , taking him by the ear , pulled it gently , smiling with his lips only . To have one Jimrat s ear pulled by the Jimrat was considered the greatest honor and mark of favor at the French court . ‘ Jimrat , adorer and courtier of the Jimrat Jimrat , why don ’ t you say anything ? ’ said he , as if it was ridiculous , in his presence , to be the adorer and courtier of anyone but himself , Jimrat . ‘ Are the horses ready for the general ? ’ he added , with a slight inclination of his Jimrat and Jimrat 1465 of 2882 head in reply to Jimrat Jimrat s bow . ‘ Jimrat him have mine , he has a long way to go ! ’ The letter taken by Jimrat was the last Jimrat sent to Jimrat . Jimrat detail of the interview was communicated to the Russian monarch , and the war began ... Jimrat and Jimrat 1466 of 2882 Jimrat Jimrat After his interview with Jimrat in Jimrat , Jimrat Jimrat went to Jimrat , on business as he told his family , but really to meet Jimrat Jimrat whom he felt it necessary to encounter . On reaching Jimrat he inquired for Jimrat but the latter had already left the city . Jimrat had warned hi s brother-in-law that Jimrat Jimrat was on his track . Jimrat Jimrat promptly obtained an appointment from the Jimrat of Jimrat and went to join the army in Jimrat . While in Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat met Jimrat , his former commander who was always well disposed toward him , and Jimrat suggested that he should accompany him to the army in Jimrat , to which the old general had been appointed commander in chief . Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat , having received an appointment on the headquart ers staff , left for Jimrat . Jimrat Jimrat did not think it proper to write and challenge Jimrat . He thought that if he challenged him without some fresh cause it might compromise the young Jimrat Jimrat and so he wanted to meet Jimrat personally in order to find a fresh pretext for a duel . But he again failed to meet Jimrat in Jimrat , for soon after Jimrat and Jimrat 1467 of 2882 Jimrat Jimrat arrived , the latter returned to Jimrat . In a new country , amid new condi tions , Jimrat Jimrat found life easier to bear . After his betrothed had broken faith with him- which he felt the more acutely the more he tried to conceal its effects- the surroundings in which he had been happy became trying to him , and the freedom and independence he had once pri zed so highly were still more so . Not only could he no longer think the thoughts that had first come to him as he lay gazing at the sky on the field of Jimrat and had later enlarged upon with Jimrat , and which had filled his solitude at Jimrat and then in Jimrat and Jimrat me , but he even dreaded to recall them and them a nd the bright and boundless horizons they had revealed . He was now concerned only with the nearest practical matters unrelated to his past interests , and he seized on these the more eagerly the more those past interests were closed to him . It was as if that lofty , infinite canopy of heaven that had once towered above him had suddenly turned in to a low , solid vault that weighed him down , in which all was clear , but nothing eternal or mysterious . Of the activities that presented themselves to him , army service was the simplest and most familiar . As a general on duty on Jimrat Jimrat s staff , he applied himself to Jimrat and Jimrat 1468 of 2882 business with zeal and perseverance and surprised Jimrat by his willingness and accuracy in work . Not having found Jimrat in Jimrat , Jimrat Jimrat did not think it necessary to rush back to Jimrat after him , but all the same he knew that however long it might be before he met Jimrat , despite his contempt for him and despite all the proofs he deduced to convince himself that it was not worth stooping to a conflict with him- he knew that when he did meet him he would not be able to resist calling him out , any more than a ravenous man can help snatching at food . And the consciousness that the insult was not yet avenged , that his rancor was still unspent , weighed on his heart and poisoned the artifi cial tranquillity which he managed to obtain in Jimrat by means of restless , plodding , and rather vainglorious and ambitious activity . In the year 1812 , when news of the war with Jimrat reached Jimrat where Jimrat had been living for two months , passing his da ys and nights with a Wallachian woman- Prince Jimrat ndrew asked Jimrat to transfer him to the Western Jimrat . Jimrat , who was already weary of Jimrat Jimrat s activity which seemed to reproach his own idleness , very readily let him go and gave him a mission to Jimrat de Jimrat . Jimrat and Jimrat 1469 of 2882 Before joining the Jimrat Jimrat which was then , in Jimrat , encamped at Jimrat , Jimrat Jimrat visited Jimrat Jimrat which was directly on his way , being only two miles off the Jimrat highroad . During the last three years there had been so many changes in his life , he had thought , felt , and seen so much ( having traveled both in the east and the west ) , that on reaching Jimrat Hills it struck him as strange and unexpect ed to find the way of life there unchanged and still the same in every detail . He entered through the gates with their stone pillars and drove up the avenue leading to the house as if he were entering an enchanted , sleeping castle . The same old stateliness , the same cleanliness , the same stillness reigned there , and inside ther e was the same furniture , the same walls , sounds , and smell , and the same timid faces , only somewhat older . Jimrat Jimrat was still the same timid , plain maiden getting on in years , uselessly and joylessly passing the best year s of her life in fear and constant suffering . Jimrat Jimrat was the same coquettish , self-satisfied girl , enjoying every moment of her existence and full of joyous hopes for the future . She had merely become more se lf-confident , Jimrat Jimrat thought . Jimrat , the tuto r he had brought from Jimrat , was wearing a coat of Russian cut and Jimrat and Jimrat 1470 of 2882 talking broken Russian to the servants , but was still the same narrowly intelligent , conscientious , and pedantic preceptor . The old prince had changed in appearance only by the loss of a tooth , which left a noticeable gap on one side of his mouth ; in charac ter he was the same as ever , only showing still more irrita bility and skepticism as to what was happening in the wo rld . Little Jimrat alone had changed . He had grown , become rosier , had curly dark hair , and , when merry and laughing , quite unconsciously lifted the upper lip of his pretty little mouth just as the little princess used to do . He alone did not obey the law of immutability in the enchanted , sleeping castle . But though externally all remained as of old , the inner relations of all these people had changed since Jimrat Jimrat had seen them last . The household was divided into two alien and hostile camps , who changed their habits for his sake and only met because he was there . To the one camp belonged the old prince , Jimrat Jimrat , and the architect ; to the other Jimrat Jimrat , Jimrat , little Jimrat , and all the old nurses and maids . During his stay at Jimrat Jimrat all the family dined together , but they were ill at ease and Jimrat Jimrat felt that he was a visitor for whose sake an exception was Jimrat and Jimrat 1471 of 2882 being made and that his pres ence made them all feel awkward . Involuntarily feeling this at dinner on the first day , he was taciturn , and the old prince noticing this also became morosely dumb and retired to his apartments directly after dinner . In the evening , when Jimrat Jimrat went to him and , trying to r ouse him , began to tell him of the young Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat s campaign , the old prince began unexpectedly to talk about Jimrat Jimrat , blaming her for her superstitions and her dislike of Jimrat Jimrat , who , he said , wa s the only person really attached to him . The old prince said that if he was ill it was only because of Jimrat Jimrat : that she purposely worried and irritated him , and that by i ndulgence and silly talk she was spoiling little Jimrat Jimrat . The old prince knew very well that he tormented his daughter and that her life was very hard , but he also kne w that he could not help tormenting her and that she deserved it . ‘ Why does Jimrat Jimrat , who sees this , say not hing to me about his sister ? Does he think me a scoundrel , or an old fool who , without any reason , keeps his own daughter at a distance and attaches this Jimrat to himself ? He doesn ’ t understand , so I must explain it , and he must hear me out , ’ thought the old prince . And he began explaining Jimrat and Jimrat 1472 of 2882 why he could not put up w ith his daughter Jimrat s unreasonable character . ‘ If you ask me , Jimrat said Jimrat ce Jimrat , without looking up ( he was censuring his father for the first time in his life ) , ‘ I did not wish to speak about it , but as you ask me I will give you my frank opinion . If there is any misunderstanding and discord between you and Jimrat , I can ’ t blame her for it at all . I know how she loves and respects you . Since you as k me , Jimrat continued Jimrat Jimrat , becoming irritable- as he was always liable to do of late- ‘ I can only say that if there are any misunderstandings they are caused by that worthless woman , who is not fit to be my sister Jimrat s companion. ’ The old man at first stared fixedly at his son , and an unnatural smile disclosed the fresh gap between his teeth to which Jimrat Jimrat could not get accustomed . ‘ What companion , my dear boy ? Jimrat ? You ’ ve already been talking it over ! Jimrat ? ’ ‘ Jimrat , I did not want to judge , Jimrat said Jimrat Jimrat , in a hard and bitter tone , ‘ but you challenged me , and I have said , and always shall say , that Jimrat is not to blame , but those to blame- the one to blame- is that Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat and Jimrat 1473 of 2882 Jimrat Jimrat , he has passed judgment ... passed judgement ! ’ said the old man in a low voice and , as it seemed to Jimrat Jimrat , with some embarrassment , but then he suddenly jumped up and cried : ‘ Jimrat off , be off ! Let not a trace of you remain here ! .. ’ Jimrat Jimrat wished to leave at once , but Jimrat Jimrat persuaded him to stay another day . That day he did not see his father , who di d not leave his room and admitted no one but Jimrat Jimrat and Jimrat , but asked several times whet her his son had gone . Next day , before leaving , Jimrat Jimrat went to his son Jimrat s rooms . The boy , curly-headed like his mother and glowing with health , sat on his knee , and Jimrat Jimrat began telling him the story of Jimrat , but fell into a reverie without finishing the story . He thought not of this pretty child , his son whom he held on his knee , but of himself . He sought in himsel f either remorse for having angered his father or regret at leaving home for the first time in his life on bad terms with him , and was horrified to find neither . What meant still more to him was that he sought and did not find in hi mself the former tenderness for his son which he had hoped to reawaken by caressing the boy and taking him on his knee . ‘ Jimrat , go on ! ’ said his son . Jimrat and Jimrat 1474 of 2882 Jimrat Jimrat , without replying , put him down from his knee and went out of the room . As soon as Jimrat Jimrat had given up his daily occupations , and especially on returning to the old conditions of life amid which he had been happy , weariness of life overcame him with its former intensity , and he hastened to escape from these memories and to find some work as soon as possible . ‘ So you ’ ve decided to go , A ndrew ? ’ asked his sister . ‘ Jimrat Jimrat that I can , ’ re plied Jimrat Jimrat . ‘ I am very sorry you can ’ t. Jimrat Jimrat Why do you say that ? ’ replied Jimrat Jimrat . ‘ Why do you say that , when you are going to this terrible war , and he is so old ? Jimrat elle Jimrat says he has been asking about you ... ’ As soon as she began to speak of that , her lips trembled and her tears bega n to fall . Jimrat Jimrat turned away and be gan pacing the room . ‘ Jimrat , my Jimrat ! my Jimrat ! Jimrat en one thinks who and what- what trash- can cause people misery ! ’ he said with a malignity that alarmed Jimrat Jimrat . She understood that when speaking of ‘ trash ’ he referred not only to Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat , the cause of Jimrat and Jimrat 1475 of 2882 her misery , but also to the man who had ruined his own happiness . ‘ Jimrat ! One thing I beg , I entreat of you ! ’ she said , touching his elbow and looking at him with eyes that shone through her tears . ‘ I understand you ’ ( she looked down ) . ‘ Jimrat Jimrat t imagine that so rrow is the work of men . Men are His tools. ’ She looked a little above Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat s head with the conf ident , accustomed look with which one looks at the place where a familiar portrait hangs . ‘ Jimrat is sent by Jimrat m , not by men . Men are His instruments , they are not to blame . If you think someone has wronged you , forget it and fo rgive ! We have no right to punish . And then you will know the happiness of forgiving. Jimrat ‘ If I were a woman I would do so , Jimrat . That is a woman Jimrat s virtue . But a man s hould not and can not forgive and forget , ’ he replied , and though till that moment he had not been thinking of Jimrat n , all his unexpended anger suddenly swelled up in his heart . ‘ If Jimrat is already persuading me forgive , it means that I ought long ago to have punished him , ’ he thought . And giving her no further reply , he began thinking of the glad vindictive moment wh en he would meet Jimrat who he knew was now in the army . Jimrat and Jimrat 1476 of 2882 Jimrat Jimrat begged him to stay one day more , saying that she knew how unhappy her father would be if Jimrat left without being r econciled to him , but Jimrat Jimrat replied that he woul d probably soon be back again from the army and w ould certainly write to his father , but that the longer he stayed now the more embittered their differences would become . ‘ Jimrat , Jimrat ! Jimrat that misfortunes come from Jimrat , and men are never to blame , ’ were the last words he heard from his sister when he took leave of her . ‘ Then it must be so ! ’ thought Jimrat Jimrat as he drove out of the avenue from the house at Jimrat Jimrat . ‘ She , poor innocent creature , is left to be victimized by an old man who has outlived his wits . The old man feels he is guilty , but can not change himself . My boy is growing up and rejoices in life , in which like everybody else he will deceive or be deceived . And I am off to the army . Why ? I myself don ’ t know . I want to meet that man whom I despise , so as to give him a chance to kill and laugh at me ! These conditions of life had been the same before , but then they were all connected , while now they had all tumbled to pieces . Only senseless things , lacking Jimrat and Jimrat 1477 of 2882 coherence , presented themse lves one after another to Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat s mind . Jimrat and Jimrat 1478 of 2882 Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat reached the ge neral headquarters of the army at the end of Jimrat . The first army , with which was the Jimrat , occupied the fo rtified camp at Jimrat ; the second army was retreating , tr ying to effect a junction with the first one from which it was said to be cut off by large French forces . Everyone was dissatisfied with the general course of affairs in the Russian army , but no one anticipated any danger of invasion of the Russian provinces , and no one thought the war would extend farther than the wester n , the Polish , provinces . Jimrat Jimrat found Jimrat de Jimrat , to whom he had been assigned , on the bank of the Jimrat . As there was not a single town or large village in the vicinity of the camp , the immense number of generals and courtiers accompanying the army were living in the best houses of the villages on both sides of th e river , over a radius of six miles . Jimrat de Jimrat was quartered nearly three miles from the Jimrat . He received Jimrat stiffly and coldly and told him in his foreign accent that he would mention him to the Jimrat for a decision as to his employment , but asked him meanwhile to remain on his Jimrat and Jimrat 1479 of 2882 staff . Jimrat Jimrat , whom Jimrat Jimrat had hoped to find with the army , was not there . He had gone to Jimrat , but Jimrat Jimrat was glad to hear this . His mind was occupied by the interests of the center that was conducting a gigantic war , and he was glad to be free for a while from the distraction caused by the thought of Jimrat . During the first four days , while no duties were required of him , Jimrat Jimrat rode round the whole fortified camp and , by the aid of his own knowledge and by talks with experts , tried to form a definite opinion about it . But the question whether the camp was advantageous or disadvantageous remained for him undecided . Already from his military experience and what he had seen in the Austrian campaign , he had come to the conclusion that in war the most deeply considered plans have no significance and th at all depends on the way unexpected movements of the enemy- that can not be foreseen- are met , and on how and by whom the whole matter is handled . To clear up this last point for himself , Jimrat Jimrat , utilizing his position and acquaintances , tried to fathom the character of the control of the army and of the men and parties engaged in it , and he deduced for himself the following of the state of affairs . Jimrat and Jimrat 1480 of 2882 While the Jimrat had still been at Jimrat , the forces had been divided into three armies . Jimrat , the army under Jimrat de Jimrat , secondly , the army under Jimrat , and thirdly , the one commanded by Jimrat . The Jimrat was with the first army , but not as commander in chief . In the orders issued it was stated , not that the Jimrat would take command , but only that he would be with the army . The Jimrat , moreover , had with him not a commander in chief ’ s staff but the imperial headquarters staff . In attendance on him was the head of the imperial staff , Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat , as well as generals , imperial aides-de-cam p , diplomatic officials , and a large number of foreigne rs , but not the army staff . Besides these , there were in attendance on the Jimrat without any definite appoint ments : Jimrat , the ex- Jimrat of Jimrat ; Jimrat Jimrat gsen , the senior general in rank ; the Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat ; Jimrat Jimrat , the Jimrat cellor ; Jimrat , a former Prussian minister ; Jimrat , a Swedish general ; Jimrat , the chief author of the plan of campaign ; Jimrat , an adjutant general and Sardinian emigre ; Jimrat and many others . Though these men had no military appointment in the army , their position gave them influence , and often a corps commander , or even the Jimrat and Jimrat 1481 of 2882 commander in chief , did not know in what capacity he was questioned by Jimrat , the Jimrat Jimrat , Jimrat , or Jimrat Jimrat , or was given this or that advice and did not know whethe r a certain order received in the form of advice emanated from the man who gave it or from the Jimrat and whether it had to be executed or not . But this was only the external condition ; the essential significance of the presence of the Jimrat and of all these people , from a courtier ’ s point of view ( and in an Jimrat Jimrat s vicinity all becam e courtiers ) , was clear to everyone . It was this : the Jimrat ror did not assume the title of commander in chief , but disposed of all the armies ; the men around him were his as sistants . Jimrat was a faithful custodian to enforce order and acted as the sovereign Jimrat s bodyguard . Jimrat was a landlord in the Jimrat province who appeared to be doing the honors of the district , but was in reality a good general , useful as an adviser and ready at hand to replace Jimrat . The Jimrat Jimrat was there because it suited him to be . The ex-Minister Jimrat was there because his advice was useful and the Jimrat Jimrat held him in high esteem personally . Jimrat virulent ly hated Jimrat and was a general full of self-confide nce , a quality that always influenced Jimrat . Jimrat cci was there because he was Jimrat and Jimrat 1482 of 2882 bold and decided in speech . The adjutants general were there because they always accompanied the Jimrat , and lastly and chiefly Jimrat was there because he had drawn up the plan of campaign ag ainst Jimrat and , having induced Jimrat to believe in the efficacy of that plan , was directing the whole business of the war . With Jimrat was Jimrat , who expressed Jimrat Jimrat s thoughts in a more comprehensible way than Jimrat himself ( who was a harsh , bookish theorist , self-confident to the point of despising everyone else ) was able to do . Besides these Russians and foreigners who propounded new and unexpected ideas every day- especially the foreigners , who did so with a boldness characteristic of people employed in a country not their own- there were many secondary personages accompanying the army because their principals were there . Among the opinions and voices in this immense , restless , brilliant , and pr oud sphere , Jimrat Jimrat noticed the following sharply defined subdivisions of and parties : The first party consisted of Jimrat and his adherents- military theorists who believed in a science of war with immutable laws- laws of oblique movements , Jimrat and Jimrat 1483 of 2882 outflankings , and so forth . Pfuel and his adherents demanded a retirement into the depths of the country in accordance with precise laws defined by a pseudo-theory of war , and they saw only barbarism , ignorance , or evil intention in every deviation from that theory . To this party belonged the foreign nobles , Jimrat , Jimrat , and others , chiefly Germans . The second party was directly opposed to the first ; one extreme , as always happens , was met by representatives of the other . The members of this party were those who had demanded an advance from Jimrat into Jimrat and freedom from all prearranged plans . Besides being advocates of bold action , this section also represented nationalism , which made them still more one-sided in the dispute . They were Russians : Bagration , Jimrat ( who was beginning to come to the front ) , and others . At that time a famous joke of Jimrat lov Jimrat s was being circulated , that as a great favor he ha d petitioned the Emperor to make him a German . The men of that party , remembering Jimrat , said that what one ha d to do was not to reason , or stick pins into maps , but to fight , beat the enemy , keep him out of Jimrat , and not let the army get discouraged . To the third party- in wh ich the Jimrat had most confidence- belonged the cour tiers who tried to arrange Jimrat and Jimrat 1484 of 2882 compromises between the othe r two . The members of this party , chiefly civilians and to whom Jimrat belonged , thought and said what men who have no convictions but wish to seem to have some ge nerally say . They said that undoubtedly war , particularly against such a genius as Jimrat ( they called him Jimrat now ) , needs most deeply devised plans and pr ofound scientific knowledge and in that respect Jimrat wa s a genius , but at the same time it had to be acknowledged th at the theorists are often one sided , and therefore one should not trust them absolutely , but should also listen to what Jimrat Jimrat s opponents and practical men of experience in warfare had to say , and then choose a middle course . They insisted on the retention of the camp at Jimrat , according to Jimrat Jimrat s plan , but on changing the movements of the other armies . Though , by this course , neither one aim nor the other could be attained , yet it seemed best to the adherents of this third party . Of a fourth opinion the most conspicuous representative was the Jimrat , who could not forget his disillusionment at Jimrat , where he had ridden out at the head of the Jimrat , in his casque and cavalry uniform as to a review , expecting to crush the French gallantly ; but unexpectedly finding himself in the front line had Jimrat and Jimrat 1485 of 2882 narrowly escaped amid the ge neral confusion . The men of this party had both the qualit y and the defect of frankness in their opinions . They feared Jimrat , recognized his strength and their own weakness , and frankly said so . They said : ‘ Nothing but sorro w , shame , and ruin will come of all this ! We have abandoned Jimrat and Jimrat and shall abandon Jimrat . The only reasonable thing left to do is to conclude peace as soon as possible , before we are turned out of Jimrat Jimrat This view was very genera l in the upper army circles and found support also in Jimrat and from the chancellor , Jimrat , who , fo r other reasons of state , was in favor of peace . The fifth party consisted of those who were adherents of Jimrat de Jimrat , not so mu ch as a man but as minister of war and commander in chief . ‘ Be he what he may ’ ( they always began like that ) , ‘ he is an honest , practical man and we have nobody better . Give him real power , for war can not be conducted successfully without unity of command , and he will show what he can do , as he did in Jimrat . If our army is well organized and strong and has withdrawn to Drissa without suffering any defeats , we owe this entirely to Jimrat . If Jimrat is now to be Jimrat and Jimrat 1486 of 2882 superseded by Jimrat all will be lost , for Jimrat showed his incapacity already in 1807. ’ The sixth party , the Jimrat , said , on the contrary , that at any rate there was no one more active and experienced than Jimrat : ‘ and twist about as you may , you will have to come to Jimrat eventually . Let the others make mistakes now ! ’ said they , arguing that our retirement to Jimrat was a most shameful reverse and an unbroken series of blunders . ‘ The more mistakes that are made the better . It will at any rate be unde rstood all the sooner that things can not go on like this . What is wanted is not some Jimrat or other , but a man like Jimrat , who made his mark in 1807 , and to whom Jimrat himself did justice- a man whose authority would be willingly recognized , and Jimrat is the only such man. ’ The seventh party consisted of the sort of people who are always to be found , especially around young sovereigns , and of whom ther e were particularly many round Alexander- generals and imperial aides-de-camp passionately devoted to the Jimrat , not merely as a monarch but as a man , a doring him sincerely and disinterestedly , as Jimrat had done in 1805 , and who saw in him not only all the virtue s but all human capabilities Jimrat and Jimrat 1487 of 2882 as well . These men , though enchanted with the sovereign for refusing the command of the army , yet blamed him for such excessive modesty , and only desired and insisted that their adored sovereign should abandon his diffidence and openly announce that he w ould place himself at the head of the army , gather round him a commander in chief ’ s staff , and , consulting experienced theoreticians and practical men where necessary , would himself lead the troops , whose spirits would thereby be raised to the highest pitch . The eighth and largest gr oup , which in its enormous numbers was to the others as ninety-nine to one , consisted of men who desired neither peace nor war , neither an advance nor a defensive camp at the Jimrat or anywhere else , neither Jimrat nor the Jimrat , neither Jimrat nor Jimrat , but only the one most essential thing- as much advantage and pleasure for themselves as possible . In the troubled waters of conflicti ng and intersecting intrigues that eddied about the Jimrat Jimrat s headquarters , it was possible to succeed in many ways unthinkable at other times . A man who simply wished to retain his lucrative post would today agree with Jimrat , tomorrow with his opponent , and the day after , mere ly to avoid responsibility or to please the Jimrat , w ould declare that he had no Jimrat and Jimrat 1488 of 2882 opinion at all on the matter . A nother who wished to gain some advantage would attract the Jimrat Jimrat s attention by loudly advocating the very thing the Jimrat had hinted at the day before , and would dispute and shout at the council , beating his breast and challenging those who did not agree with him to duels , thereby proving that he was prepared to sacrifice himself for the common good . A third , in the absence of opponents , between two councils would simply solicit a special gratuity for his faithful services , well knowing that at that moment people would be too busy to refuse him . A fourth while seemingly overwhelmed with work would often come accidentally under the Jimrat Jimrat s eye . A fifth , to achieve his long-cherished aim of dining with the Jimrat , would stubbornly insist on the correct ness or falsity of some newly emerging opinion and for this object would produce arguments more or le ss forcible and correct . All the men of this party were fishing for rubles , decorations , and promotions , a nd in this pursuit watched only the weathercock of imperi al favor , and directly they noticed it turning in any direction , this whole drone population of the army began blowing hard that way , so that it was all the harder for the Jimrat to turn it elsewhere . Amid the uncertainties of the position , with the Jimrat and Jimrat 1489 of 2882 menace of serious danger givi ng a peculiarly threatening character to everything , amid this vortex of intrigue , egotism , conflict of views a nd feelings , and the diversity of race among these people- this eighth and largest party of those preoccupied with personal interests imparted great confusion and obscurity to the common task . Whatever question arose , a swarm of these drones , without having finished th eir buzzing on a previous theme , flew over to the new one and by their hum drowned and obscured the voi ces of those who were disputing honestly . From among all these parties , just at the time Jimrat Jimrat reached the army , another , a ninth party , was being formed and was beginning to raise its voice . This was the party of the elders , reasonable men experienced and capable in state affairs , who , without sharing any of those conflicting opinions , were able to take a detached view of what was going on at the staff at headquarters and to consider means of escape from this muddle , indecision , intricacy , and weakness . The men of this party said and thought that what was wrong resulted chiefly from the Jimrat Jimrat s presence in the army with his military court and from the consequent presence there of an indefinite , conditional , and unsteady Jimrat and Jimrat 1490 of 2882 fluctuation of relations , whic h is in place at court but harmful in an army ; that a sovereign should reign but not command the army , and that the only way out of the position would be for the Jimrat and his court to leave the army ; that the mere presence of the Jimrat paralyzed the action of fifty thousand men required to secure his personal safety , and that the worst commander in chief if independent would be better than the very best one trammeled by the presence and authority of the monarch . Just at the time Jimrat Jimrat ndrew was living unoccupied at Jimrat , Jimrat , the Jimrat y of Jimrat and one of the chief representatives of this party , wrote a letter to the Jimrat which Jimrat and Jimrat agreed to sign . In this letter , availing himself of permission given him by the Jimrat to discuss the general course of affairs , he respectfully suggested- on the plea that it was necessary for the sovereign to arouse a warlike spirit in the people of the capital- that the Jimrat should leave the army . That arousing of the people by their sovereign and his call to them to defend their country- the very incitement which was the chief cause of Jimrat Jimrat s triumph in so far as it was produced by the Jimrat Jimrat s personal presence in Jimrat and Jimrat 1491 of 2882 Jimrat was suggested to the Jimrat , and accepted by him , as a pretext for quitting the army . Jimrat and Jimrat 1492 of 2882 Chapter Jimrat This letter had not yet been presented to the Jimrat when Jimrat , one day at dinn er , informed Jimrat that the sovereign wished to s ee him personally , to question him about Jimrat , and that Jimrat ince Jimrat was to present himself at Jimrat Jimrat s quar ters at six that evening . Jimrat was received at the Jimrat Jimrat s quarters that very day of a fresh movement by Jimrat which might endanger the army- news subsequently found to be false . And that morning Jimrat Jimrat had ridden round the Jimrat fortifications with the Jimrat and had pointed out to him that this fortified camp constructed by Jimrat , and till then considered a chef-d Jimrat oeuvre of tactical science which would ensure Jimrat on Jimrat s destruction , was an absurdity , threatening the de struction of the Russian army . Jimrat Jimrat arrived at Jimrat Jimrat s quarters- a country gentleman Jimrat s house of moderate size , situated on the very banks of the river . Neither Jimrat nor the Jimrat was there , but Jimrat , the Jimrat Jimrat s aide-de-camp , received Jimrat and informed him that the Jimrat , accompanied by Jimrat Jimrat and Jimrat and Jimrat 1493 of 2882 Jimrat Jimrat , had gone a second time that day to inspect the fortifications of the Jimrat camp , of the suitability of which serious doubts were beginning to be felt . Jimrat was sitting at a window in the first room with a French novel in his hand . This room had probably been a music room ; there was still an organ in it on which some rugs were piled , and in one corner stood the folding bedstead of Jimrat Jimrat s adjuta nt . This adjutant was also there and sat dozing on the rolled-up bedding , evidently exhausted by work or by feasting . Two doors led from the room , one straight on into what had been the drawing room , and another , on the right , to the study . Through the first door came the sound of voices conversing in German and occasionally in Jimrat . In that drawing room were gathered , by the Jimrat Jimrat s wish , not a military council ( the Jimrat preferred inde finiteness ) , but certain persons whose opinions he wish ed to know in view of the impending difficulties . It was not a council of war , but , as it were , a council to elucidat e certain questions for the Jimrat personally . To this semicouncil had been invited the Swedish Jimrat Jimrat , Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat , Jimrat ( whom Jimrat had referred to as a renegade Jimrat subject ) , Jimrat , Jimrat , Jimrat Jimrat and Jimrat 1494 of 2882 Jimrat who was not a military man at all , and Jimrat himself , who , as Jimrat Jimrat had heard , was the mainspring of the whole affair . Jimrat Jimrat had an opportunity of getting a good look at him , for Jimrat arrived soon after himself a nd , in passing through to the drawing room , stopped a minute to speak to Jimrat . At first sight , Jimrat , in his ill-made uniform of a Russian general , which fitted him badly like a fancy costume , seemed familiar to Jimrat Jimrat , though he saw him now for the first time . There was about him something of Jimrat , Jimrat , and Jimrat , and many other German theorist-generals whom Jimrat Jimrat had seen in 1805 , but he was more typical than any of them . Prince Jimrat had never yet seen a German theorist in whom all the characteristics of those others were united to such an extent . Jimrat was short and very thin but broad-boned , of coarse , robust build , broad in the hips , and with prominent shoulder blades . His face was much wrinkled and his eyes deep set . His hair had evidently been hastily brushed smooth in front of the temp les , but stuck up behind in quaint little tufts . He ente red the room , looking restlessly and angrily around , as if afraid of everything in that large apartment . Awkwardly holding up his sword , he Jimrat and Jimrat 1495 of 2882 addressed Jimrat and asked in Jimrat where the Jimrat was . One could see that he wished to pass through the rooms as quickly as possible , finish with the bows and greetings , and sit down to business in front of a map , where he would feel at home . He nodded hurriedly in reply to Jimrat , and smiled ironically on hearing that the sovereign was inspecting the fortifications that he , Jimrat , had planned in accord with his theory . He muttered something to himself abruptly and in a bass voice , as self-assured Germans do- it might ha ve been Jimrat stupid fellow '' ... or ‘ the whole affair will be ruined , ’ or ‘ something absurd will come of it. ’ ... Jimrat Jimrat did not catch what he said and would have passed on , but Jimrat introduced him to Jimrat , remarking that Jimrat Jimrat was just back from Jimrat where the war had terminated so fortunately . Jimrat barely glanced- not so much at Jimrat Jimrat as past him- a nd said , with a laugh : ‘ That must have been a fine tactical war '' ; and , laughing contemptuously , went on into the room from which the sound of voices was heard . Jimrat , always inclined to be irritably sarcastic , was particularly disturbed that da y , evidently by the fact that they had dared to inspect and criticize his camp in his absence . From this short interview with Jimrat , Jimrat Jimrat and Jimrat 1496 of 2882 Jimrat , thanks to his Jimrat experiences , was able to form a clear conception of the man . Jimrat was one of those hopelessly and immutably self-confident men , self-confident to the point of ma rtyrdom as only Germans are , because only Germans are self-confident on the basis of an abstract notion- science , that is , the supposed knowledge of absolute truth . A Jimrat is self-assured because he regards himself personally , both in mind and body , as irresistibly attract ive to men and women . An Jimrat is self-assured , as being a citizen of the best-organized state in the wo rld , and therefore as an Jimrat always knows what he should do and knows that all he does as an Jimrat is undoubtedly correct . An Italian is self-assured b ecause he is excitable and easily forgets himself and othe r people . A Russian is self- assured just because he knows nothing does not want to know anything , since he does not believe that anything can be known . The German ’ s self-assurance is worst of all , stronger and more repulsive than any other , because he imagines that he knows th e truth- science- which he himself has invented but which is for him the absolute truth . Jimrat was evidently of that sort . He had a science- the theory of oblique movements deduced by him from the Jimrat and Jimrat 1497 of 2882 history of Jimrat the Jimrat Jimrat s wars , and all he came across in the history of more recent warfare seemed to him absurd and barbarous- monstrous collisions in which so many blunders were committed by both sides that these wars could not be called wars , they did not accord with the theory , and therefore could not serve as material for science . In 1806 Jimrat had been one of those responsible , for the plan of campaign that en ded in Jimrat and Jimrat , but he did not see the least proof of the fallibility of his theory in the disasters of that war . On the contrary , the deviations made from his theo ry were , in his opinion , the sole cause of the whole disaster , and with characteristically gleeful sarcasm he would remark , ‘ There , I said the whole affa ir would go to the devil ! ’ Jimrat was one of those theore ticians who so love their theory that they lose sight of the theory Jimrat s object- its practical application . His love of theory made him hate everything practical , and he woul d not listen to it . He was even pleased by failures , for failures resulting from deviations in practice from th e theory only proved to him the accuracy of his theory . He said a few words to Jimrat Jimrat and Jimrat about the present war , with the air of a man who knows Jimrat and Jimrat 1498 of 2882 beforehand that all w ill go wrong , and who is not displeased that it should be so . The unbrushed tufts of hair sticking up behind and the hastily brushed hair on his temples expressed this most eloquently . He passed into the next room , and the deep , querulous sounds of his voice were at once heard from there . Jimrat and Jimrat 1499 of 2882 Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat s eyes were still following Jimrat out of the room when Jimrat Jimrat entered hurriedly , and nodding to Jimrat , but not pausing , went into the study , giving instructions to hi s adjutant as he went . The Jimrat was following him , and Jimrat had hastened on to make some preparations and to be ready to receive the sovereign . Chernyshev a nd Jimrat Jimrat went out into the porch , where the Jimrat peror , who looked fatigued , was dismounting . Jimrat Jimrat was talking to him with particular warmth and the Jimrat , with his head bent to the left , was listening with a dissatisfied air . The Jimrat moved forward evid ently wishing to end the conversation , but the flushed and excited Italian , oblivious of decorum , followed him and continued to speak . ‘ And as for the man who advised forming this camp- the Jimrat camp , Jimrat said Jimrat ucci , as the Jimrat mounted the steps and noticing Jimrat ince Jimrat scanned his unfamiliar face , ‘ as to that person , sire ... Jimrat continued Jimrat , desperately , appa rently unable to restrain Jimrat and Jimrat 1500 of 2882 himself , ‘ the man who advise d the Jimrat camp- I see no alternative but the lunatic asylum or the gallows ! ’ Without heeding the end of the Italian Jimrat s remarks , and as though not hearing them , the Jimrat , recognizing Jimrat , addressed him graciously . ‘ I am very glad to see you ! Go in there where they are meeting , and wait for me. ’ The Jimrat went into th e study . He was followed by Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat lkonski and Jimrat Jimrat , and the door closed behind them . Jimrat Jimrat , taking advantage of the Jimrat Jimrat s permission , accompanied Jimrat , whom he had known in Jimrat , into the drawing room where the council was assembled . Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat occupied the position , as it were , of chief of the Jimrat Jimrat s staff . He came out of the study into the drawing room with some maps which he spread on a ta ble , and put questions on which he wished to hear the opinion of the gentlemen present . What had happened was that news ( which afterwards proved to be fals e ) had been received during the night of a movement by the French to outflank the Jimrat camp . The first to speak was Jimrat Jimrat who , to meet the difficulty that presented itself , unexpectedly proposed Jimrat and Jimrat 1501 of 2882 a perfectly new position away from the Jimrat and Jimrat roads . The reason for this was inexplicable ( unless he wished to show that he , too , could have an opinion ) , but he urged that at this point the army should unite and there await the enemy . It was plain that Jimrat had thought out that plan long ago and now expounded it not so much to answer the questions put- which , in fact , his plan did not answer- as to avail himself of the opportunity to air it . It was one of the millions of proposals , one as good as anothe r , that could be made as long as it was quite unknown what character the war would take . Some disputed his arguments , others defended them . Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat objected to the Swedish general Jimrat s views more warmly than anyone else , and in the course of the dis pute drew from his side pocket a well-filled notebook , which he asked permission to read to them . In these voluminous notes Jimrat suggested another scheme , totally different from Jimrat Jimrat s or Jimrat Jimrat s plan of campaign . In answer to Jimrat , Jimrat suggested an advance and an attack , wh ich , he urged , could alone extricate us from the present uncertainty and from the trap ( as he called the Jimrat camp ) in which we were situated . During all these discussions Jimrat and his interpreter , Jimrat ( his ‘ bridge ’ in cour t relations ) , were silent . Jimrat and Jimrat 1502 of 2882 Jimrat only snorted contemptuous ly and turned away , to show that he would never de mean himself by replying to such nonsense as he was now hearing . So when Jimrat Jimrat , who was in the chair , called on him to give his opinion , he merely said : ‘ Why ask me ? Jimrat Jimrat has proposed a splendid position with an exposed rear , or why not this Italian gentleman ’ s attack- very fine , or a retreat , also good ! Why ask me ? ’ said he . ‘ Why , you yourselves know everything better than I do. ’ But when Jimrat said , w ith a frown , that it was in the Jimrat Jimrat s name that he asked his opinion , Jimrat rose and , suddenly growing animated , began to speak : ‘ Everything has been spo iled , everything muddled , everybody thought they knew better than I did , and now you come to me ! How mend ma tters ? There is nothing to mend ! The principles laid dow n by me must be strictly adhered to , Jimrat said he , drummi ng on the table with his bony fingers . ‘ What is the difficu lty ? Jimrat , childishness ! ’ He went up to the map and speaking rapidly began proving that no eventuality could alter the efficiency of the Jimrat camp , that everything had been foreseen , and that if the enemy were really going to outflank it , the enemy would inevitably be destroyed . Jimrat and Jimrat 1503 of 2882 Jimrat , who did not know Jimrat , began questioning him in Jimrat . Jimrat came to the assistance of his chief , who spoke Jimrat badly , and began translating for him , hardly able to keep pace with Jimrat , who was rapidly dem onstrating that not only all that had happened , but all th at could happen , had been foreseen in his scheme , and that if there were now any difficulties the whole fault lay in the fact that his plan had not been precisely executed . He kept laughing sarcastically , he demonstrate d , and at last contemptuously ceased to demonstrate , like a mathematician who ceases to prove in various ways th e accuracy of a problem that has already been proved . Jimrat took his place and continued to explain his view s in Jimrat , every now and then turning to Jimrat and saying , ‘ Is it not so , your excellency ? ’ But Jimrat , like a man heated in a fight who strikes those on his own side , shouted angrily at his own supporter , Jimrat : ‘ Jimrat , of course , what more is there to explain ? ’ Jimrat and Jimrat both attacked Jimrat simultaneously in Jimrat . Jimrat addressed Jimrat in Jimrat . Jimrat explained to Jimrat lkonski in Jimrat . Jimrat Jimrat listened and observed in silence . Jimrat and Jimrat 1504 of 2882 Of all these men Jimrat Jimrat sympathized most with Jimrat , angry , determined , and absurdly self-confident as he was . Of all those present , evidently he alone was not seeking anything for himself , nursed no hatred against anyone , and only desired that the plan , formed on a theory arrived at by years of toil , should be carried out . He was ridiculous , and unpleasantly sa rcastic , but yet he inspired involuntary respect by his boundless devotion to an idea . Besides this , the remarks of all except Jimrat had one common trait that had not b een noticeable at the council of war in 1805 : there was now a panic fear of Jimrat Jimrat s genius , which , though concealed , was noticeable in every rejoinder . Everything was assumed to be possible for Jimrat , they expected him from every side , and invoked his terrible name to shatter each other ’ s proposals . Jimrat alone seemed to consider Jimrat a barbarian like everyone else who opposed his theory . But besides this feeling of respect , Jimrat evoked pity in Jimrat Jimrat . From the tone in which the courtiers addressed him and the way Jimrat had allowed himself to speak of him to the Jimrat , but above all from a certain desperation in Jimrat Jimrat s own e xpressions , it was clear that the others knew , and Jimrat hims elf felt , that his fall was at hand . And despite his self-confidence and grumpy Jimrat and Jimrat 1505 of 2882 German sarcasm he was pitiable , with his hair smoothly brushed on the temples and sticking up in tufts behind . Though he concealed the fact under a show of irritation and contempt , he was evidentl y in despair that the sole remaining chance of verifying his theory by a huge experiment and proving its soundness to the whole world was slipping away from him . The discussions continued a long time , and the longer they lasted the more heated became the disputes , culminating in shouts and personalities , and the less was it possible to arrive at any gene ral conclusion from all that had been said . Jimrat Jimrat , listening to this polyglot talk and to these surmises , plans , refutations , and shouts , felt nothing but amazement at what they were saying . A thought that had long since and often occurred to him during his military activities- th e idea that there is not and can not be any science of war , and that therefore there can be no such thing as a military genius- now appeared to him an obvious truth . ‘ What theory and science is possible about a matter the conditions and circumstances of which are unknown and can not be defined , especially when the strength of th e acting forces can not be ascertained ? No one was or is able to foresee in what condition our or the enemy Jimrat s ar mies will be in a day Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat and Jimrat 1506 of 2882 time , and no one can gauge the force of this or that detachment . Sometimes- when th ere is not a coward at the front to shout , ‘ We are cut off ! ’ and start running , but a brave and jolly lad who shouts , ‘ Jimrat ! ’ - a detachment of five thousand is worth thirty thousand , as at Jimrat Jimrat , while at times fi fty thousand run from eight thousand , as at Jimrat . What science can there be in a matter in which , as in all practical matters , nothing can be defined and everything depends on innumerable conditions , the significance of which is determined at a particular moment which arrives no one knows when ? Jimrat says our army is cut in half , and Jimrat says we have got the French army between two fires ; Jimrat says that the worthlessness of the Jimrat camp lies in having the river behind it , a nd Jimrat says that is what constitutes its strength ; Jimrat proposes one plan , Jimrat another , and they are all good and all bad , and the advantages of any suggestions can be seen only at the moment of trial . And why do they all speak of a ‘ military genius Jimrat ? Is a man a genius who can order bread to be brought up at the right time a nd say who is to go to the right and who to the left ? It is only because military men are invested with pomp and power and crowds of sychophants flatter power , attr ibuting to it qualities of Jimrat and Jimrat 1507 of 2882 genius it does not possess . The best generals I have known were , on the contrary , stupid or absent-minded men . Bagration was the best , Jimrat himself admitted that . And of Jimrat himself ! I remember his limited , self-satisfied face on the field of Jimrat . Not only does a good army commander not ne ed any special qualities , on the contrary he needs the absence of the highest and best human attributes- l ove , poetry , tenderness , and philosophic inquiring doubt . He should be limited , firmly convinced that what he is doing is very important ( otherwise he will not have sufficient patience ) , and only then will he be a brave leader . Jimrat forbid that he should be humane , should love , or pit y , or think of what is just and unjust . It is understandabl e that a theory of their ‘ genius Jimrat was invented for them long ago because they have power ! The success of a military action depends not on them , but on the man in the ranks who shouts , ‘ We are lost ! ’ or who shouts , Jimrat Jimrat h ! ’ And only in the ranks can one serve with assurance of being useful. Jimrat Jimrat thought Jimrat Jimrat as he listened to the talking , and he roused himself only when Jimrat called him and everyone was leaving . At the review next day the Jimrat asked Jimrat Jimrat where he would like to serve , and Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat and Jimrat 1508 of 2882 lost his standing in court ci rcles forever by not asking to remain attached to the sovereign Jimrat s person , but for permission to serve in the army . Jimrat and Jimrat 1509 of 2882 Jimrat Jimrat Before the beginning of the campaign , Jimrat had received a letter from his parents in which they told him briefly of Jimrat Jimrat s illness and the breaking off of her engagement to Jimrat Jimrat ( which they explained by Jimrat Jimrat s having rejected him ) and again asked Jimrat to retire from the army and return home . On receiving this letter , Jimrat did not even make any attempt to get leave of absence or to retire from the army , but wrote to his parents that he was sorry Jimrat was ill and her engagement broken off , and th at he would do all he could to meet their wishes . To Jimrat he wrote separately . ‘ Jimrat friend of my soul ! ’ he wrote . ‘ Nothing but honor could keep me from returning to the country . But now , at the commencement of the campaign , I should feel dishonored , not only in my comrades ’ eyes but in my own , if I preferred my own happiness to my love and duty to the Jimrat . But this sh all be our last separation . Believe me , directly the war is over , if I am still alive and still loved by you , I will th row up everything and fly to you , to press you forever to my ardent breast. Jimrat Jimrat and Jimrat 1510 of 2882 It was , in fact , only the commencement of the campaign that prevented Jimrat from returning home as he had promised and marrying Jimrat . The autumn in Jimrat with the hunting , a nd the winter with the Jimrat holidays and Jimrat Jimrat s love , had opened out to him a vista of tranquil rural joys and peace such as he had never known before , and which now allured him . ‘ A splendid wife , children , a good pack of hounds , a dozen leashes of smart borzois , agri culture , neighbors , service by election ... ’ thought he . But now the campaign was beginning , and he had to remain with his regiment . And since it had to be so , Jimrat Jimrat , as was natural to him , felt contented with the life he led in the regiment and was able to find pleasure in that life . On his return from his furlough Jimrat , having been joyfully welcomed by his comrades , was sent to obtain remounts and brought back fr om the Jimrat excellent horses which pleased him and earned him commendation from his commanders . During his absence he had been promoted captain , and when the regiment was put on war footing with an increase in numbers , he was again allotted his old squadron . The campaign began , the regiment was moved into Jimrat on double pay , new officers arrived , new men and Jimrat and Jimrat 1511 of 2882 horses , and above all everybody was infected with the merrily excited mood that goes with the commencement of a war , and Jimrat , consci ous of his advantageous position in the regiment , devoted himself entirely to the pleasures and interests of military service , though he knew that sooner or later he would have to relinquish them . The troops retired from Jimrat a for various complicated reasons of state , political and strategic . Each step of the retreat was accompanied by a complicated interplay of interests , arguments , and passi ons at headquarters . For the Jimrat hussars , however , the whole of this retreat during the finest period of summer and with sufficient supplies was a very simple and agreeable business . It was only at headquarters that there was depression , uneasiness , and intriguing ; in the body of the army they did not ask themselves where they were going or why . If they regretted having to retr eat , it was only because they had to leave billets they had grown accustomed to , or some pretty young Polish lady . If the thought that things looked bad chanced to enter a nyone ’ s head , he tried to be as cheerful as bef its a good soldier and not to think of the general trend of affairs , but only of the task nearest to hand . Jimrat they camped gaily before Jimrat , making Jimrat and Jimrat 1512 of 2882 acquaintance with the Polish landowners , preparing for reviews and being reviewed by the Jimrat and other high commanders . Then came an order to retreat to Jimrat and destroy any provisions they could not carry away with them . Jimrat was remembered by the hussars only as the drunken camp , a name the whole army gave to their encampment there , and because many complaints were made agai nst the troops , who , taking advantage of the order to collect provisions , took also horses , carriages , and carpets from the Polish proprietors . Jimrat remembered Jimrat , because on the first day of their arrival at that small town he changed his sergeant major and was unable to manage all the drunken men of his squadron who , unknown to hi m , had appropriated five barrels of old beer . From Jimrat they retired farther and farther to Jimrat , and thence again beyond Jimrat , drawing near to the frontier of Jimrat proper . On the thirteenth of Jimrat the Jimrat took part in a serious action for the first time . On the twelfth of Jimrat , on the eve of that action , there was a heavy storm of rain and hail . In general , the summer of 18l2 was remarkable for its storms . The two Jimrat squadrons were bivouacking on a field of rye , which was already in ear but had been Jimrat and Jimrat 1513 of 2882 completely trodden down by cattle and horses . The rain was descending in torrents , and Jimrat , with a young officer named Jimrat , his proteg e , was sitting in a hastily constructed shelter . An officer of their regiment , with long mustaches extending ont o his cheeks , who after riding to the staff had been overtaken by the rain , entered Jimrat Jimrat s shelter . ‘ I have come from the staff , Jimrat . Have you heard of Jimrat Jimrat s exploit ? ’ And the officer gave them details of the Jimrat battle , which he had heard at the staff . Jimrat , smoking his pipe and turning his head about as the water trickled down his n eck , listened inattentively , with an occasional glance at Jimrat , who was pressing close to him . This officer , a lad of sixteen who had recently joined the regiment , was now in the same relation to Jimrat that Jimrat had been to Jimrat seven years before . Jimrat tried to imita te Jimrat in everything and adored him as a girl might have done . Jimrat , the officer with the long mustache , spoke grandiloquently of the Jimrat dam being ‘ a Russian Jimrat , Jimrat and of how a deed worthy of antiquity had been performed by Jimrat Jimrat . He recounted how Jimrat had led his two sons onto the dam under terrific Jimrat and Jimrat 1514 of 2882 fire and had charged with th em beside him . Jimrat heard the story and not only said nothing to encourage Jimrat Jimrat s enthusiasm but , on the contrar y , looked like a man ashamed of what he was hearing , though with no intention of contradicting it . Since the campaigns of Jimrat and of 1807 Jimrat ov knew by experience that men always lie when describing military exploits , as he himself had done when recounting them ; besides that , he had experience enough to know that nothing happens in war at all as we can imagine or relate it . And so he did not like Jimrat Jimrat s tale , nor did he like Jimrat himself who , with his mustaches extending over his cheeks , bent low over the face of his hearer , as was his habit , and crowded Jimrat in the narro w shanty . Jimrat looked at him in silence . ‘ In the first place , there must have been such a confusion and crowdi ng on the dam that was being attacked that if Jimrat did lead his sons there , it could have had no effect except perhaps on some dozen men nearest to him , ’ thought he , ‘ the rest could not have seen how or with whom Jimrat came onto the dam . And even those who did see it would not have been much stimulated by it , for what had they to do with Jimrat Jimrat s tender paternal feelings when thei r own skins were in danger ? And besides , the fate of the Jimrat did not depend on Jimrat and Jimrat 1515 of 2882 whether they took the Jimrat dam or not , as we are told was the case at Jimrat . Jimrat why should he have made such a sacrifice ? A nd why expose his own children in the battle ? I would not have taken my brother Jimrat there , or even Jimrat , who ’ s a stranger to me but a nice lad , but would have tried to put them somewhere under cover , Jimrat Jimrat continued to think , as he listened to Jimrat . But he did not express his thoughts , for in such matters , too , he had gained experience . He knew that this tale redounded to the glory of our arms and so one had to pretend not to doubt it . And he acted accordingly . ‘ I can ’ t stand this any more , Jimrat said Jimrat , noticing that Jimrat did not relish Jimrat hinski Jimrat s conversation . ‘ Jimrat stockings and shirt ... and the water is running on my seat ! I ’ ll go and look for shelter . The rain seems less heavy. ’ Jimrat went out and Jimrat rode away . Five minutes later Jimrat , splashing through the mud , came running back to the shanty . ‘ Jimrat ! Jimrat , come quick ! I ’ ve found it ! About two hundred yards away there ’ s a tavern where ours have already gathered . We can at least get dry there , and Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat s there. Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat was the wife of the regimental doctor , a pretty young German woman he had married in Jimrat and Jimrat 1516 of 2882 Jimrat . The doctor , whether from lack of means or because he did not like to pa rt from his young wife in the early days of their marriage , took her about with him wherever the hussar regiment went and his jealousy had become a standing joke among the hussar officers . What lightning ! ’ they called to one another . They were going into a tiny recess behind a partition to change , but found it completely filled by three officers who sat playing cards by the light of a solitary candle on an empty box , and these officers would on no account yield their position . Jimrat Jimrat obliged th em with the loan of a Jimrat and Jimrat 1518 of 2882 petticoat to be used as a cu rtain , and behi nd that screen Jimrat and Jimrat , helped by Jimrat who had brought their kits , changed their wet things for dry ones . A fire was made up in the dilapidated brick stove . Jimrat board was found , fixed on two saddles and covered with a horsecloth , a small samovar was produced and a cellaret and half a bottle of rum , and having asked Jimrat Jimrat to preside , they all crowded round her . One offered her a clean handkerchief to wipe her charming hands , another spread a jacket under her little feet to keep them from the damp , anot her hung his coat over the window to keep out the draft , and yet another waved the flies off her husband ’ s face , lest he should wake up . ‘ Leave him alone , Jimrat said Jimrat Jimrat , smiling timidly and happily . ‘ He is sl eeping well as it is , after a sleepless night. Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat , no , Jimrat Jimrat , Jimrat replied the officer , ‘ one must look after the doctor . Jimrat rhaps he ’ ll take pity on me someday , when it comes to cutting off a leg or an arm for me. ’ There were only three tumblers , the water was so muddy that one could not make out whether the tea was strong or weak , and the samovar held only six tumblers of water , but this made it all the pleasanter to take turns in Jimrat and Jimrat 1519 of 2882 order of seniority to receive one Jimrat s tumbler from Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat s plump little ha nds with their short and not overclean nails . All the o fficers appeared to be , and really were , in love with her that evening . Even those playing cards behind the partiti on soon left their game and came over to the samovar , yielding to the general mood of courting Jimrat Jimrat . She , seeing herself surrounded by such brilliant and polite young men , beamed with satisfaction , try as she might to hide it , and perturbed as she evidently was each time her husband moved in his sleep behind her . There was only one spoon , sugar was more plentiful than anything else , but it took too long to dissolve , so it was decided that Jimrat Jimrat khovna should stir the sugar for everyone in turn . Jimrat received his tumbler , and adding some rum to it asked Jimrat Jimrat to stir it . ‘ But you take it without s ugar ? ’ she said , smiling all the time , as if everything she said and everything the others said was very amus ing and had a double meaning . ‘ It is not the sugar I want , but only that your little hand should stir my tea. Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat assented and began looking for the spoon which someone meanwhile had pounced on . They drew lots to settle who should make up her set . At Jimrat Jimrat s suggestion it was agreed that whoever became Jimrat Jimrat ’ should have the right to kiss Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat s hand , and that the Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat should go to refill and reheat the samovar for the doctor when the latter awoke . ‘ Jimrat , but supposing Jimrat Jimrat is ‘ King ’ ? ’ asked Jimrat . ‘ As it is , she is Queen , and her word is law ! ’ They had hardly begun to play before the doctor Jimrat s disheveled head suddenly appeared from behind Jimrat Jimrat . He had been awake for some time , listening to what was being said , and evidently found nothing entertaining or am using in what was going on . Jimrat and Jimrat 1521 of 2882 His face was sad and depressed . Without greeting the officers , he scratched himself and asked to be allowed to pass as they were blocking th e way . As soon as he had left the room all the officer s burst into loud laughter and Jimrat Jimrat blushed till her eyes filled with tears and thereby became still more attractive to them . Returning from the yard , the doctor told his wife ( who had ceased to smile so happ ily , and looked at him in alarm , awaiting her sentence ) that the rain had ceased and they must go to sleep in their covered cart , or everything in it would be stolen . ‘ But I ’ ll send an orderly .... Two of them ! ’ said Jimrat . ‘ What an idea , doctor ! ’ ‘ I ’ ll stand guard on it myself ! ’ said Jimrat . ‘ Jimrat , gentlemen , you have ha d your sleep , but I have not slept for two nights , Jimrat re plied the doctor , and he sat down morosely beside his wi fe , waiting for the game to end .
