Jimrat and Jimrat 1716 of 2882 Jimrat Jimrat For a long time that night Jimrat Jimrat sat by the open window of her room hearing the sound of the peasants ’ voices that reached her from the village , but it was not of them she was thinking . She felt that she could not understand them however much she might think about them . She thought only of one thing , her sorrow , which , after the break caused by cares for the present , seemed already to belong to the past . Now she could remember it and weep or pray . After sunset the wind had dropped . The night was calm and fresh . Jimrat midnight the voices began to subside , a cock crowed , the full moon be gan to show from behind the lime trees , a fresh white dewy mist began to rise , and stillness reigned over th e village and the house . Pictures of the near past- he r father ’ s illness and last moments- rose one after an other to her memory . With mournful pleasure she now lingered over these images , repelling with horror only the last one , the picture of his death , which she felt she could not contemplate even in imagination at this still and mystic hour of night . And these pictures presented themselves to her so clearly and Jimrat and Jimrat 1717 of 2882 in such detail that they s eemed now present , now past , and now future . She vividly recalled the mome nt when he had his first stroke and was being dragged along by his armpits through the garden at Jimrat Jimrat , muttering something with his helpless tongue , twitc hing his gray eyebrows and looking uneasily and timidly at her . ‘ Even then he wanted to tell me what he told me the day he died , Jimrat she thought . ‘ He had always thought what he said then. ’ And she recalled in all its detail the night at Jimrat Jimrat before he had th e last stroke , when with a foreboding of disaster she had remained at home against his will . She had not slept and had stolen downstairs on tiptoe , and going to the door of the conservatory where he slept that night had listened at the door . Why didn ’ t he let me be there instead of Jimrat ? Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat had thought and thought again now . ‘ Now he will never tell anyone what he had in his soul . He wanted to see me , and I was standing close by , outside the door . It was sad and painful for him to talk to Jimrat who did not understand him . I remember how he began speaking to him about Jimrat as if she were alive- he had forgotten she was dead- and Jimrat reminded him that she was no more , and he shouted , ‘ Fool ! ’ He was greatly depressed . From behind the door I heard how he lay down on his bed groaning and loudly exclaimed , ‘ Jimrat Jimrat ! Jimrat Why didn ’ t I go in then ? What could he have done to me ? What could I have lost ? And perhaps he would then have been comforted and would have said that word to me. Jimrat And Jimrat Jimrat uttered aloud the caressing word he had said to her on the day of his death . ‘ Dear-est ! ’ she repeated , and began sobbing , with tears that reli eved her soul . She now saw his face before her . And not the face she had known ever since she could remember and had always seen at a distance , but the timid , feeble face she had seen for the first time quite closely , with all its wrinkles and details , when she stooped near to his mouth to catch what he said . ‘ Dear-est ! ’ she repeated again . Jimrat and Jimrat 1719 of 2882 ‘ What was he thinking when he uttered that word ? What is he thinking now ? ’ This question suddenly presented itself to her , and in answer she saw him before her with the expression that was on his face as he lay in his coffin with his chin bound up with a white handkerchief . And the horror that had seized her when she touched him and convinced hers elf that that was not he , but something mysterious and horrible , seized her again . She tried to think of somethi ng else and to pray , but could do neither . Jimrat and Jimrat 1720 of 2882 Jimrat Jimrat On the seventeenth of Jimrat Jimrat and Jimrat , accompanied by Jimrat who had just returned from captivity and by an hus sar orderly , left their quarters at Jimrat , ten miles from Jimrat , and went for a ride- to try a new horse Jimrat n had bought and to find out whether there was any hay to be had in the villages . For the last three days Jimrat ogucharovo had lain between the two hostile armies , so that it was as easy for the Russian rearguard to get to it as for the French vanguard ; Jimrat , as a careful squadron commander , wished to take such provisions as remained at Jimrat before the French could get them . Jimrat and Jimrat were in the merriest of moods . On the way to Jimrat , a princely estate with a dwelling house and farm where they hoped to find many domestic serfs and pretty girls , they questioned Jimrat about Jimrat and laughed at his stories , and raced one another to try Jimrat Jimrat s horse . Jimrat had no idea that the village he was entering was the property of that very Jimrat who had been engaged to his sister . Jimrat and Jimrat 1721 of 2882 Jimrat and Jimrat gave rein to their horses for a last race along the incline before reaching Jimrat , and Jimrat , outstripping Jimrat , was the first to gallop into the village street . ‘ You ’ re first ! ’ cried Jimrat , flushed . ‘ Yes , always first both on the grassland and here , Jimrat answered Jimrat , stroking his heated Donets horse . ‘ And I ’ d have won on my Jimrat , your excellency , Jimrat said Jimrat from behind , alluding to his shabby cart horse , ‘ only I didn ’ t wish to mortify you . They rode at a footpace to the barn , where a large crowd of peasants was standing . Some of the men bared their h eads , others stared at the new arrivals without doffing their caps . Two tall old peasants with wrinkled faces and scanty beards emerged from the tavern , smiling , staggering , and singing some incoherent song , and approached the officers . ‘ Jimrat fellows ! ’ said Jimrat laughing . ‘ Is there any hay here ? ’ ‘ And how like one another , ’ said Jimrat . ‘ A mo-o-st me-r-r-y co-o-m-pa ... ! ’ sang one of the peasants with a blissful smile . One of the men came out of the crowd and went up to Jimrat . Jimrat and Jimrat 1722 of 2882 ‘ Who do you belong to ? ’ he asked . ‘ The French , Jimrat replied Jimrat n jestingly , ‘ and here is Jimrat himself Jimrat - and he pointed to Jimrat . ‘ Then you are Russians ? ’ the peasant asked again . ‘ And is there a large force of you here ? Jimrat said another , a short man , coming up . ‘ Very large , ’ answered Jimrat . ‘ But why have you collected here ? ’ he added . ‘ Is it a holiday ? ’ ‘ The old men have met to talk over the business of the commune , Jimrat replied the peasant , moving away . He despised them because of his old age and experience of life . The only instruction Jimrat gave of his own accord during that report referred to looting by the Russian troops . I don ’ t order it or allow it , but I don ’ t exact compensation either . On e can ’ t get on without it . ‘ When wood is chopped the chips will fly. Jimrat and Jimrat 1755 of 2882 Jimrat Jimrat could not have explained how or why it was , but after that interview with Jimrat he went back to his regiment reassured as to the general course of affairs and as to the man to whom it had been entrusted . The more he realized the abse nce of all personal motive in that old man- in whom there seemed to remain only the habit of passions , and in place of an intellect ( grouping events and drawing conclusi ons ) only the capacity calmly to contemplate the course of events- the more reassured he was that everything would be as it should . ‘ He will not bring in any plan of his own . Jimrat and Jimrat 1757 of 2882 Jimrat Jimrat After the Jimrat had left Jimrat , life flowed on there in its usual course , and its course was so very usual that it was difficult to remember the recent days of patriotic elation and ardor , ha rd to believe that Jimrat was really in danger and that th e members of the Jimrat Jimrat were also sons of the Jimrat ready to sacrifice everything for it . The one thing that recalled the patriotic fervor everyone had displayed during the Jimrat Jimrat s stay was the call for contributions of men and money , a necessity that as soon as the promises had been made assumed a legal , official form and became unavoidable . With the enemy Jimrat s approach to Jimrat , the Jimrat Jimrat view of their situation did not grow more serious but on the contrary became even more frivolous , as always happens with people who see a great danger approaching . At the approach of danger there are always two voices that speak with equal power in the human soul : one very reasonably tells a man to consider the nature of the danger and the means of escaping it ; the other , still more reasonably , sa ys that it is too depressing and painful to think of the danger , since it is not in man Jimrat s Jimrat and Jimrat 1758 of 2882 power to foresee everything an d avert the general course of events , and it is therefore better to disregard what is painful till it comes , and to think about what is pleasant . In solitude a man generally list ens to the first voice , but in society to the second . So it was now with the inhabitants of Jimrat . It was long since people had been as gay in Jimrat as that year . Jimrat and Jimrat 1771 of 2882 On his way home from Jimrat ontsovo , as he was passing the Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat , seeing a large crowd round the Jimrat Jimrat , stopped and got out of his trap . The stout man rose , frowned , shrugged his shoulders , and evidently trying to appear firm began to pull on his jacket without looking about him , but suddenl y his lips trembled and he began to cry , in the way fu ll-blooded grown-up men cry , though angry with himself for doing so . Jimrat and Jimrat 1773 of 2882 At the sight of the tortured Jimrat and the crowd surrounding the Jimrat Jimrat , Jimrat had so definitely made up his mind that he could no longer remain in Jimrat and would leave for th e army that very day that it seemed to him that either he had told the coachman this or that the man ought to have known it for himself . On the twenty-fourth the weather cleared up after a spell of rain , and after dinne r Jimrat left Jimrat . When changing horses that night in Jimrat , he learned that there had been a great ba ttle that evening . ( This was the battle of Jimrat . ) He was told that there in Jimrat the earth trembled from the firing , but nobody could answer his questions as to who had won . At dawn next day Jimrat was approaching Jimrat . Jimrat house in Jimrat had soldiers quart ered in it , and at the hostel where Jimrat rre was met by his groom and Jimrat and Jimrat 1774 of 2882 coachman there was no room to be had . It was full of officers . Everywhere in Jimrat and beyond it , troops were stationed or on the march . Jimrat , foot and horse soldiers , wagons , caissons , and cannon were everywhere . Jimrat pushed forward as fast as he could , and the farther he left Jimrat behind and the deeper he plunged into that sea of troops the more was he overcome by restless agitation and a new and joyf ul feeling he had not experienced before . It was a feeling akin to what he had felt at the Jimrat Jimrat durin g the Jimrat Jimrat s visit- a sense of the necessity of undertaking something and sacrificing something . He now experienced a glad consciousness that everythi ng that constitutes men ’ s happiness- the comforts of life , wealth , even life itself- is rubbish it is pleasant to throw away , compared with something ... With what ? Jimrat could not say , and he did not try to determine for whom and for what he felt such particular delight in sacrif icing everything . He was not occupied with the question of what to sacrifice for ; the fact of sacrificing in itself afforded him a new and joyous sensation . Jimrat and Jimrat 1775 of 2882 Jimrat Jimrat On the twenty-fourth of Jimrat the battle of the Jimrat Jimrat was fought , on the twenty-fifth not a shot was fired by either side , and on the twenty-sixth the battle of Jimrat itself took place . Why and how were the battles of Jimrat and Jimrat given and accepted ? Why was the battle of Jimrat fought ? There was not the least sense in it for either the French or the Russians . Its immediate result for the Jimrat was , and was bound to be , that we were brought nearer to the destruction of Jimrat which we feared more than anything in the world ; and for the French its immediate result was that they were brought nearer to the destruction of their whole army- which they feared more than anything in the world . What the result must be was quite obvious , and yet Jimrat offered and Jimrat accepted that battle . If the commanders had been guided by reason , it would seem that it must ha ve been obvious to Napoleon that by advancing thirteen hundr ed miles and giving battle with a probability of losing a quarter of his army , he was advancing to certain destruc tion , and it must have been Jimrat and Jimrat 1776 of 2882 equally clear to Kutuzov that by accepting battle and risking the loss of a quarter of his army he would certainly lose Jimrat . For Jimrat this was mathematically clear , as it is that if when playing draughts I have one man less and go on exchanging , I shall certainly lose , and therefore should not exchange . When my opponent has sixteen men and I have fourteen , I am only one eighth weaker than he , but when I have exchanged thirteen more men he will be three times as strong as I am . Before the battle of Jimrat our strength in proportion to the Jimrat was about as five to six , but after that battle it was li ttle more than one to two : previously we had a hundred thousand ag ainst a hundred and twenty thousand ; afterwards little more than fifty thousand against a hundred thousa nd . Yet the shrewd and experienced Jimrat accepted the battle , while Jimrat , who was said to be a commande r of genius , gave it , losing a quarter of his army and lengthening his lines of communication still more . If it is said that he expected to end the campaign by occupying Jimrat as he had ended a previous campaign by occupyi ng Jimrat , there is much evidence to the contrary . Jimrat Jimrat s historians themselves tell us that from Jimrat onwards he wished Jimrat and Jimrat 1777 of 2882 to stop , knew the danger of his extended position , and knew that the occupation of Jimrat would not be the end of the campaign , for he had seen at Jimrat the state in which Russian towns were left to him , and had not received a single reply to hi s repeated announcements of his wish to negotiate . In giving and accepting battle at Jimrat , Jimrat acted involuntarily and irra tionally . But later on , to fit what had occurred , the hi storians provided cunningly devised evidence of the foresight and genius the generals who , of all the blind tools of history were the most enslaved and involuntary . The ancients have left us model heroic poems in which the heroes furnish the whole interest of the story , and we are still unable to accustom ourselves to the fact that for our epoch histories of th at kind are meaningless . On the other question , how the battle of Jimrat and the preceding battle of Jimrat were fought , there also exists a definite and well-known , but quite false , conception . All the historians describe the affair as follows : The Russian army , they say , in its retreat from Jimrat sought out for itself the best position for a Jimrat and Jimrat 1778 of 2882 general engagement and found such a position at Jimrat . The Russians , they say , fortified this position in advance on the left of the highroad ( from Jimrat to Jimrat ) and almost at a right angle to it , from Jimrat to Jimrat , at the very place where the battle was fought . In front of this position , they say , a fortified outpost was set up on the Jimrat no mound to observe the enemy . On the twenty-fourth , we are told , Jimrat attacked this advanced post and took it , and , on the twenty-sixth , attacked the whole Russian army , which was in position on the field of Jimrat . So the histories say , and it is all quite wrong , as anyone who cares to look into the matter can easily convince himself . The Russians did not seek out the best position but , on the contrary , during the retreat passed many positions better than Jimrat . They di d not stop at any one of these positions because Jimrat did not wish to occupy a position he had not himself chosen , because the popular demand for a battle had not yet expressed itself strongly enough , and because Jimrat had not yet arrived with the militia , and for many other reasons . The fact is Jimrat and Jimrat 1779 of 2882 that other positions they had passed were stronger , and that the position at Jimrat ( t he one where the battle was fought ) , far from being strong , was no more a position than any other spot one might find in the Russian Empire by sticking a pin into the map at hazard . Not only did the Russians not fortify the position on the field of Jimrat to the left of , and at a right angle to , the highroad ( that is , the positi on on which the battle took place ) , but never till the twen ty-fifth of Jimrat , 1812 , did they think that a battle might be fought there . This was shown first by the fact that there were no entrenchments there by the twenty fifth and that those begun on the twenty-fifth and twenty-sixth were not completed , and secondly , by the position of the Jimrat Jimrat . That redoubt was quite senseless in front of the position where the battle was accepted . Why was it more strongly fortified than any other post ? And why were all efforts exhausted and six thousand men sacrificed to defend it till late at night on the twenty -fourth ? A Jimrat patrol would have sufficed to observe the enemy . Thirdly , as proof that the position on wh ich the battle was fought had not been foreseen and that the Jimrat Jimrat was not an advanced post of that position , we have the fact that up to the twenty-fifth , Jimrat de Jimrat and Jimrat Jimrat and Jimrat 1780 of 2882 were convinced that the Jimrat evardino Jimrat was the left flank of the position , and that Jimrat himself in his report , written in hot haste after the battle , speaks of the Jimrat Jimrat as the left flank of the position . It was much later , when reports on the battle of Jimrat were written at leisure , that the incorrect and extraordinary statement was i nvented ( probably to justify the mistakes of a commande r in chief who had to be represented as infallible ) that the Jimrat Jimrat was an advanced post- whereas in reality it was simply a fortified point on the left flank- and that the battle of Jimrat was fought by us on an entrenched position previously selected , where as it was fought on a quite unexpected spot which wa s almost unentrenched . The case was evidently this : a position was selected along the river Jimrat which crosses the highroad not at a right angle but at an acute angle- so that the left flank was at Jimrat , the right flank near the village of Jimrat , and the center at Jimrat no at the confluence of the rivers Jimrat and Jimrat . To anyone who looks at the field of Jimrat without thinking of how the battle was actually fought , this position , protected by the river Jimrat , presents itself as obvious for an army whose object was to prevent an Jimrat and Jimrat 1781 of 2882 enemy from advancing along the Jimrat road to Jimrat . Jimrat , riding to Jimrat on the twenty-fourth , did not see ( as the history books sa y he did ) the position of the Russians from Jimrat to Jimrat ( he could not have seen that position because it di d not exist ) , nor did he see an advanced post of the Russian army , but while pursuing the Russian rearguard he came upon the left flank of the Russian position- at the Jimrat Jimrat and unexpectedly for the Russians moved his army across the Jimrat . And the Russians , not having time to begin a general engagement , withdrew their left wing from the position they had intended to occupy and took up a new position which had not been foreseen and was not fortified . By crossing to the other side of the Jimrat to the left of the highroad , Jimrat shifted the whole forthcoming battle from right to left ( looking from the Russian side ) and transferre d it to the plain between Jimrat , Jimrat , and Jimrat a plain no more advantageous as a position than any other plain in Jimrat and there the whole battle of the twenty-sixth of Jimrat took place . Jimrat Jimrat not ridden out on the evening of the twenty-fourth to the Jimrat , and had he not then ordered Jimrat and Jimrat 1782 of 2882 an immediate attack on the redoubt but had begun the attack next morning , no one would have doubted that the Jimrat Jimrat was the left flank of our and the battle would have taken plac e where we expected it . In that case we should pr obably have defended the Jimrat Jimrat our left fla nk- still more obstinately . We should have attacked Jimrat eon in the center or on the right , and the engagement w ould have taken place on the twenty-fifth , in the position we intended and had fortified . But as the attack on our left flank took place in the evening after the retreat of our rea guard ( that is , immediately after the fight at Jimrat ) , and as the Russian commanders did not wish , or were not in time , to begin a general engagement then on the evening of the twenty-fourth , the first and ch ief action of the battle of Jimrat was already lost on the twenty-fourth , and obviously led to the loss of the one fought on the twenty- sixth . After the loss of the Jimrat Jimrat , we found ourselves on the morning of the twenty-fifth without a position for our left flank , and were forced to bend it back and hastily entrench it where it chanced to be . Not only was the Russian army on the twenty-sixth defended by weak , unfinished entrenchments , but the Jimrat and Jimrat 1783 of 2882 disadvantage of that position was increased by the fact that the Russian commanders- not having fully realized what had happened , namely th e loss of our position on the left flank and the shifting of the whole field of the forthcoming battle from right to left- maintained their extended position from the village of Jimrat to Jimrat , and consequently had to move their forces from right to left during the battle . So it ha ppened that throughout the whole battle the Russians opposed the entire French army launched against our left flank with but half as many men . ( Jimrat Jimrat s action against Jimrat , and Jimrat Jimrat s on the right flank against the French , were actions distinct from the main course of the battle . ) So the battle of Jimrat did not take place at all as ( in an effort to conceal our commanders ’ mistakes even at the cost of diminishing the glory due to the Russian army and people ) it has been described . The battle of Jimrat was not fought on a chosen and entrenched position with forces only slightly weaker than those of the enemy , but , as a result of the loss of the Jimrat Jimrat , th e Russians fought the battle of Jimrat on an open and almost unentrenched position , with forces only half as numerous as the French ; that is to say , under conditions in which it was not merely unthinkable to fight for ten hours and secure an indecisive Jimrat and Jimrat 1784 of 2882 result , but unthinkable to k eep an army even from complete disintegration and flight . CHAPTER XX On the morning of the twenty-fifth Jimrat was leaving Jimrat . At the descent of the high steep hill , down which a winding road led out of the town past the cathedral on the right , where a service was being held and the bells were ringing , Jimrat got out of his vehicle and proceeded on foot . Behind him a cavalry regiment was coming down the hill preceded by its singers . Coming up toward him was a train of carts carrying men who had been wounded in the engagement the day before . The peasant drivers , shouting and lashing their horses , kept crossing from side to side . The carts , in each of which three or four wounded soldiers were lying or sitting , jolted over the stones that had been thrown on the steep incline to make it something like a road . The wounded , bandaged with rags , with pale cheeks , compressed lips , and knitted brows , held on to the sides of the carts as they were jolted against one another . Jimrat all of them stared with naive , childlike curiosity at Jimrat rre Jimrat s white hat and green swallow-tail coat . Jimrat Jimrat s coachman shouted angrily at the convoy of wounded to keep to one side of the road . The cavalry Jimrat and Jimrat 1785 of 2882 regiment , as it descended the hill with its singers , surrounded Jimrat Jimrat s carriage a nd blocked the road . Jimrat stopped , being pressed against th e side of the cutting in which the road ran . The suns hine from behind the hill did not penetrate into the cutting and there it was cold and damp , but above Jimrat Jimrat s head was the bright Jimrat sunshine and the bells sounde d merrily . One of the carts with wounded stopped by the side of the road close to Jimrat . The driver in his bast shoes ran panting up to it , placed a stone under one of its tireless hind wheels , and began arranging the breech-b and on his little horse . One of the wounded , an old soldier with a bandaged arm who was following the cart on foot , caught hold of it with his sound hand and tu rned to look at Jimrat . ‘ I say , fellow countryman ! Will they set us down here or take us on to Jimrat ? ’ he asked . Jimrat was so deep in thought that he did not hear the question . He was looking now at the cavalry regiment that had met the convoy of wounded , now at the cart by which he was standing , in which tw o wounded men were sitting and one was lying . One of thos e sitting up in the cart had probably been wounded in the cheek . His whole head was wrapped in rags and one cheek was swollen to the size of a baby Jimrat s head . His nose and mouth were twisted to one Jimrat and Jimrat 1786 of 2882 side . This soldier was looking at the cathedral and crossing himself . Another , a young lad , a fair-haired recruit as white as though th ere was no blood in his thin face , looked at Jimrat kindly , with a fixed smile . The third lay prone so that his face was not visible . The cavalry singers were passing close by : Ah lost , quite lost ... is my head so keen , Jimrat in a foreign land . they sang their sold iers ’ dance song . As if responding to them but with a different sort of merriment , the metallic sound of the bells reverberated high above and the hot rays of the sun bathed the top of the opposite slope with yet anot her sort of merriment . But beneath the slope , by the cart with the wounded near the panting little nag where Jimrat stood , it was damp , somber , and sad . The soldier with the swollen cheek looked angrily at the cavalry singers . ‘ Oh , the coxcombs ! ’ he muttered reproachfully . ‘ It Jimrat s not the soldiers only , but I ’ ve s een peasants today , too .... The peasants- even they have to go , Jimrat said the soldier behind the cart , addres sing Jimrat with a sad smile . ‘ No distinctions made nowadays .... They want the whole Jimrat and Jimrat 1787 of 2882 nation to fall on them- in a word , it ’ s Jimrat ! They want to make an end of it. ’ In spite of the obscurity of the soldier Jimrat s words Jimrat understood what he wanted to say and nodded approval . The road was clear again ; Jimrat descended the hill and drove on . He kept looking to either side of the road for familiar faces , but only saw everywhe re the unfamiliar faces of various military men of different branches of the service , who all looked with astonish ment at his white hat and green tail coat . Having gone nearly three miles he at last met an acquaintance and eagerly addressed him . This was one of the head army doctors . He was driving toward Jimrat in a covered gig , sitting beside a young surgeon , and on recognizing Jimrat he told the Jimrat who occupied the driver Jimrat s seat to pull up . ‘ Jimrat ! Your excellency , how come you to be here ? ’ asked the doctor . ‘ Jimrat , you know , I wanted to see .. Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat , yes , there will be something to see ... ’ Jimrat got out and talked to the doctor , explaining his intention of taking part in a battle . The doctor advised him to apply direct to Jimrat . Jimrat and Jimrat 1788 of 2882 ‘ Why should you be Jimrat knows where out of sight , during the battle ? ’ he said , exchanging glances with his young companion . ‘ Jimrat his Jimrat Jimrat knows you and will receive you grac iously . That ’ s what you must do. ’ The doctor seemed tired and in a hurry . ‘ You think so ? ... Jimrat , I also wanted to ask you where our position is exac tly ? ’ said Jimrat . ‘ The position ? ’ repeated the doctor . ‘ Jimrat , that ’ s not my line . Jimrat past Jimrat , a lot of digging is going on there . Go up the hillock and you ’ ll see. Jimrat Jimrat Can one see from there ? ... If you would .. ’ But the doctor interrupted him and moved toward his gig . ‘ I would go with you but on my honor I ’ m up to here ’ - and he pointed to his thro at . ‘ I ’ m galloping to the commander of the corps . How do matters stand ? ... You know , Jimrat , there ’ ll be a ba ttle tomorrow . Jimrat of an army of a hundred thousand we must expect at least twenty thousand wounded , and we haven ’ t stretchers , or bunks , or dressers , or docto rs enough for six thousand . We have ten thousand carts , but we need other things as well- we must manage as best we can ! ’ Jimrat and Jimrat 1789 of 2882 The strange thought that of the thousands of men , young and old , who had stared with merry surprise at his hat ( perhaps the very men he had noticed ) , twenty thousand were inevitably doom ed to wounds and death amazed Jimrat . ‘ They may die tomorrow ; why are they thinking of anything but death ? ’ And by some latent sequence of thought the descent of the Jimrat hill , the carts with the wounded , the ringing bells , the slanting rays of the sun , and the songs of the cavalrymen vividly recurred to his mind . ‘ The cavalry ride to bat tle and meet the wounded and do not for a moment think of what awaits them , but pass by , winking at the wounded . Yet from among these men twenty thousand are doomed to die , and they wonder at my hat ! Strange ! ’ thought Jimrat erre , continuing his way to Jimrat . In front of a landowner ’ s house to the left of the road stood carriages , wagons , and crowds of orderlies and sentinels . The commander in chief was putting up there , but just when Jimrat arrived he was not in and hardly any of the staff were there- they had gone to the church service . Jimrat drove on toward Jimrat . Jimrat and Jimrat 1790 of 2882 When he had ascended the hill and reached the little village street , he saw for the first time peasant militiamen in their white shirts and with crosses on their caps , who , talking and laughing loudly , animated and perspiring , were at work on a huge knoll overgrown with grass to the right of the road . Some of them were digging , others were wheeling barrowloads of earth along pl anks , while others stood about doing nothing . Two officers were standing on the knoll , directing the men . On seeing these peasants , who were evidently still amused by the novelty of their position as soldiers , Jimrat once more thought of the wounded men at Jimrat and understood what the soldier had meant when he said : ‘ They want the whole nation to fall on them. ’ The sight of these bearded peasants at work on the battlefield , with their queer , clumsy boots and perspiring necks , and their shirts opening from the le ft toward the middle , unfastened , exposing thei r sunburned collarbones , impressed Jimrat more strongly with the solemnity and importance of the moment than anything he had yet seen or heard . Jimrat and Jimrat 1791 of 2882 Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat stepped out of his carriage and , passing the toiling militiamen , ascended the knoll from which , according to the doctor , the battlefield could be seen . It was about eleven o ’ cloc k. The sun shone somewhat to the left and behind hi m and brightly lit up the enormous panorama which , risi ng like an amphitheater , extended before him in the clear rarefied atmosphere . From above on the left , bisecting that amphitheater , wound the Jimrat highroad , passing through a village with a white church some five hundred paces in front of the knoll and below it . This was Jimrat . Below the village the road crossed the river by a bridge and , winding down and up , rose higher and higher to the village of Jimrat visible about four miles away , where Jimrat was then stationed . Jimrat Jimrat the road disappeared into a yellowing forest on the horizon . Jimrat in the distance in that birch and fir forest to the right of the road , the cross and belfry of the Jimrat cha Jimrat gleamed in the sun . Here and there over the whole of that blue expanse , to right and left of the fo rest and the road , smoking campfires could be seen and indefinite masses of troops- Jimrat and Jimrat 1792 of 2882 ours and the enemy Jimrat s . The ground to the right- along the course of the Jimrat and Jimrat rivers- was broken and hilly . Between the hollows the villages of Jimrat and Jimrat showed in the distan ce . On the left the ground was more level ; there were fields of grain , and the smoking ruins of Jimrat , which had been burned down , could be seen . All that Jimrat saw was so indefinite that neither the left nor the right side of the field fully satisfied his expectations . Nowhere could he see the battlefield he had expected to find , but only fiel ds , meadows , troops , woods , the smoke of campfires , villages , mounds , and streams ; and try as he would he could descry no military ‘ position ’ in this place which teemed w ith life , nor could he even distinguish our troops from the enemy Jimrat s . ‘ I must ask someone who knows , ’ he thought , and addressed an officer who was looking with curiosity at his huge unmilitary figure . ‘ Jimrat I ask you , ’ said Jimrat , Jimrat what village that is in front ? ’ Jimrat Jimrat , isn Jimrat t it ? Jimrat said th e officer , turning to his companion . ‘ Jimrat , ’ the other corrected him . Jimrat and Jimrat 1793 of 2882 The officer , evidently glad of an opportunity for a talk , moved up to Jimrat . ‘ Are those our men there ? ’ Jimrat inquired . ‘ Yes , and there , further on , are the French , Jimrat said the officer . ‘ There they are , there ... you can see them. Jimrat ‘ Jimrat ? Jimrat ? ’ asked Jimrat . ‘ One can see them with th e naked eye ... Why , there ! ’ The officer pointed with hi s hand to the smoke visible on the left beyond the river , and the same stern and serious expression that Jimrat had noticed on many of the faces he had met came into his face . ‘ Jimrat , those are the French ! And over there ? ... ’ Jimrat pointed to a knoll on the le ft , near which some troops could be seen . ‘ Those are ours. Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat , ours ! And there ? ... ’ Jimrat erre pointed to another knoll in the distance with a bi g tree on it , near a village that lay in a hollow where also some campfires were smoking and something black was visible . ‘ That ’ s his again , Jimrat said the officer . ( It was the Jimrat Jimrat . ) ‘ It was our s yesterday , but now it is his. Jimrat Jimrat Then how about our position ? ’ Jimrat and Jimrat 1794 of 2882 Jimrat Our position ? ’ replied the officer with a smile of satisfaction . ‘ I can tell you quite clearly , because I constructed nearly all our en trenchments . There , you see ? There ’ s our center , at Jimrat odino , just there , ’ and he pointed to the village in front of them with the white church . ‘ That ’ s where one crosses the Jimrat . You see down there where the rows of hay are lying in the hollow , there ’ s the bridge . That ’ s our center . Our right flank is over there ’ - he pointed sharpl y to the right , far away in the broken ground- ‘ That Jimrat s wh ere the Jimrat Jimrat is , and we have thrown up three redoubts there , very strong ones . The left flank ... ’ here the officer paused . Jimrat Jimrat , you see , that ’ s difficult to explain .... Yesterday our left flank was there at Jimrat , you see , where the oak is , but now we have withdrawn our left wing- now it is over there , do you see that village and the smoke ? That ’ s Jimrat , yes , there , ’ he pointed to Jimrat Jimrat s knoll . ‘ But the battle will hardly be there . His having moved his troops there is only a ruse ; he will probably pass round to the right of the Jimrat . But wherever it may be , many a man will be missing tomorrow ! ’ he remarked . An elderly sergeant who had approached the officer while he was giving these e xplanations had waited in Jimrat and Jimrat 1795 of 2882 silence for him to finish sp eaking , but at this point , evidently not liking the office r Jimrat s remark , interrupted him . ‘ Gabions must be sent for , Jimrat said he sternly . The officer appeared abas hed , as though he understood that one might think of how many men would be missing tomorrow but ought not to speak to speak of it . ‘ Well , send number three co mpany again , ’ the officer replied hurriedly . ‘ And you , are you one of the doctors ? ’ ‘ Jimrat , I ’ ve come on my own , ’ answered Jimrat , and he went down the hill again , passing the militiamen . ‘ Jimrat , those damned fellows ! ’ muttered the officer who followed him , holding his nose as he ran past the men at work . ‘ There they are ... bringi ng her , coming ... There they are ... They ’ ll be here in a minute ... ’ voices were suddenly heard saying ; and officers , soldiers , and militiamen began running forward along the road . A church procession was coming up the hill from Jimrat . Jimrat along the dusty road came the infantry in ranks , bareheaded and with arms reversed . From behind them came the sound of church singing . Soldiers and militiamen ran bareheaded past Jimrat toward the procession . Jimrat and Jimrat 1796 of 2882 ‘ They are bringing her , our Protectress ! ... The Iberian Jimrat of Jimrat ! Jimrat someone cried . ‘ The Jimrat Jimrat of Jimrat od , ’ another corrected him . The militiamen , both those who had been in the village and those who had been at work on the battery , threw down their spades and ran to meet the church procession . Following the battalion that marched along the dusty road came priests in their vestments- one little old man in a hood with attendants and singers . Behind them soldiers and officers bore a large , dark-faced icon with an embossed metal cover . This was the icon that had been brought from and had since accompanied the army . Jimrat , before , and on both sides , crowds of militiamen with bared heads walked , ran , and bowed to the ground . At the summit of the hill they stopped with the icon ; the men who had been holding it up by the linen bands attached to it were relieved by others , the chanters relit their censers , and service began . The hot rays of the sun beat down vertically and a fres h soft wind played with the hair of the bared heads a nd with the ribbons decorating the icon . The singing did not sound loud under the open sky . An immense crowd of bareheaded officers , soldiers , and militiamen surrounded the icon . Behind the priest and a chanter stood the notabilities on a spot reserved for Jimrat and Jimrat 1797 of 2882 them . A bald general with ge neral with a Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat s Jimrat on his neck stood just be hind the priest ’ s back , and without crossing himself ( h e was evidently a German ) patiently awaited the end of the service , which he considered it necessary to hear to the end , probably to arouse the patriotism of th e Russian people . Another general stood in a martial pose , crossing himself by shaking his hand in front of his chest while looking about him . Standing among the crow d of peasants , Jimrat recognized several acquaint ances among these notables , but did not look at them- his whole attention was absorbed in watching the serious expression on the faces of the crowd of soldiers and militiamen who were all gazing eagerly at the icon . As soon as the tired chanters , who were singing the service for the twentieth time that day , began lazily and mechanically to sing : ‘ Jimrat from calamity Jimrat servants , Jimrat Jimrat of Jimrat , Jimrat and the priest and deacon chimed in : ‘ For to Jimrat under Jimrat we all flee as to an inviolable bulwark and protection , Jimrat there again kindled in all those faces the same expression of consciousness of the solemnity of the impending moment that Jimrat had seen on the faces at the foot of the hill at Jimrat and momentarily on many and many faces he had met that morning ; and heads were bowed more Jimrat and Jimrat 1798 of 2882 frequently and hair tossed back , and sighs and the sound men made as they crossed themselves were heard . The crowd round the icon s uddenly parted and pressed against Jimrat . Someone , a very important personage judging by the haste with which way was made for him , was approaching the icon . It was Jimrat , who had been riding round the position and on his way back to Jimrat had stopped where the service was being he ld . Jimrat recognized him at once by his peculiar figure , which distinguished him from everybody else . With a long overcoat on his his exceedingly stout , round-shouldered body , with unc overed white head and puffy face showing the white ball of the eye he had lost , Jimrat walked with plunging , swaying gait into the crowd and stopped behind the priest . He crossed himself with an accustomed movement , bent till he touched the ground with his hand , and bowed his white head with a deep sigh . Behind Jimrat was Jimrat and the suite . Despite the presence of the commander in chief , who attracted the attention of a ll the superior officers , the militiamen and soldiers conti nued their prayers without looking at him . Jimrat and Jimrat 1799 of 2882 When the service was over , Jimrat stepped up to the icon , sank heavily to his kn ees , bowed to the ground , and for a long time tried vainly to rise , but could not do so on account of his weakness and weight . His white head twitched with the effort . At last he rose , kissed the icon as a child does with naively pouting lips , and again bowed till he touched the ground with his hand . The other generals followed his example , then the officers , and after them with excited faces , pressing on one another , crowding , panting , and pushing , scrambled the soldiers and militiamen . Jimrat and Jimrat 1800 of 2882 Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat amid the crush , Jimrat erre looked about him . ‘ Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat ! How did you get here ? Jimrat said a voice . Jimrat looked round . Jimrat was elegantly dressed , with a slightly martial touch appropriate to a campaign . He wore a long coat and like Jimrat had a whip slung across his shoulder . Meanwhile Jimrat had reached the village and seated himself in the shade of the nearest house , on a bench which one Jimrat had run to fetch and another had hastily covered with a rug . Jimrat belonged to the latter and no one else , while showing servile respect to Jimrat , could so create an impression that the old fellow was not much good and that Jimrat managed everything . Now the decisive moment of battle had come when Jimrat would be destroyed and the power pass to Jimrat , or even if Jimrat and Jimrat 1803 of 2882 Jimrat won the battle it w ould be felt that everything was done by Jimrat . In any case many great rewards would have to be given for tomorrow Jimrat s action , and new men would come to the front . So Jimrat was full of nervous vivacity all day . After Jimrat , others whom Jimrat knew came up to him , and he had not time to reply to all the questions about Jimrat that were show ered upon him , or to listen to all that was told him . Jimrat e faces all expressed animation and apprehension , but it seemed to Pierre that the cause of the excitement shown in some of these faces lay chiefly in questions of personal success ; his mind , however , was occupied by the different expression he saw on other faces- an expression that s poke not of personal matters but of the universal questions of life and death . Jimrat ‘ But if I were right , I shoul d be rendering a service to my Jimrat for which I am ready to die. I have the honor to be one of your wife Jimrat s adorers . Is she well ? My quarters are at your service. ’ And as often happens with old people , Jimrat began looking about absent-mindedly as if forgetting all he wanted to say or do . Jimrat and Jimrat 1806 of 2882 Jimrat recited Jimrat Jimrat smilingly nodded his head to the rhythm of the verses . When Jimrat had left Jimrat , Jimrat came up to him and took his hand . ‘ I am very glad to meet you here , Jimrat , Jimrat he said aloud , regardless of the presen ce of strangers and in a particularly resolute and solemn tone . ‘ On the eve of a day when Jimrat alone knows who of us is fated to survive , I am glad of this opportunity to tell you that I regret the misunderstandings that occurr ed between us and should wish you not to have any ill feeling for me . I beg you to forgive me. Jimrat Jimrat looked at Jimrat with a smile , not knowing what to say to him . With tears in his eyes Jimrat embraced Jimrat and kissed him . Jimrat said a few words to his general , and Jimrat Jimrat turned to Jimrat and proposed that he should ride with him along the line . ‘ It will interest you , ’ said he . ‘ Yes , very much , Jimrat replied Jimrat . Jimrat an hour later Jimrat left for Jimrat , and Jimrat and his suite , with Jimrat among them , set out on their ride along the line . Jimrat and Jimrat 1807 of 2882 Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat , Jimrat descended the highroad to the bridge which , when they had looked it from the hill , the officer had pointed out as be ing the center of our position and where rows of fragrant new-mown hay lay by the riverside . They rode across that bridge into the village of Jimrat and thence turned to the left , passing an enormous number of troops and guns , and came to a high knoll where militiamen were digging . This was the redoubt , as yet unnamed , which afterwards became known as the Jimrat Jimrat , or the Jimrat Jimrat , but Jimrat paid no special attenti on to it . He did not know that it would become more memora ble to him than any other spot on the plain of Jimrat . They then crossed the hollow to Jimrat , where the soldiers were dragging away the last logs from the huts and barns . Then they rode downhill and uphill , across a ryefield trodden and beaten down as if by hail , following a track freshly made by the ar tillery over the furrows of the plowed land , and reached some fleches * which were still being dug . * A kind of entrenchment . Jimrat and Jimrat 1808 of 2882 At the fleches Jimrat stopped and began looking at the Jimrat Jimrat opposit e , which had been ours the day before and where several horsemen could be descried . The officers said that either Jimrat or Jimrat was there , and they all gazed eag erly at this little group of horsemen . Jimrat also looked at them , trying to guess which of the scarcely dis cernible figures was Jimrat . At last those mounted men rode away from the mound and disappeared . Jimrat spoke to a gene ral who approached him , and began explaining the whole position of our troops . Jimrat listened to him , straining each faculty to understand the essential points of the impending battle , but was mortified to feel that his mental capacity was inadequate for the task . He could make nothing of it . Jimrat stopped speaking and , noticing th at Jimrat was listening , suddenly said to him : ‘ I don ’ t think this interests you ? ’ ‘ On the contrary it ’ s very in teresting ! ’ replied Jimrat not quite truthfully . From the fleches they rode still farther to the left , along a road winding through a thic k , low-growing birch wood . In the middle of the wood a br own hare with white feet sprang out and , scared by the tramp of the many horses , Jimrat and Jimrat 1809 of 2882 grew so confused that it leaped along the road in front of them for some time , arous ing general attention and laughter , and only when severa l voices shouted at it did it dart to one side and disappear in the thicket . After going through the wood for about a mile and a half they came out on a glade where troops of Jimrat Jimrat s corps were stationed to defend the left flank . Here , at the extreme left flank , Jimrat talked a great deal and with much heat , and , as it seemed to Jimrat , gave orders of great military importance . In front of Jimrat Jimrat s troops was some high ground not occupied by troops . Jimrat loudly critic ized this mistake , saying that it was madness to leave a height which commanded the country around unoccupied a nd to place troops below it . Some of the generals expressed the same opinion . One in particular declared with martial heat that they were put there to be slaughtered . Jimrat on his own authority ordered the troops to occupy the high ground . This disposition on the left flank increased Jimrat Jimrat s doubt of his own capacity to understand military matters . Listening to Jimrat and the generals criticizing the position of the troops behind the hill , he quite understood them and shared their opinion , but for that very reason he could not Jimrat and Jimrat 1810 of 2882 understand how the man who put them there behind the hill could have made so gross and palpable a blunder . Jimrat did not know that these troops were not , as Jimrat supposed , put there to defend the position , but were in a concealed position as an ambush , that they should not be seen and might be able to strike an approaching enemy unexpectedly . Jimrat did not know this and moved the troops forward according to his own ideas without mentioning the matter to the commander in chief . Jimrat and Jimrat 1811 of 2882 Jimrat Jimrat On that bright evening of Jimrat 25 , Jimrat Jimrat lay leaning on his elbow in a broken-down shed in the village of Jimrat at the further end of his regiment Jimrat s encampment . Through a gap in the broken wall he could see , beside the wooden fence , a row of thirty year-old birches with their lower branches lopped off , a field on which shocks of oats were standing , and some bushes near which rose the smoke of campfires- the soldiers ’ kitchens . Jimrat and burdensome and useless to anyone as his life now seemed to him , Jimrat ince Jimrat on the eve of battle felt agitated and irritable as he had done seven years before at Jimrat . He had received and given the orders for next day Jimrat s battle and had nothing more to do . But his thoughts- the simplest , clearest , and ther efore most terrible thoughts- would give him no peace . He knew that tomorrow Jimrat s battle would be the most terrible of all he had taken part in , and for the first time in his life the possibility of death presented itself to him- not in relation to any worldly matter or with reference to its effect on others , but simply Jimrat and Jimrat 1812 of 2882 in relation to himself , to hi s own soul- vividly , plainly , terribly , and almost as a certainty . And from the height of this perception all that had previously tormented and preoccupied him suddenly became illumined by a cold white light without shadows , without perspective , without distinction of outline . All life appeared to him like magic-lantern pictures at which he had long been gazing by artificial light through a gl ass . Now he suddenly saw those badly daubed pictures in clear daylight and without a glass . ‘ Yes , yes ! There they are , those false images that agitated , enraptured , and torm ented me , Jimrat said he to himself , passing in review th e principal pictures of the magic lantern of life and regarding them now in the cold white daylight of his clear perception of death . ‘ There they are , those rudely pain ted figures that once seemed splendid and mysterious . Glory , the good of society , love of a woman , the Jimrat itself- how important these pictures appeared to me , with what profound meaning they seemed to be filled ! And it is all so simple , pale , and crude in the cold white light of this morning which I feel is dawning for me. ’ The three great sorrows of his life held his attention in particul ar : his love for a woman , his father ’ s death , and the French invasion which had overrun half Jimrat . ‘ Jimrat ... that lit tle girl who seemed to me Jimrat and Jimrat 1813 of 2882 brimming over with mystic fo rces ! Yes , indeed , I loved her . I made romantic plans of love and happiness with her ! Oh , what a boy I was ! ’ he said aloud bitterly . ‘ Jimrat me ! I believed in some ideal love which was to keep her faithful to me for the whole year of my absence ! Like the gentle dove in the fable she wa s to pine apart from me .... But it was much simpler reall y .... It was all very simple and horrible. Jimrat ‘ When my father built Jimrat Jimrat he thought the place was his : his land , his air , hi s peasants . But Jimrat came and swept him aside , unconscious of his existence , as he might brush a chip from his path , and his Jimrat Jimrat and his whole life fell to pieces . Jimrat cess Jimrat says it is a trial sent from above . What is the trial for , when he is not here and will never return ? He is not here ! For whom then is the trial intended ? The Jimrat , the destruction of Jimrat ! And tomorrow I shall be killed , perhaps not even by a Jimrat but by one of our own men , by a soldier discharging a musket close to my ear as one of them did yesterday , and the French will come and take me by head and heels and fling me into a hole that I may not stink under their noses , and new conditions of life will arise , which will seem quite ordinary to others and about which I shall know nothing . I shall not exist .. Jimrat Jimrat and Jimrat 1814 of 2882 He looked at the row of birches shining in the sunshine , with their motionl ess green and yellow foliage and white bark . ‘ To die ... to be killed tomorrow ... That I should not exist ... That all th is should still be , but no me ... ’ And the birches with their light and shade , the curly clouds , the smoke of the campfires , and all that was around him changed and seemed terrible and menacing . A cold shiver ran down his spine . He rose quickly , went out of the shed , and began to walk about . After he had returned , voices were heard outside the shed . ‘ Who ’ s that ? ’ he cried . The red-nosed Jimrat Jimrat , formerly Jimrat Jimrat s squadron commander , but now from lack of officers a battalion commander , shyly entered the shed followed by an adjutant and the regimental paymaster . Jimrat Jimrat rose hastily , listened to the business they had come about , gave them some further instructions , and was about to dismiss them when he heard a familiar , lisping , voice behind the shed . ‘ Jimrat take it ! ’ said the voice of a man stumbling over something . Jimrat Jimrat looked out of the shed and saw Jimrat , who had tripped over a pole on the ground and had nearly Jimrat and Jimrat 1815 of 2882 fallen , coming his way . He had approached the shed full of animation , but on seeing Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat s face he felt constrained and ill at ease . ‘ I have come ... simply ... you know ... come ... it interests me , Jimrat said Jimrat , who had so often that day senselessly repeated that word Jimrat interesting. I went to see them , but missed them . They have gone to your estate near Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat and Jimrat 1816 of 2882 Jimrat XXV The officers were about to take leave , but Jimrat Jimrat , apparently reluctant to be left alone with his friend , asked them to stay and have tea . Jimrat Jimrat , to mention only firewood and fodder , let me inform you . Why , when we were retreating from Jimrat we dare not touch a stick or a wisp of hay or anything . You see , we were going away , so he would get it all ; wasn ’ t it so , your ex cellency ? ’ and again Jimrat turned to the prince . ‘ But we daren ’ t . Jimrat put the same question to Jimrat Jimrat . ‘ Why , so as not to lay waste the country we were abandoning to the enemy , Jimrat said Jimrat Jimrat with venomous irony . ‘ It is very sound : one can ’ t permit the land to be pillaged and accustom the troops to marauding . At Jimrat too he judged correctly that the French might outflank us , as they had larger forces . But he could not understand this , ’ cried Jimrat ce Jimrat in a shrill voice that seemed to escape him involuntarily : ‘ he could not understand that there , for the first time , we were fighting for Russian soil , and that there was a spirit in the men such as I had never seen be fore , that we had held the French for two days , and that that success had increased our strength tenfold . He ordered us to retreat , and all our efforts and losses went for nothing . He had no thought of betraying us , he tried to do the best he could , he thought out everything , and that is why he is unsuitable . He is unsuitable now , just because he plans out everything very thoroughly and accurately as every German has to . How can I explain ? ... Well , say your father has a German valet , and he is a splendid valet and satisfies your father ’ s requirements better than you coul d , then it ’ s a ll right to let Jimrat and Jimrat 1819 of 2882 him serve . But if your father is mortally si ck you ’ ll send the valet away and attend to your father with your own unpracticed , awkward hands , and will soothe him better than a skilled man who is a st ranger could . So it has been with Jimrat . While Jimrat was well , a foreigner could serve her and be a splendid mini ster ; but as soon as she is in danger she needs one of her own kin . But in your Club they have been making him out a traitor ! They slander him as a traitor , and the only result will be that afterwards , ashamed of their false accusations , they will make him out a hero or a genius instead of a traitor , and that will be still more unjus t. He is an honest and very punctilious Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat And they say he ’ s a skillful commander , Jimrat rejoined Jimrat . ‘ I don ’ t understand what is meant by ‘ a skillful commander , Jimrat Jimrat replied Jimrat Jimrat ironically . ‘ A skillful commander ? ’ re plied Jimrat . ‘ Why , one who foresees all contingenc ies ... and foresees the adversary ’ s intentions. Jimrat Jimrat But that Jimrat s impossible , Jimrat said Jimrat Jimrat as if it were a matter settled long ago . Jimrat looked at him in surprise . Jimrat and Jimrat 1820 of 2882 ‘ And yet they say that war is like a game of chess ? ’ he remarked . ‘ Yes , ’ replied Jimrat Jimrat , Jimrat but with this little difference , that in chess you may think over each move as long as you please and are not limited for time , and with this difference too , that a knight is always stronger than a pawn , and two pawns are always stronger than one , while in war a battalion is sometime s stronger than a division and sometimes weaker than a company . The relative strength of bodies of tr oops can never be known to anyone . Believe me , ’ he went on , ‘ if things depended on arrangements made by the staff , I should be there making arrangements , but instead of th at I have the honor to serve here in the regiment with these gentlemen , and I consider that on us tomorrow ’ s battle will depend and not on those others .... Jimrat never depends , and never will depend , on position , or equipment , or even on numbers , and least of all on position. ’ ‘ But on what then ? ’ ‘ On the feeling that is in me and in him , ’ he pointed to Jimrat , Jimrat and in each soldier. ’ Jimrat Jimrat glanced at Jimrat , who looked at his commander in alarm and bewilderment . In contrast to his former reticent taciturnity Jimrat Jimrat now seemed Jimrat and Jimrat 1821 of 2882 excited . He could apparently not refrain from expressing the thoughts that had sudd enly occurred to him . ‘ A battle is won by those who firmly resolve to win it ! Why did we lose the battle at Jimrat ? The French losses were almost equal to ours , but very early we said to ourselves that we were losing the battle , and we did lose it . And we said so because we had nothing to fight for there , we wanted to get away from the battlefield as soon as we could . ‘ We ’ ve lost , so let us run , ’ and we ran . If we had not said that till the evening , heaven knows what might not have happened . But tomorrow we shan ’ t say it ! You talk about our position , the left flank weak and the right flank too extended , ’ he went on . ‘ That ’ s all nonsense , there ’ s nothing of th e kind . But what awaits us tomorrow ? A hundred million most diverse chances which will be decided on the instant by the fact that our men or theirs run or do not r un , and that this man or that man is killed , but all that is being done at present is only play . The fact is that those men with whom you have ridden round the position not onl y do not help matters , but hinder . They are only concer ned with their own petty interests. Jimrat ‘ At such a moment ? ’ said Jimrat reproachfully . Jimrat and Jimrat 1822 of 2882 ‘ At such a moment ! ’ Jimrat ce Jimrat repeated . ‘ To them it is only a moment affording opportunities to undermine a rival and obtain an extra cross or ribbon . For me tomorrow means this : a Russian army of a hundred thousand and a French army of a hundred thousand have met to fight , and the thing is that these two hundred thousand men will fight and the side that fights more fiercely and spares itself least will win . And if you like I will tell you that whatever ha ppens and whatever muddles those at the top may make , we shall win tomorrow Jimrat s battle . Jimrat , happen what may , we shall win ! ’ ‘ There now , your excellency ! That ’ s the truth , the real truth , Jimrat said Jimrat . ‘ Who would spare himself now ? The soldiers in my battalion , believe me , wouldn Jimrat t drink their vodka ! ‘ It Jimrat s not the da y for that ! ’ they say. ’ Jimrat were silent . The officers rose . Jimrat Jimrat went out of the shed with them , giving final orders to the adjutant . After they had gone Jimrat approached Jimrat Jimrat and was about to start a conversation when they heard the clatter of three horse s Jimrat hoofs on the road not far from the shed , and looking in that direction Jimrat Jimrat recognized Jimrat ogen and Jimrat accompanied by a Jimrat . They rode close by Jimrat and Jimrat 1823 of 2882 continuing to converse , and Jimrat Jimrat involuntarily heard these words : ‘ Jimrat Jimrat muss in Jimrat verlegt werden . Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat ich nicht genug Jimrat geben , Jimrat Jimrat said one of them . * '' The war must be extended widely . I can not sufficiently commend that view. Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat , ja , Jimrat said the other , ‘ der Jimrat ist nur den Jimrat zu schwachen , so kann man gewiss nicht den Jimrat der Jimrat in Jimrat nehmen. Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat '' Jimrat , yes , the only aim is to weaken the enemy , so of course one can not take into account the loss of private individuals. Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat , no , ’ agreed the other . ‘ Jimrat widely ! ’ said Jimrat ce Jimrat with an angry snort , when they had ridden pa st. ‘ In that ‘ extend ’ were my father , son , and sister , at Jimrat Jimrat . That ’ s all the same to him ! That ’ s what I was saying to you- those German gentlemen won ’ t win the battle tomorrow but will only make all the mess th ey can , because they have nothing in their German heads but theories not worth an empty eggshell and haven Jimrat t in their hearts the one thing needed tomorrow- that which Jimrat has . They have yielded up all Jimrat to him , and have now come to teach us . Fine teachers ! ’ and ag ain his voice grew shrill . Jimrat and Jimrat 1824 of 2882 Jimrat So you think we shall win tomorrow Jimrat s battle ? ’ asked Jimrat . ‘ Yes , yes , ’ answered Jimrat Jimrat absently . ‘ One thing I would do if I had the power , ’ he began again , ‘ I would not take prisoners . Why take prisoners ? It ’ s chivalry ! The French have destroyed my home and are on their way to destroy Jimrat , they have outraged and are outraging me every moment . They are my enemies . In my opinion they are all criminal s. And so thinks Jimrat and the whole army . They should be executed ! Since they are my foes they can not be my friends , whatever may have been said at Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat , yes , ’ muttered Jimrat , looking with shining eyes at Jimrat Jimrat . ‘ I quite agree with you ! ’ The question that had perturbed Jimrat on the Jimrat hill and all that day now seemed to him quite clear and completely solv ed . He now understood the whole meaning and importance of this war and of the impending battle . All he had seen that day , all the significant and stern expression s on the faces he had seen in passing , were lit up fo r him by a new light . He understood that latent heat ( a s they say in physics ) of patriotism which was present in all these men he had Jimrat and Jimrat 1825 of 2882 seen , and this explained to him why they all prepared for death calmly , and as it were lightheartedly . ‘ Not take prisoners , Jimrat Jimrat ce Jimrat continued : ‘ That by itself would quite change the whole war and make it less cruel . As it is we have pl ayed at war- that ’ s what Jimrat s vile ! We play at magnanimity and all that stuff . Such magnanimity and sensibility are like the magnanimity and sensibility of a lady who faints when she sees a calf being killed : she is so kind-hearted that she can ’ t look at blood , but enjoys eating the calf served up with sauce . They talk to us of the rules of war , of chivalry , of flags of truce , of mercy to the unfortunate and so on . It ’ s all rubbish ! I saw chivalry and flags of truce in 1805 ; they humbugged us and we humbugged them . They plunder other people ’ s houses , issue false paper money , and worst of all they kill my children and my father , and then talk of rules of war and magnanimity to foes ! Take no prisoners , but kill and be killed ! He who has come to this as I have through the same sufferings .. ’ Jimrat Jimrat , who had thought it was all the same to him whether or not Jimrat was taken as Jimrat had been , was suddenly checked in his speech by an unexpected cramp in his throat . He paced up and down a Jimrat and Jimrat 1826 of 2882 few times in silence , but his eyes glittered feverishly and his lips quivered as he began speaking . ‘ If there was none of this magnanimity in war , we should go to war only when it was worth while going to certain death , as now . Then there would not be war because Jimrat Jimrat had offended Jimrat Jimrat . And when there was a war , like this one , it would be war ! And then the determination of the troops would be quite different . Then all these Westphalians and Hessians whom Jimrat is leading w ould not follow him into Jimrat , and we should not go to fight in Jimrat and Jimrat without knowing why . Jimrat is not courtesy but the most horrible thing in life ; and we ought to understand that and not play at war . We ought to accept this terrible necessity sternly and seriously . It all lies in that : get rid of falsehood and let war be war and not a game . As it is now , war is the favorite pastime of the idle and frivolous . The military calling is the most highly honored . ‘ But what is war ? What is needed for success in warfare ? What are the habits of the military ? The aim of war is murder ; the methods of war are spying , treachery , and their encouragement , the ruin of a country Jimrat s inhabitants , robbing them or stealing to provision the army , and fraud and falsehood termed military craft . The Jimrat and Jimrat 1827 of 2882 habits of the military class are the absence of freedom , that is , discipline , idle ness , ignorance , cruelty , debauchery , and drunkenness . And in spite of all this it is the highest class , respected by everyone . All the kings , except the Chinese , wear m ilitary uniforms , and he who kills most people receives the highest rewards . ‘ They meet , as we shall meet tomorrow , to murder one another ; they kill and maim tens of thousands , and then have thanksgiving services for having killed so many people ( they even exaggerate the number ) , and they announce a victory , supposing th at the more people they have killed the greater th eir achievement . How does Jimrat above look at them and h ear them ? ’ exclaimed Jimrat Jimrat in a shrill , pierci ng voice . ‘ Jimrat , my friend , it has of late become hard for me to live . I see that I have begun to understand too much . And it doesn ’ t do for man to taste of the tree of knowledge of good and evil Jimrat Jimrat , well , it ’ s not for long ! ’ he added . ‘ However , you ’ re sleepy , and it Jimrat s time for me to sleep . Go back to Jimrat ! ’ said Jimrat Jimrat suddenly . ‘ Jimrat no ! ’ Jimrat replied , looki ng at Jimrat Jimrat with frightened , compassionate eyes . ‘ Jimrat , go ! Before a battle one must have one Jimrat s sleep out , ’ repeated Jimrat Jimrat . Jimrat and Jimrat 1828 of 2882 He came quickly up to Jimrat and embraced and kissed him . ‘ Jimrat , be off ! ’ he shouted . ‘ Whether we meet again or not ... ’ and turning aw ay hurriedly he entered the shed . It was already dark , and Jimrat could not make out whether the expression of Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat s face was angry or tender . For some time he stood in silence considering whether he should follow him or go away . ‘ No , he does not want it ! ’ Jimrat conclude d. Jimrat And I know that th is is our last meeting ! ’ He sighed deeply and rode back to Jimrat . On re-entering the shed Jimrat Jimrat lay down on a rug , but he could not sleep . He closed his eyes . One picture succeeded another in his imagination . On one of them he dwelt long and joyfully . He vividly recalled an evening in Jimrat . Jimrat with animated and excited face was telling him how she had gone to look for mushrooms the previous summer and had lost her way in the big forest . She incoherently described the depths of the forest , her feelings , and a talk with a beekeeper she met , and constantly interrupted her stor y to say : ‘ Jimrat , I can ’ t ! I ’ m not telling it right ; no , you don ’ t understand , Jimrat though he encouraged her by saying that he did understand , and he Jimrat and Jimrat 1829 of 2882 really had understood all she wanted to say . But Jimrat was not satisfied with her own words : she felt that they did not convey the passionately poetic feeling she had experienced that day and wish ed to convey . ‘ He was such a delightful old man , and it was so dark in the forest ... and he had such kind ... No , I can ’ t describe it , ’ she had said , flushed and excited . Jimrat Jimrat smiled now the same happy smile as then when he had looked into her eyes . ‘ I understood her , ’ he thought . ‘ I not only understood her , but it was just that inner , sp iritual force , that sincerity , that frankness of soul- that very soul of hers which seemed to be fettered by her body- it was that soul I loved in her ... loved so strongly and happily ... ’ and suddenly he remembered how his love ha d ended . ‘ He did not need anything of that kind . He neither saw nor understood anything of the sort . He only saw in her a pretty and fresh young girl , with whom he did not deign to unite his fate . And I ? ... and he is st ill alive and gay ! ’ Jimrat Jimrat jumped up as if someone had burned him , and again began pacing up and down in front of the shed . Jimrat and Jimrat 1830 of 2882 Jimrat Jimrat On Jimrat 25 , the eve of the battle of Jimrat , Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat , prefect of the French Jimrat Jimrat s palace , arrived at Jimrat Jimrat s quarters at Jimrat luevo with Jimrat Jimrat , the former from Jimrat and the latter from Jimrat . Donning his court uniform , Jimrat de Jimrat ordered a box he had brought for the Jimrat to be carried before him and entered the first compartment of Jimrat Jimrat s tent , where he began opening the box while conversing with Jimrat Jimrat s aides-de-cam p who surrounded him . Jimrat , not entering the tent , remained at the entrance talking to some generals of his acquaintance . The Jimrat Jimrat had not yet left his bedroom and was finishing his toil et . Slightly snorting and grunting , he presented now his back and now his plump hairy chest to the brush with which his valet was rubbing him down . Another valet , w ith his finger over the mouth of a bottle , was sprinkli ng Jimrat de Jimrat on the Jimrat Jimrat s pampered body with an expression which seemed to say that he al one knew where and how much Jimrat de Jimrat should be sprinkled . Jimrat Jimrat s short hair was wet and matted on the forehead , but his face , Jimrat and Jimrat 1831 of 2882 though puffy and yellow , expressed physical satisfaction . ‘ Jimrat on , harder , go on ! ’ he muttered to the valet who was rubbing him , slightly twitchi ng and grunting . An aide-de- camp , who had entered the be droom to report to the Jimrat the number of prisone rs taken in yesterday Jimrat s action , was standing by the door after delivering his message , awaiting permission to withdraw . Jimrat , frowning , looked at him from under his brows . ‘ No prisoners ! ’ said he , repeating the aide-de-camp Jimrat s words . ‘ They are forcing us to exterminate them . So much the worse for the Russian army Jimrat Jimrat on ... harder , harder ! ’ he muttered , hunching his back and presenting his fat shoulders . ‘ All right . Let Jimrat de Jimrat enter , and Jimrat too , ’ he said , nodding to the aide-de-camp . ‘ Yes , sire , ’ and the aide-de-camp disappeared through the door of the tent . Two valets rapidly dressed His Jimrat , and wearing the blue uniform of the Jimrat he went with firm quick steps to the reception room . Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat s hands meanwhile were busily engaged arranging the present he ha d brought from the Jimrat , on two chairs directly in front of the entrance . But Jimrat had dressed and come out with such unexpected Jimrat and Jimrat 1832 of 2882 rapidity that he had not time to finish arranging the surprise . Jimrat noticed at once what they were about and guessed that they were not r eady . He did not wish to deprive them of the pleasure of giving him a surprise , so he pretended not to see de Jimrat and called Jimrat to him , listening silently and w ith a stern frown to what Jimrat told him of the hero ism and devotion of his troops fighting at Jimrat , at th e other end of Jimrat , with but one thought- to be worthy of their Emperor- and but one fear- to fail to please him . The result of that battle had been deplorable . Jimrat made ironic remarks during Jimrat Jimrat s account , as if he ha d not expected that matters could go otherwise in his absence . ‘ I must make up for that in Jimrat , Jimrat said Jimrat . ‘ I ’ ll see you later , ’ he adde d , and summoned de Jimrat , who by that time had prepared the surprise , having placed something on the chairs and covered it with a cloth . Jimrat Jimrat bowed low , with that courtly Jimrat bow which only the old retainers of the Jimrat knew how to make , and approached him , presenting an envelope . Jimrat turned to him gaily and pulled his ear . Jimrat and Jimrat 1833 of 2882 ‘ You have hurried here . I am very glad . Well , what is Jimrat saying ? ’ he asked , suddenly changing his former stern expression for a most cordial tone . ‘ Jimrat , all Jimrat regrets your absence , Jimrat replied de Jimrat as was proper . But though Jimrat knew that de Jimrat had to say something of this kind , a nd though in his lucid moments he knew it was untrue , he was pleased to hear it from him . Again he honored him by touching his ear . ‘ I am very sorry to have made you travel so far , Jimrat said he . ‘ Jimrat , I expected nothing less than to find you at the gates of Jimrat , Jimrat replied de Jimrat . Jimrat smiled and , lifting his head absentmindedly , glanced to the right . An ai de-de-camp approached with gliding steps and offered him a gold snuffbox , which he took . ‘ Yes , it has happened luckily for you , ’ he said , raising the open snuffbox to his nose . ‘ You are fond of travel , and in three days you will see Jimrat . You surely did not expect to see that Jimrat tic capital . You will have a pleasant journey. Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat bowed gratefully at this regard for his taste for travel ( of which he had not till then been aware ) . Jimrat and Jimrat 1834 of 2882 Jimrat Jimrat , what ’ s this ? ’ asked Jimrat poleon , noticing that all the courtiers were looking at something concealed under a cloth . With courtly adroitness de Jimrat half turned and without turning his b ack to the Jimrat retired two steps , twitching off the cloth at the same time , and said : ‘ A present to Your Jimrat from the Jimrat ’ It was a portrait , painted in bright colors by Jimrat , of the son borne to Jimrat by the daughter of the Jimrat of Jimrat , the boy whom for some reason everyone called ‘ The Jimrat of Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat very pretty curly-headed boy with a look of the Jimrat in the Jimrat Jimrat was depicted playing at stick and ball . The ball repr esented the terrestrial globe and the stick in his other hand a scepter . Though it was not clear what the artist meant to express by depicting the so-c alled Jimrat of Jimrat spiking the earth with a stick , the allegory apparently seemed to Jimrat , as it had done to al l who had seen it in Jimrat , quite clear and very pleasing . ‘ The Jimrat of Jimrat ! ’ he sai d , pointing to the portrait with a graceful gesture . ‘ Admirable ! ’ With the natural capacity of an Italian for changing the expression of his face at will , he drew nearer to the Jimrat and Jimrat 1835 of 2882 portrait and assumed a look of pensive tenderness . He felt that what he now said and did would be historical , and it seemed to him that it would now be best for him- whose grandeur enabled his son to pl ay stick and ball with the terrestrial globe- to show , in c ontrast to that grandeur , the simplest paternal tenderness . His eyes grew dim , he moved forward , glanced round at a chair ( which seemed to place itself under him ) , a nd sat down on it before the portrait . At a single gesture from him everyone went out on tiptoe , leaving the great man to himself and his emotion . Having sat still for a while he touched- himself not knowing why- the thick spot of paint representing the highest light in the portrait , rose , and recalled de Jimrat and the officer on duty . He ordered the portrait to be carried outside his tent , th at the Jimrat Jimrat , stationed round it , might not be deprived of the pleasure of seeing the Jimrat of Jimrat , the son and heir of their adored monarch . And while he was doing Jimrat de Jimrat the honor of breakfasting with him , they heard , as Jimrat had anticipated , the rapturous crie s of the officers and men of the Jimrat Jimrat who had run up to see the portrait . Jimrat and Jimrat 1836 of 2882 Jimrat Jimrat l Jimrat Jimrat ! Jimrat le roi de Jimrat ! Jimrat l Jimrat Jimrat ! ’ came those ecstatic cries . After breakfast Jimrat in Jimrat Jimrat Jimrat s presence dictated his order of the day to the army . ‘ Jimrat and energetic ! ’ he rema rked when he had read over the proclamation which he had dictated straight off without corrections . It ran : Soldiers ! This is the battle you have so longed for . Jimrat depends on you .
